revision.text:
{{short description|Series of Jeep pickup trucks}} {{other uses|Gladiator (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox automobile | image = Jeep Honcho.jpg | caption = Jeep J20 Pickup | name = Jeep Gladiator / Jeep Pickup | manufacturer = {{ubl |[[Willys|Willys Motors]] (1962) | [[Kaiser Jeep|Kaiser-Jeep]] (1963-70) | [[American Motors]] (1970-87) | [[Chrysler]] (1987-88) }} | body_style = 2-door [[pickup truck]] | Designer = [[Brooks Stevens]] | layout = [[Front-engine design|Front-engine]], [[rear-wheel drive]] / [[four-wheel drive]] | production = 1962-1988 | predecessor = [[Willys Jeep Truck]]
[[Jeep Forward Control]] | successor = [[Jeep Comanche]] | engine = {{ubl |{{convert|230|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[Jeep Tornado engine|Tornado]]'' [[Straight-six engine|I6]] | {{convert|232|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[AMC Straight-6 engine|AMC]]'' I6 | {{convert|258|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[AMC Straight-6 engine|AMC]]'' I6 | {{convert|327|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[AMC V8 engine#327|AMC Vigilante]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]] | {{convert|350|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Buick]] ''[[Buick V8 engine#350|Dauntless]]'' V8 | {{convert|360|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[AMC V8 engine|AMC]]'' V8 | {{convert|401|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[AMC V8 engine|AMC]]'' V8 }} | transmission = {{ubl |3-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]] | 4-speed manual | 3-speed [[General Motors|GM]] ''[[Turbo-Hydramatic|THM400]]'' [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] | 3-speed [[Chrysler]] ''[[TorqueFlite|A727]]'' automatic }} | wheelbase = {{ubl | {{convert|120|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | {{convert|126|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | {{convert|132|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | {{convert|165|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} chassis camper }} | related = [[Jeep Wagoneer (SJ)]] }}{{This article is about|the 1962-1988 Gladiator|the 2020 Gladiator model based on the [[Jeep Wrangler (JL)|fourth-generation Jeep Wrangler]]|Jeep Gladiator (JT)}} The '''[[Jeep]] Gladiator''', '''Jeep Pickup''' or '''J-series''' is a series of full-size [[pickup truck]]s based on the large [[Jeep SJ]] ([[Jeep Wagoneer (SJ)|Wagoneer]]) platform, which was built and sold under numerous marques from 1962 to 1988. The Jeep Gladiator / Pickup design is noteworthy for remaining in production for more than 26 years on a single [[automobile platform]] generation. The Gladiator was the basis of the first post-war U.S. Army trucks designed to be civilian vehicles and adapted to military use. Numerous versions of the Jeep pickup were built in other markets, including Mexico by [[Vehículos Automotores Mexicanos]]. The Gladiator nameplate was revived on a midsize pickup truck based on the fourth-generation [[Jeep Wrangler (JL)]]. It was unveiled at the Los Angeles Auto Show on November 28, 2018. ==Gladiator 1962-1971== [[File:1964 Jeep Pick-Up (14296525169).jpg|thumb|left|1964 short wheelbase Jeep Gladiator Townside]] [[File:Jeep Gladiator J300 (2406095893).jpg|thumb|left|Long-wheelbase J300 with a hardtop on the bed]] Introduced in 1962 for the 1963 [[model year]], the Gladiator was a conventional body on frame pickup design that shared its basic frame architecture and front end with the Jeep Wagoneer four-wheel-drive station wagon.{{cite web|url= http://www.allpar.com/trucks/jeep/gladiator.html |title=1963-1987 Jeep Gladiator and J-Series Pickups |publisher=allpar.com/trucks |accessdate=16 January 2014}} Gladiators were available in [[Rear-wheel drive|RWD]] and [[Four-wheel drive|4WD]], with optional dual rear wheels.{{cite web|url= http://www.txfsja.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=19&t=11 |title=Jeep Dually Tech & Specs |author=Elliot |date=22 April 2009 |publisher=Jeep Dually Registry |accessdate=16 January 2014}} A remarkable innovation was the available [[independent suspension|independent front suspension]] instead of a solid front axle on the 4WD half-ton Gladiator trucks. It was a simple IFS design with a Dana 44 center section, that proved troublesome, didn’t sell well, and the option was deleted in 1965.[http://www.fourwheeler.com/features/1502-1963-jeep-wagoneer-custom-backward-glances/ 1963 Jeep Wagoneer Custom – Backward Glances] Most likely very few were produced with this option. Gladiator trucks were available as: Cab and Chassis; Wrecker; Stake Bed; and [[chassis]]-mounted campers with extended wheelbases. The load bed options were Townside, Thriftside (a "step-side"), and Stake Bed, with up to {{convert|8600|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} G.V.W. and almost two-ton payload capacity. A new [[overhead camshaft|overhead cam]] [[Jeep Tornado engine]] {{convert|230|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[straight-six]] producing {{convert|140|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} was standard. It was the first production overhead cam engine in an American light truck or SUV and one of the first OHC engines offered by an American manufacturer.
Further innovations for four-wheel-drive pickups included optional automatic transmission (an industry first), as well as power brakes, power steering, and just like early post-war Jeeps a [[power take-off]] for numerous accessories that included snow plows and push plates. In early 1963, [[Willys|Willys Motors]] changed its name to [[Kaiser Jeep|Kaiser Jeep Corporation]]. During 1965 the {{convert|327|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC V8 engine]] became available. It produced {{convert|250|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|340|lb.ft|N·m|0}} of torque at 2600 rpm. The standard Tornado engine was replaced by American Motors' {{convert|232|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} OHV [[Straight-6|inline six]]. In 1967 all (RWD) two-wheel drive versions, except for the J-100 panel delivery, were dropped due to poor sales.[http://www.jeeptech.com/models/jpu.htm Full Size Jeeps - J-Series Pickups — JeepTech] For 1968, the flared-fender Thriftside models were dropped while a new camper option was added for the J-3600. From 1968 to 1971 Jeep pickups offered the [[Buick]] {{convert|350|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} {{convert|230|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} [[Buick V8 engine#350|Dauntless]] V8 as an optional engine. [[American Motors|American Motors Corporation]] (AMC) purchased the Kaiser Jeep operations in 1970 when Kaiser Industries decided to leave the automobile business. The Jeep trucks moved to all AMC engines to improve performance and standardize production and servicing. The Buick engine was replaced by the {{convert|360|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} or {{convert|401|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC V8 engine|AMC V8]]s. In 1970, the Gladiator's front grille was changed to the same design as the Jeep Wagoneer SUV. This was the truck's first styling change since its introduction. An AMC badge was also added on the grille. ==Jeep pickup 1971-1988== [[File:Jeep J-10 pick-up blue f md.jpg|thumb|Jeep J10 pickup]] [[File:Wellington Free Ambulance Jeep - Flickr - 111 Emergency (1).jpg|thumb|J20-based Ambulance built like a chassis-camper (New Zealand)]] The Gladiator name was dropped after 1971, after which the line was known simply as the Jeep pickup, or J-series. The pickups were designated as J2000 and J4000 models (the 3000 series was dropped in 1971) until 1973, then as J10 and J20 models from 1974 to 1988. Engines: From 1971 to 1972 Jeep pickups offered the AMC {{convert|304|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} {{convert|210|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} V8 as an optional engine. The AMC {{convert|258|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} I6 engine was introduced in 1972 and offered through 1988. The engine produced {{convert|112|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|210|lb.ft|N·m|0|abbr=on}} of torque. The [[AMC V8 engine#360|AMC 360]] cu in (5.9L) was offered in 1971 and through 1988. Producing in early versions {{convert|175|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|245|lb.ft|N·m|0|abbr=on}} of torque. Later 360s produced {{convert|195|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|295|lb.ft|N·m|0|abbr=on}} of torque. The model designations were simplified for 1974, with the J-2000 and the J-4000, which designate wheelbase, being swapped out for the J-10 and J-20, designating payload capacity. Larger brakes were made standard and the turning radius reduced. The Quadra-Trac system was now available with all engines. The AMC {{convert|401|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} was offered from 1974 through 1978. These engines are known for their toughness and excellent power output. The 401 produced {{convert|225|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|320|lb.ft|N·m|0|abbr=on}} of torque. For 1977, Jeep J-10 pickups included [[Dana Holding Corporation|Dana]]'s manual four-wheel-drive system, a more powerful {{convert|258|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} six-cylinder engine, and heavier axle tubes, while power front disc brakes became standard equipment and the considerably greater GWV capacity J-20s included AMC's {{convert|360|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 engine.{{cite journal|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=5OEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA73&lpg=PA73&dq=Jeep+J-20 |page=73 |title=Over-the-counter pickups |journal=Popular Mechanics |date=December 1976 |volume=73 |issue=6 |accessdate=16 January 2014 }} The {{convert|401|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} engine was optional, as well as full-time [[Quadra-Trac]] and both automatic and manual transmissions. 1983 saw the new full-time four-wheel drive system, Selec-Trac, replace Quadra-Trac. From 1981 to 1985 a rebodied version of the J-10 was built and sold as the [[Jeep CJ#CJ-10|Jeep CJ-10]], featuring a CJ-like nose and cab, as well as a very boxy redesigned rear truck-bed, somewhat resembling that of a Land-Rover. [[Chrysler]] bought out AMC in 1987. The full-size Jeep Pickup line was not only an aging model, but also competed directly with the broader range of [[Dodge]] trucks. Chrysler discontinued the full-size Jeep trucks, but continued to build the luxurious and highly profitable [[Jeep Wagoneer (SJ)|Grand Wagoneer]], which shared the chassis with the large pickups. After the Chrysler buyout, the compact [[Jeep Comanche]] pickup (based on the [[Jeep Cherokee (XJ)]] platform) received only minor changes and its production continued until 1992.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/06/business/company-news-chrysler-to-end-production-of-jeep-comanche.html |title=Chrysler to end production of Jeep Comanche |date=6 June 1992 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=16 January 2014}} ==Military versions== [[File:Jeep M725, military ambulance.jpg|thumb|right|U.S. military M725 ambulance]] {{main|Kaiser Jeep M715}} Military versions of the civilian Jeep pickup included the [[Kaiser Jeep M715|M715]] and M725, built from 1967 to 1969. They were built under contract for nations in addition to the United States. The idea was to reduce costs by starting from a civilian truck and sharing parts with normal production-line truck, like the later “[[Commercial Utility Cargo Vehicle]]” (CUCV) for the military as a 5/4 ton tactical vehicle. [[File:Klargöringsbil 9711 med amsläpkärra.jpg|thumb|right|''Klargöringsbil 9711'' of The Swedish Air Force]] The [[Swedish Air Force]] acquired 450 Gladiator vehicles in the early 1980s. They were given the local designations ''Klargöringsbil 9711'' and ''Klargöringsbil 9712'', with the latter variant being equipped with a hardtop. The vehicles were modified to be used by aircraft groundcrew for mobile flight line operations in the Swedish [[Bas 90]] system, and could carry trailers with equipment and tow aircraft. It is often informally referred to as "The Dallas Jeep".{{Cite web|url=https://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=105&artikel=6588160|title=Ny version av övning från kalla kriget|language=Swedish}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.femorefortet.se/Kalla-FV.htm|title=Femörefortet - Kalla krigets svenska försvar|language=Swedish}} ==Trim packages== [[File:Honchotruck.JPG|thumb|right|Jeep J10 Honcho]] From 1975, Jeep tried making their pickups more "car-like" and appealing to consumers, starting with the Pioneer package, featuring a fancier interior, woodgrain interior and exterior trim, chromed front bumpers, window moldings, and wheel covers, dual horns, and other “car” features. From 1976-1983 the "Honcho" [[trim package]] was offered on the J10 pickup. It consisted of bold striping and decals, and was offered with factory extras such as the [[Levi's]] interior or a [[roll cage|roll bar]]. The content of the Honcho package varied from year to year, but "always included the wide-track look of the Cherokee Chief."{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=zTsAbTJB5RIC&pg=PA171&lpg=PA171&dq=Jeep+Honcho+package+varied+always+included+wide-track+Cherokee+Chief |page=171 |last=Allen |first=Jim |title=Jeep |year=2004 |publisher=MBI Publishing |isbn=978-0-7603-1979-6 |accessdate=16 January 2014|authorlink=Jim Allen (4x4 writer)}} The Honcho was one in a series of special decal packages offered for J-Series trucks in the mid to late 1970s, which included the 1977–1979 Golden Eagle{{cite web|url= http://www.angelfire.com/nb2/jeeppickups/Golden%20Eagle%2011.jpg |title=The new Jeep J-10 Golden Eagle (image) |publisher=The Jeep Pickups Page |accessdate=16 January 2014}} and the 1978 "10-4" version which offered an optional [[Citizens' Band radio]] along with the decals. The Honcho package was only available on the sportside (stepside) and short bed trucks. Between 1980 and 1983, only 1,264 of the sportside versions were produced. Decal packages were available for many of Jeep's vehicles in the 1970s, including a package for the [[Jeep Cherokee (SJ)|Jeep Cherokee]] called the Cherokee Chief.{{cite web|url= http://www.adclassix.com/images80cherokee.jpg |title=Jeep Cherokee Chief (advertisement) |publisher=adclassix.com |accessdate=16 January 2014 }} The Golden Eagle package was also available for both the CJ and the Cherokee.{{cite web|url= http://www.phoenixgraphix.com/amc/7780ge.jpg |title=Jeep CJ Golden Eagle (picture) |publisher=phoenixgraphix.com |accessdate=16 January 2014}} The 1980 (1981 model year) Laredo package was perhaps the most luxurious one, including leather bucket seats, and leather-wrapped steering wheel, chrome interior trim, and a state-of-the-art Alpine sound system. == Jeep truck concepts == Jeep has shown numerous [[Concept car|concept]] pickup trucks, and officials at the automaker have "expressed interest in putting such a vehicle into production."{{cite web |url=http://wot.motortrend.com/jeeps-future-does-it-include-a-small-pickup-truck-9022.html |title=Jeep’s Future: Does It Include a Small Pickup Truck? |first=Andrew |last=Peterson |date=21 June 2010 |publisher=Motor Trend |accessdate=16 January 2014}} ===2003 small pickup truck=== A production-ready version of a Jeep Scrambler pickup was shown in 2003 at the North American Dealers Association, but was pulled after a few hours. According to ''Motor Trend'', there might be a "production Jeep pickup truck in the works". ===2005 Jeep Gladiator=== [[File:Picturegladiator 203.jpg|thumb|right|Jeep Gladiator at the 2005 [[Chicago Auto Show]]]] In late-2004 a new '''Jeep Gladiator''' [[Concept car|concept]] was introduced. While not officially intended to be sold, it was used as a demonstration "that a Jeep pickup was in the dark recesses of DaimlerChrysler's brain trust.{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YXow9otLiI8C&pg=PA147&lpg=PA147&dq=2005+Gladiator+vehicle+demonstrated+that+a+Jeep+pickup+was+in+the+dark+recesses+of+DaimlerChrysler's+brain+trust |title=The Joy of Jeep |page=147 |first=Tom |last=Morr |first2=Ken |last2=Brubaker |publisher=MBI Publishing |isbn=978-0-7603-3061-6 |year=2007 |accessdate=16 January 2014}} The Gladiator concept features an open-air [[canvas]] roof, fold-down [[windshield]], removable doors, and has an expandable truck bed. The Gladiator has a 2.8-liter, [[Straight-4|4-cylinder]] common-rail turbo [[diesel engine]] that provides {{convert|165|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|295|lb.ft|N·m|0|abbr=on}} of torque. The truck has a 6-speed [[manual transmission]]. Ground clearance is {{convert|13.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}, with a [[break-over angle]] of 23.2°, an [[approach angle]] of 47.6° and departure angle of 38.0°. Front and rear tires are {{convert|34|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} and are mounted on 18x8-inch wheels. The Jeep Gladiator has a {{convert|1500|lb|kg|0|adj=on}} [[Cargo|payload]].{{cite web|url= http://trucks.about.com/od/conceptcars/ss/jeep_gladiator.htm |title=Jeep Gladiator Concept |publisher=trucks about com |accessdate=16 January 2014}} A "midgate" made the concept Gladiator truck closer to an imitation of the [[Chevrolet Avalanche]], "than an attempt to revive its namesake's glory." The 2005 Gladiator Concept was also a preview of the all-new 2007 [[Jeep Wrangler (JK)]] and [[Jeep Wrangler (JK)]] Unlimited, and featured nearly identical exterior and interior styling to the production model of the 2007-2017 [[Jeep Wrangler (JK)]]. ===2012 Jeep J12=== In March, Jeep announced a revealing of a new concept at the Easter Jeep Safari in Moab, Utah. The J-12 is based on a modified Wrangler Unlimited chassis with a {{convert|18|in|mm|0|adj=on}} frame extension allowing the use of a {{convert|6|ft|mm|0|adj=on}} load bed.{{cite web|url=http://blog.caranddriver.com/jeep-shows-off-six-concepts-headed-for-2012-moab-easter-jeep-safari/ |title=Jeep Mighty FC and J-12 Pickups Among Six Concepts Revealed for 2012 Moab Easter Safari |date=27 March 2012 |first=Alexander |last=Stoklosa |publisher=Car and Driver |accessdate=16 January 2014}} The styling resembles the classic 1960s-era Jeep Gladiator truck and features "old-school" 16-inch smooth steel wheels with 36-inch tires, as well as a full bench seat in the cab. === 2016 Jeep Crew Chief 715 === At the 2016 Jeep Safari in Moab, Utah, Jeep revealed seven new concepts including a '''Crew Chief 715''' pickup with four-doors and a 5-foot cargo bed.{{cite web|last=Priddle |first=Alisa |title=2016 Easter Jeep Safari Concepts |url= http://www.motortrend.com/news/2016-easter-jeep-safari-concepts/ |publisher=Motor Trend |date=10 March 2016 |accessdate=18 December 2017}} The design was inspired by the [[Kaiser Jeep M715]] military vehicle from the late 1960s that was based on the regular civilian production Jeep Gladiator pickup.{{cite web|last=Sutton |first=Mike |title=Jeep Crew Chief 715 Concept Dissected |url= https://www.caranddriver.com/features/jeep-crew-chief-715-concept-dissected-feature |date=May 2016 |publisher=Car and Driver |accessdate=18 December 2017}} The Jeep Crew Chief concept rides on 20-inch [[beadlock]] wheels, and 40-inch military tires, but is mostly based on a Wrangler Unlimited stretched to a {{convert|139|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} wheelbase.{{cite web|last=Brubaker |first=Ken |title=Jeep Crew Chief 715 Exposed At Moab EJS 2016 - Day 3: Exclusive Photos, Video, Opinions |url= http://www.fourwheeler.com/moab-experience/2016/1603-jeep-crew-chief-715-exposed-at-moab-ejs-2016-day-3-exclusive-photos-video-opinions/ |publisher=Four Wheeler |date=22 March 2016 |accessdate=18 December 2017}} {{clear}} ==Notes== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Jeep Gladiator}} {{commons category|Jeep Honcho}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120712070717/http://wagoneers.com/FSJ/ Wagoneers.com Full Size Jeeps since 1995] * [http://www.ifsja.org/ International Full Size Jeep Association] * [http://jeeptruck.com/ JeepTruck.com for Jeep Truck enthusiasts] * {{imcdb vehicle|make=Jeep|model=Gladiator|Jeep Gladiator}} * {{imcdb vehicle|make=Jeep|model=Pickup|Jeep Pickup}} {{Jeep early timeline}} {{Jeep Car Timeline}} [[Category:Jeep vehicles|Gladiator]] [[Category:Pickup trucks]] [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Vehicles introduced in 1962]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:1970s cars]] [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:Kaiser Motors]] [[Category:Willys vehicles]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Trucks of the United States]] [[Category:Jeep concept vehicles|Gladiator]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2019}} {{Infobox automobile | image = Jeep-Comanche-Pioneer.jpg | caption = Jeep Comanche Pioneer | name = Jeep Comanche | manufacturer = [[Jeep]]
[[American Motors]] (1985-1987)
[[Chrysler Corporation]] (1987-1992) | class = Compact [[pickup truck]] | body_style = 2-door truck | predecessor = [[Jeep_CJ#Scrambler_(CJ-8)|Jeep CJ-8 (Scrambler)]]
[[Jeep_CJ#CJ-10|Jeep CJ-10]]
[[Jeep Gladiator (SJ)]] | successor = [[Dodge Dakota#First Generation|Dodge Dakota]]
[[Jeep Gladiator (JT)]] | production = 1985{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4pqgGnFY6w0C&q=Jeep+Comanche+Introduction+of+the+1986+Jeep+trucks+took+place+in+the+fall+of+1985 |title=Standard catalog of 4 x 4's |first=Robert C. |last=Ackerson |page=458 |publisher=Krause Publications |year=1993 |isbn=978-0-87341-203-2 |accessdate=July 4, 2011 }}–1992 | model_years = 1986–1992 | layout = [[Front-engine design|Front engine]], [[rear-wheel drive|rear-wheel]] and [[four-wheel drive]] | platform = | engine = {{nowrap|2.1 L [[Douvrin engine#2.1 Diesel|Renault J8S]] [[Turbocharger|turbo]] [[Diesel engine|diesel]] [[Straight-4|I4]]}}
{{nowrap|2.5 L (150 CID) ''[[AMC straight-4 engine|AMC 150]]'' I4}}
{{nowrap|2.8 L [[General Motors|GM]] ''[[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LR2|LR2]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]]}}
{{nowrap|4.0 L (242 CID) ''[[AMC Straight 6 engine#4.0|AMC 242]]'' [[Straight-6|I6]]}} | transmission = 4-speed [[Aisin]] ''AX-4'' manual
5-speed [[Aisin]] ''AX-5'' manual
5-speed [[Peugeot]] ''BA-10/5'' [[Manual transmission|manual]]
5-speed [[Aisin]] ''[[Aisin AX15 transmission|AX-15]]'' manual
3-speed ''[[TorqueFlite|A904]]'' automatic
4-speed [[Aisin]] ''AW-4'' [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] | wheelbase = {{convert|113|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} Short Wheel Base{{cite web|url= http://www.comanchemj.1hwy.com/photo6.html |title=The Complete Comanche History |author=Rob L. |accessdate=February 2, 2017}}
{{convert|119.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} Long Wheel Base | length = {{convert|179.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} Short Bed
{{convert|194.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} Long Bed | width = {{convert|71.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|64.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | related = [[Jeep Cherokee (XJ)|Jeep Cherokee]] }} The '''Jeep Comanche''' (designated '''MJ''') is a [[pickup truck]] variant of the [[Jeep Cherokee (XJ)|Cherokee]] [[compact SUV]] (1984–2001){{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f-QDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA42&dq=Jeep+Comanche+introduction |first=Daniel Charles |last=Ross |title=Detroit Listening Post |journal=Popular Mechanics |date=October 1985 |volume=161 |issue=10 |page=42 |accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} manufactured and marketed by [[Jeep]] for model years 1986-1992 in [[Rear wheel drive|rear wheel]] (RWD) and [[four-wheel drive]] (4WD) models as well as two cargo bed lengths: six-foot (1.83 metres) and seven-foot (2.13 metres).{{cite web|url= http://www.allpar.com/trucks/jeep/comanche.html |title=The Jeep Comanche (1986-1992) |work=Allpar |accessdate=February 2, 2017}} ==Introduction== During the mid-1980s, according to AMC chairman W. Paul Tippett Jr. "People are finding trucks a reasonable and sophisticated alternative to cars."{{cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,923832-1,00.html |journal=Time |date=December 17, 1984 |title=Pickups Make a Haul |first=Alexander L. |last=Taylor III |first2=Paul A. |last2=Witteman |first3=Meg |last3=Grant |accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} To satisfy the demand and to compete with Japanese competitors, both AMC and Chrysler were preparing compact pickups for the 1986 and 1987 model years (respectively). Also at this time the financial health of AMC was poor and the automaker was in need of cash as it was preparing a new line of midsize sedans (the [[Eagle Premier]]) scheduled to be produced at a factory being built in Canada ([[Brampton Assembly]]), but the best thing the company had going for it was its popular line of Jeeps and introducing a compact Jeep pickup truck in the fall of 1985 was expected to help.{{cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,957751,00.html |journal=Time |date=June 3, 1985 |title=Autos: Expensive, Old and Inefficient |accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} The Jeep Comanche was introduced in mid-August 1985, at a lavish event staged at the ballroom of the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino (currently [[Bally's Las Vegas]]) for AMC's over 1,500 North American dealers.{{cite book| url=https://archive.org/details/beijingjeepcases00mann | url-access=registration |title=Beijing Jeep: a case study of Western business in China |first=Jim |last=Mann |pages=[https://archive.org/details/beijingjeepcases00mann/page/n14 13]–15 |publisher=Westview Press |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-8133-3327-4 |accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} American Motors included Chinese officials as part of the negotiations establishing Beijing Jeep (now [[Beijing Benz]]). The goal was to produce and sell Comanches in China through this [[joint venture]]. The new trucks were unveiled by [[Jose Dedeurwaerder]], an engineer and international business executive with 23 years of experience with [[Renault]], who had just been appointed as AMC's new president.https://www.nytimes.com/1985/06/27/business/business-people-chairman-of-amc-to-join-textile-concern.html The base price of the two-wheel drive model was $7,049 (adjusted only for inflation equal to US${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|7049|1985}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}), making it the lowest priced Jeep model for the 1986 model year.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D05p17q4cSYC&pg=PA198&dq=Jeep+Comanche+introduction |title=The Story of Jeep |first=Patrick R. |last=Foster |page=198 |publisher=KP Books |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-87349-735-0|accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} ==Design== American Motors' Jeep designers based the Comanche MJ body, styling, engineering, and drivetrain on the [[Jeep Cherokee (XJ)|XJ Cherokee]], which had been introduced for the 1984 model year. The Comanche had a somewhat more conventional body-on-frame design behind the cab and a removable cargo box, but retained the unibody construction of the Cherokee in the front half of the vehicle. In the United States where the Comanche and [[Dodge Rampage]] were sold they are both considered pickup trucks. By contrast, in other markets the Volkswagen Rabbit Pickup was called the [[Volkswagen Caddy]] and considered a [[Coupé utility|coupe utility]], not a truck because the cargo bed is an integral part of the body structure and not removable. However this is not the legal definition of truck in the United States where the Comanche, Rampage and Rabbit were all sold. Two cargo bed lengths were used; one for the seven-foot long-bed model, which appeared first in 1986, and a second, shorter version for the six-foot cargo bed, which debuted for the 1987 model year. Unlike other pickups of the time that used C-channel frames, the Comanche's frame design (called a "Uniframe" by Jeep) under the cargo bed was fully boxed, with a large X structure centered over the rear axle. For strength, the rails were over eight inches deep (top to bottom), much deeper than conventional midsize truck frames (1983 Jeep J-10 full-size truck frame is 6.75 inches at the deepest point). This structure was pioneered by AMC for the 1971 "[[AMC Hornet#Cowboy|Cowboy]]" compact pickup prototype.{{cite web|url= http://vintagetruckmagazine.com/1971-amc-jeep-cowboy/ |title=1971 AMC Jeep Cowboy—What Might Have Been |date=October 5, 2015 |first=Rich |last=Truesdell |work=Vintage Truck Magazine |accessdate=February 2, 2017}} From 1986 to 1987, the Jeep Comanche [[grille]] had ten slots in a similar configuration to the 1984-1987 Cherokee XJ, while from 1988 to 1992, this configuration changed to eight slots to match with the SUV.{{cite book |author=Bureau of National Affairs |title=The United States patents quarterly |chapter=AM General Corp v. DaimlerChrysler |page=1015 |publisher=Associated Industry Publications |year=2003 }} A new "4x4" badge, similar to those found on the Cherokee and Wagoneer models, was affixed to the upper rear of the cargo box on all the four-wheel drive models. After the Chrysler buyout of American Motors for $1.5 billion on March 9, 1987, designed to capture "the highly profitable Jeep vehicles ... and 1,400 additional dealers",{{cite news|last=Holusha|first=John|title=Chrysler is Buying American Motors; Cost is $1.5 billion|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/business/chrysler-is-buying-american-motors-cost-is-1.5-billion.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=March 10, 1987 |accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} the Jeep Comanche, like the similar Cherokee, received only minor changes. These were primarily to improve reliability and parts interchangeability with other Chrysler-built vehicles. ==Suspension== [[File:Jeep Comanche Pioneer white MD r.jpg|thumb|right|Jeep Comanche Pioneer]] [[File:Jeep Comanche Chief.jpg|thumb|Jeep Comanche Chief with aftermarket modifications]] The Comanche used the XJ Cherokee's "Quadralink" front suspension, with coil springs and upper/lower control arms on a solid axle. It was argued that the coil springs allowed for greater ride comfort and axle articulation during off-road excursions. A track bar ([[Panhard rod]]) is used to keep the axle centered under the truck. Modified versions of this same basic suspension system were later used on the 1993-2004 [[Jeep Grand Cherokee|Grand Cherokee]], 1997 and newer [[Jeep Wrangler#TJ (1997–2006)|TJ Wrangler]]s and 1994 and newer [[Dodge Ram]]s. For the rear suspension, the truck used leaf springs that are considerably longer than the Cherokee's, which give Comanches good load-carrying capacity without creating a hard ride. The standard rear axle was the same [[Dana 35]] used in the Cherokee, except that the Comanche mounted the leaf springs underneath the axle, as do most other trucks, and the Cherokee mounted them on top of the axle. There was also a heavy duty Metric Ton package for the long-bed models. The package included heavier-duty leaf springs and wheels, larger tires, and upgraded the rear axle to a [[Dana 44]], which increased the stock payload ([[cargo]]) capacity from {{convert|1400|to|2205|lb|kg}}, well above that of any other mid-size truck. The Metric Ton Comanche's payload rating was higher than that of many full-size pickups. ==Drivetrain== The inaugural 1986 model year Comanches could be equipped with one of three engines: AMC's [[AMC straight-4 engine|2.5 L four-cylinder]] as standard, with [[General Motors]]' [[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LR2|2.8 L V6]] or [[Renault]]'s 2.1 L I4 [[turbo]] [[Diesel engine|diesel]] available as options. In base trim the four-cylinder engine was backed by a four-speed manual transmission, with either a five-speed manual or three-speed [[TorqueFlite]] A904 automatic built by [[Chrysler]] as an option. The [[V6 engine]] was available with either the five-speed manual or the automatic, while the turbodiesel was only available with the five-speed. The V6 was the same engine used in the competing [[Chevrolet S-10]], and equipped with a two-barrel [[Rochester Products Division|Rochester]] [[carburetor]] instead of the four-cylinder's electronic throttle-body [[fuel injection]] system the optional six-cylinder was slightly less powerful than the standard four. The V6 thus offered little performance advantage over the base engine while penalizing the owner with poorer fuel economy. In the truck's second year on the market the V6 was replaced by [[AMC Straight 6 engine#4.0|AMC's new fuel-injected 4.0 L straight-six]] that developed {{convert|173|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|220|lb.ft|N.m|0|abbr=on}}: 50% more power and 47% more torque than the previous V6.{{cite news| title=New Fuel-Injected Engine Adds Power to Jeep Models |newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |date=October 21, 1986 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jWoeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3WkEAAAAIBAJ&dq=jeep%20comanche&pg=2538%2C1254657 |page=5F |accessdate=August 24, 2012}} The new six-cylinder was also more fuel-efficient. The performance of the base 2.5 L engine was also improved with a new air intake, raising peak output to 121 hp and 141 lb⋅ft. The slow-selling turbodiesel option was dropped during the model year. Concurrent with introduction of the new straight-six a new four-speed automatic built by [[Aisin Seiki|Aisin-Warner]] replaced the former Chrysler three-speed. The [[Toyota A transmission#A340E (30-40LE)|30-40LE]] featured electronic controls with a switch on the dashboard allowing the driver to choose between two performance modes: "Power", in which the transmission downshifts more quickly and upshifts at higher rpm during hard acceleration, and "Comfort", in which the upshifts are made at lower engine speeds to conserve fuel and reduce engine noise and vibration.{{cite magazine |last=Dunne |first=Jim |date=October 1986 |title=Power to the people |page=72 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=z-MDAAAAMBAJ |magazine=Popular Mechanics |volume=163 |issue=10 |location=New York City |publisher=The Hearst Corporation |access-date=January 5, 2019}} In 1988 output of the 4.0 L engine was improved slightly to 177 hp and 224 lb⋅ft. Chrysler purchased AMC in 1987, and by the 1991 model year adapted their own engine control electronics to replace the original [[Renix]] systems used with the 2.5 L and 4.0 L engines. Power and torque in both engines improved as a result, with the four-cylinder having an additional 9 hp and 8 lb⋅ft and the six-cylinder improving by 1 lb⋅ft and 13 hp. The 4.0 L was badged "High Output" thereafter. As a result of the power improvements the Aisin-Warner automatic transmission's output shaft was changed from 21 splines to 23, and the "Power-Comfort" switch was deleted. The four-cylinder was no longer available with the automatic in 1991 and 1992. During the production life of the Comanche six different transmissions were offered, manufactured by [[Aisin]], [[Chrysler]], and [[Peugeot]]. Chrysler provided the aforementioned TorqueFlite 904 three-speed automatic in 1986 models. In addition to the aforementioned 30-40LE four-speed automatic Aisin also provided the AX-4 (four-speed), AX-5 and AX-15 (five-speed overdrive) manual transmissions. The AX-15 was phased in midway through the 1989 model year to replace the Peugeot BA10/5 five-speed that had been used behind the 4.0 L engine from its introduction in 1987. Comanches were available in either two or four-wheel-drive, with solid axles front and rear (two-wheel-drive Comanches used a simple beam axle with otherwise the same front suspension as four-wheel-drive models). [[Transfer case]]s were built by [[New Venture Gear|New Process Gear]], and the Comanche was available with either part-time "Command-Trac" or full-time "Selec-Trac" systems. In 1986 Command-Trac transfer cases were model NP207 and Selec-Trac were NP228, both with a 2.61:1 low gear ratios. In 1987 the NP207 was replaced with the NP231 and NP228 was replaced with the NP242, both with 2.72:1 low gears. These remained the same through the rest of the Comanche's production. ===Engines=== {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="0" style="text-align:center; font-size:88%;" |- style="background:#dcdcdc; text-align:center; vertical-align:middle;" !Name !Displacement !Layout !Fuel !Power !Torque !Notes !Years |- |rowspan=3|'''2.5 Litre''' |rowspan=3|2464 cc (150 CID) |rowspan=3|[[Inline-four engine|I4]], [[Overhead valve|OHV]] |rowspan=3|[[Gasoline]] |{{convert|117|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 5,000 rpm |{{convert|135|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 3,250 rpm |[[Renix]] [[Throttle-body injection|TBI]] |1986 |- |{{convert|121|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 5,000 rpm |{{convert|141|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 3,500 rpm |Renix TBI |1987–1990 |- |{{convert|130|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 5,250 rpm |{{convert|149|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 3,250 rpm |[[Chrysler]] [[Multi-point fuel injection|MPI]] |1991–1992 |- |'''2.8 L V6''' |2838 cc (173 CID) |[[V6 engine|V6]], OHV |Gasoline |{{convert|115|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 4,800 rpm{{cite magazine |last=Keebler |first=Jack |date=February 1986 |title=Pickup showdown—can Detroit hold off the imports? |page=42 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=113OPTBSLVkC |magazine=Popular Science |volume=228 |issue=2 |location=New York City |publisher=Bonnier Corporation |access-date=January 5, 2019}} |{{convert|150|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 2,100 rpm |[[Chevrolet]] [[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LR2|LR2]] |1986 |- |'''2.1 L TurboDiesel''' |2068 cc (126 CID) |I4, [[Single overhead camshaft|SOHC]] |[[Diesel fuel|Diesel]] |{{convert|85|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 3,750 rpm |{{convert|132|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 2,750 rpm |[[Renault]] [[Douvrin engine|J8S]] |1986–1987 |- |rowspan=3|'''4.0 Litre''' |rowspan=3|3964 cc (242 CID) |rowspan=3|[[Straight-6|I6]], OHV |rowspan=3|Gasoline |{{convert|173|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 4,500 rpm |{{convert|220|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 2,500 rpm |Renix MPI |1987 |- |{{convert|177|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 4,500 rpm |{{convert|224|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 2,500 rpm |Renix MPI |1988–1990 |- |{{convert|190|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 4,750 rpm |{{convert|225|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 3,950 rpm |Chrysler MPI, "High Output" |1991–1992 |} ===Transmissions=== {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="0" style="text-align:center; font-size:88%;" |- style="background:#dcdcdc; text-align:center; vertical-align:middle;" !Name !Type !Engine !Years |- |'''Aisin AX-4''' |Manual, 4-speed |2.5 Litre |1986–1992 |- |rowspan=3|'''Aisin AX-5''' |rowspan=3|Manual, 5-speed |2.5 Litre |1986–1992 |- |2.8 L V6 |1986 |- |2.1 L TurboDiesel |1986–1987 |- |rowspan=2|'''TorqueFlite A904''' |rowspan=2|Automatic, 3-speed |2.5 Litre |rowspan=2|1986 |- |2.8 L V6 |- |rowspan=2|'''Aisin-Warner 30-40LE''' |rowspan=2|Automatic, 4-speed |2.5 Litre |1987–1990 |- |4.0 Litre |1987–1992 |- |'''Peugeot BA10/5''' |Manual, 5-speed |4.0 Litre |1987–1989 (march 9th) |- |'''Aisin AX-15''' |Manual, 5-speed |4.0 Litre |1989 (march 10th) –1992 |- |} ==Trims== [[File:Jeep comanche Laredo longbed 1988.jpg|thumb|1988 Jeep Comanche Laredo 4.0 L longbed with aftermarket modifications]] By model year availability: *1986 - Custom- The most basic Comanche trim that could be ordered. *1986 - X- One of the more "basic" trims of the Comanche. *1986 - XLS- A "step-up" version of the more "basic" Comanche trims. *1987-1992 - Base (SporTruck)- Became the most basic trim of the Comanche after 1986. *1988- Olympic Edition- Based on the '''Pioneer''' trim to commemorate the 1988 Summer Olympics and Team U.S.A. . *1987-1988 - Chief- Added more standard equipment to the base-level Comanche trims. *1987-1990 - Laredo- The top-of-the-line and most "up-level" trim on the Comanche. *1987-1992 - Pioneer- A "step-up" version of the base Comanche trim. *1988-1992 - Eliminator- The "sporty" Comanche trim. ==Phaseout and aborted name revival== The decision to phase out the Jeep Comanche "came from a combination of two factors— low sales and Chrysler's attempts to make the Jeep brand fit into the Chrysler hierarchy of [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]], [[Dodge]], and [[Chrysler (brand)|Chrysler]] models" with Jeep housing SUVs and Dodge making trucks.{{cite book |title=Jeep Color History |first=Steve |last=Statham |page=[https://archive.org/details/jeepcolorhistory00stev/page/71 71] |url=https://archive.org/details/jeepcolorhistory00stev |url-access=registration |publisher=MBI Publishing |year=2002 |isbn=978-0-7603-0636-9 |accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} As sales dropped, the Comanche was planned for discontinuation. In 1990, the National Council of Jeep-Eagle [[Car dealership|dealers]] asked Chrysler to discontinue the Comanche, and allow them to sell a version of the [[Dodge Dakota]] pickup.{{cite news |title=Baker's job is to keep Jeep 'King of the Hill' |newspaper=Toledo Blade |date= July 2, 1990 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7UlPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KgMEAAAAIBAJ&dq=&pg=6334%2C698952 |first=Tahree |last=Lane |page=20 |accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} The company decided to cease production of the Comanche on June 12, 1992, after only a few thousand more trucks rolled off the [[Toledo, Ohio]], assembly line.{{cite news|title=Chrysler to end production of Jeep Comanche |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 6, 1992 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE0DC1F30F935A35755C0A964958260 |accessdate=August 24, 2012 }} A total of 190,446 Comanches were made during its production run.{{cite web|last=Kurt|first=Ernst|title=Lost Cars of the 1980s – Jeep Comanche Pickup|url=http://blog.hemmings.com/index.php/2013/12/23/lost-cars-of-the-1980s-jeep-comanche-pickup/?refer=news|work=Hemmings Daily|publisher=[[Hemmings Motor News]]|accessdate=December 25, 2013|date=December 23, 2013}} Following the discontinuation of the Comanche, the [[Dodge Ramcharger]] would be dropped outside of [[Mexico]] shortly afterwards as part of Chrysler's plans to have Dodge sell pickup trucks and Jeep sell SUVs. Despite that, Dodge would later re-enter the SUV field with the [[Dodge Durango]] in 1998 at the height of the initial SUV boom and at one point would offer three SUVs or crossovers (Durango, [[Dodge Journey|Journey]] and [[Dodge Nitro|Nitro]], the latter being a [[Rebadging|rebadged]] version of the [[Jeep Liberty (KK)]]) while Jeep didn't offer any pickup trucks. Dodge itself would stop offering pickup trucks in 2011 when the [[Ram Trucks]] brand was spun-off from Dodge, taking the [[Ram Pickup|Dodge Ram]] and Dakota with it. Jeep re-entered the pickup truck market in early 2019 with the [[Jeep Wrangler (JL)|Wrangler]]-based [[Jeep Gladiator (JT)|Jeep Gladiator]]. Jeep actually considered reviving the Comanche name alongside [[Jeep Gladiator (SJ)|Gladiator]] and most commonly [[Jeep CJ#CJ-8 (Scrambler)File:Jeep Gladiator Concept.JPG|Scrambler]], as well as simply using a new name, before deciding on Gladiator, feeling it fits that truck the best; [[Native American name controversy|sensitivity]] to the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] (specifically the [[Comanche]] tribe) and much less brand recognition compared to Jeep's decades-long use of "[[Cherokee]]" for the Jeep Cherokee and [[Jeep Grand Cherokee|Grand Cherokee]] also likely played factors.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7NS_s-Zyeks|title=A Closer Look - 2018 LA Auto Show - 2020 Jeep® Gladiator|first=|last=Jeep|publisher=|accessdate=December 9, 2018|via=YouTube}} The new Gladiator will serve as a 27-year later replacement for the Comanche. Production numbers: 1985: 29,245 1986: 33,386 1987: 43,070 1988: 43,718 1989: 25,311 1990: 9,576 1991: 5,188 1992: 952 ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Jeep Comanche}} * [http://comancheclub.com/ ComancheClub Site dedicated to Jeep MJs] *{{imcdb vehicle|make=Jeep|model=Comanche|Jeep Comanche}} {{Jeep Car Timeline}} [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Jeep vehicles|Comanche]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Pickup trucks]] [[Category:1990s cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1985]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Cars powered by longitudinal 4-cylinder engines]]

{{short description|Compact crossover SUV}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox automobile |name = Jeep Compass |image = Jeep Compass II 00001 China 2017-03-30.jpg |caption = |manufacturer =[[DaimlerChrysler]] (2007)
[[Chrysler LLC]] (2007-2009)
[[Chrysler Group LLC]] (2009-2014)
[[FCA US LLC]] (2014-present)
FCA India Automobiles (2017-present) |production = 2006–present |model_years = 2007–present |class = [[compact car|Compact]] [[crossover SUV]] |body_style = 4-door [[SUV]] |layout = [[FF layout|FF]] / [[F4 layout|F4]] }} The '''Jeep Compass''' is a four-door [[compact SUV|compact]]http://media.fcanorthamerica.com/newsrelease.do?id=17952&mid=786https://cars.usnews.com/cars-trucks/jeep/compass{{Cite web | url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/2017-jeep-compass-first-drive-review/ | title=The 2017 Jeep Compass is compact, yet totally competent for outdoor exploration| date=4 April 2017}} [[crossover SUV]] introduced for the 2007 [[model year]], and is now in its second generation. The first generation Compass and [[Jeep Patriot|Patriot]], its rebadged variant, were among [[Jeep]]'s first crossover SUVs. The second-generation Compass debuted in September 2016 in [[Brazil]] and at the [[Los Angeles International Auto Show#2016|Los Angeles International Auto Show]] in November 2016, sharing a modified platform with the [[Jeep Renegade (BU)|Renegade]]. ==Concept== Four years prior to the introduction of the production Jeep Compass, a [[concept car|concept vehicle]] with the same name had its world premiere in [[Detroit]] at the [[North American International Auto Show#2002|2002 North American International Auto Show]]. It featured a two-door body, [[all-wheel drive]] and a 3.7-liter [[V6 engine]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimatecarpage.com/car/1183/Jeep-Compass.html |title=Jeep Compass concept vehicle |publisher=www.ultimatecarpage.com |accessdate=25 March 2012 }} The 3.7 L Power-Tech [[V6 engine]] from the [[Jeep Liberty]] did not make it into the all-new Compass for 2007, though the production model Compass kept the concept car's styling cues and some of its features. The production model Compass also had four doors instead of the two doors on the concept car. {{clear}} =={{Anchor|MK49}}First generation (MK49; 2006–2016)== {{Infobox automobile | image = 2008 Jeep Compass (MK MY08) Limited 2.4 wagon (2015-11-11) 01.jpg | name = First generation | caption = 2008 Jeep Compass Limited | production = 2006–2016 | model_years = 2007–2017 | layout = [[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|front-engine, front-wheel drive]]
[[Front-engine, all-wheel-drive layout|Front-engine, all-wheel-drive]] | body_style = 4-door [[SUV]] | platform = [[Mitsubishi GS platform|Chrysler PM/MK platform]] | related = {{unbulleted list | [[Dodge Caliber]] | [[Jeep Patriot]] | [[Mitsubishi Lancer]] | [[Mitsubishi Outlander]] }} | class = [[compact SUV|Compact]] [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover SUV]] | engine = {{unbulleted list | 2.0 L ''[[World Gasoline Engine#2.0|World]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]] (gasoline) | 2.0 L ''[[List of Volkswagen Group diesel engines#2.0 R4 TDI PD 47-103kW|VW]]'' I4 ([[turbocharger|turbo]] diesel) | 2.2 L ''[[Mercedes-Benz OM651 engine|OM651]]'' I4 (turbo diesel) | 2.4 L ''[[World Gasoline Engine#2.4|World]]'' I4 (gasoline) }} | transmission = {{unbulleted list | 5-speed ''[[Magna International|Magna]] T355'' [[manual transmission|manual]] | 6-speed ''[[Aisin]] BG6'' manual | 6-speed ''[[Hyundai Motor Company|Hyundai]] 6F24'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] | [[Continuously variable transmission|CVT]] ''[[Jatco]] JF011E'' automatic }} | assembly = [[Belvidere Assembly Plant|Belvidere, Illinois]], [[United States]] | wheelbase = {{convert|2635|mm|in|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} | length = {{convert|173.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|69.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{unbulleted list | {{convert|64.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} 2007–09 | {{convert|65.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} 2010–: }} }} [[File:2008 Jeep Compass (MK MY08) Limited 2.4 wagon (2015-11-11) 02.jpg|thumbnail|left|Jeep Compass Limited (Australia; pre-facelift)]] Jeep debuted the production version of the Compass at the [[North American International Auto Show#2006|2006 North American International Auto Show]] in January. The first Compass was assembled on May 30, 2006, in [[Belvidere, Illinois]], where the [[Dodge Neon]] was produced. The Compass did not carry the "Trail Rated" badge found on other SUVs in the Jeep family for the 2007-2010 model years, but received the "Trail Rated" badge for the 2011 model year. This indicates that the Compass targets first-time Jeep buyers and those who drive primarily on paved roads. The Compass and Patriot are both based on the [[DaimlerChrysler]]/[[Mitsubishi Motors|Mitsubishi]] [[Mitsubishi GS platform|GS platform]]. These vehicles are differentiated by their styling and marketing: The Patriot is a traditionally styled 4-door Jeep [[station wagon|wagon]], while the Compass has a softer [[hatchback]] look, similar to the [[Dodge Caliber]].{{cite web |title=Jeep will reportedly build two car-based vehicles |publisher=AutoWeek |url=http://www.autoweek.com/article/20050613/FREE/506130722 |date=13 June 2005 |first=Rick |last=Kranz |accessdate=23 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014220854/http://www.autoweek.com/article/20050613/free/506130722 |archive-date=14 October 2012 |url-status=dead }} ===Facelift=== For 2011, Jeep redesigned the Compass to more closely resemble the [[Jeep Grand Cherokee|Grand Cherokee]], while keeping its own identity. The 2011 Jeep Compass also receives a revised suspension for better handling, a revised interior with more standard equipment, and more option packages including a [[Freedom Drive II]] Off-Road Package which includes a continuously variable transmission fitted with a low-range setting, all-terrain tires inside 17-inch aluminum wheels, skid plates, a four-wheel-drive system, and an increase ground clearance of a full inch.{{cite web|url= http://www.automoblog.net/2010/12/14/jeep-resets-compass-on-new-course-in-2011/ |title=Jeep Resets Compass on New Course in 2011 |publisher=Automoblog.net |date=14 December 2010 |first=Chris |last=Nagy |accessdate=23 June 2014}} A special edition Compass model commemorated Jeep’s 70th anniversary in 2011, and included various upgrades, special interiors, badges, wheels, and was available in only three exterior colors: Bronze Star, Bright Silver, and Black.{{cite web|url= http://www.topspeed.com/cars/jeep/2011-jeep-compass-70th-anniversary-edition-ar103208.html |title=2011 Jeep Compass 70th Anniversary Edition |author=Kirby |date=1 November 2011 |publisher=www.topspeed.com |accessdate=23 June 2014}} ===Powertrain=== The Compass uses a {{convert|172|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 2.4 L ''[[Chrysler World engine#2.4|World]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]] gasoline engine. The 2.0 L [[Chrysler World engine#2.0|World]] engine is available on the 4X2 Sport model with {{convert|158|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. A 2.0 L l-R4 TDi {{convert|103|kW|hp PS|0|abbr=on}} [[Volkswagen]]-designed [[diesel engine]] was available for the [[Europe]]an and [[Australia]]n markets, replaced in 2011 by the 2.2 L [[Mercedes-Benz OM651]]. The Compass also features two electronically controlled [[four-wheel drive]] systems. [[Freedom Drive I]] and [[Freedom Drive II]], Freedom Drive I is a full-time four-wheel drive system with locking capabilities; Freedom Drive II is based on Freedom Drive I but by using the vehicle's CVT transmission it is capable of a 19:1 gear reduction simulating a low-range usually found in vehicles with dedicated transfer cases. The base model version has [[front wheel drive]] (FWD).{{cite news|last=McCraw |first=Jim |title=The First Front-Wheel-Drive Jeep |newspaper=The New York Times |date=12 April 2006 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/12/automobiles/autospecial/12glance-jeep-patriot.html |accessdate=23 June 2014}} The Trail Rated version of the Compass has passed the same testing of off-road ability as other Jeep vehicles in terms of traction, ground clearance, maneuverability, articulation, and water fording. ===Models=== [[File:2015 Jeep Compass (MK MY16) Limited wagon (2015-12-07) 01.jpg|thumb|right|Jeep Compass Limited (Australia; facelift)]] [[File:2014 Jeep Compass (MK MY14) Sport wagon (2015-07-24).jpg|thumb|right|Jeep Compass Sport (Australia; facelift)]] [[File:Jeep Compass Limited interior.jpg|thumb|right|Interior]] The three basic models of Compass are '''Sport''', '''Latitude''', and '''Limited'''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.jeep-india.com/compass.html|title=Explore The New Jeep® Compass - Jeep India|website=www.jeep-india.com|access-date=2019-11-04}} The '''Sport''' serves as the base model. It includes features such as seventeen-inch [[alloy wheels]], an AM/FM stereo with single-disc CD player and four speakers, a heater, cloth seating surfaces, and manual, roll-up windows and manual door locks. Features such as power windows and door locks, a seven-speaker [[Boston Acoustics]] premium sound system with a 368-watt external amplifier, and air conditioning are options. The 2014-2016 Jeep Compass Sport and Sport SE, The Electronic Vehicle Information Center (EVIC) does not come as standard equipment. An EVIC gives the user information such as gas mileage, number of miles to empty, service intervals, tire pressure, etc.{{Cite web|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/auto/latest-auto-news/story/jeep-compass-sport-plus-sale-starts-new-variant-priced-at-rs-15-99-lakh-1494271-2019-04-04|title=Jeep Compass Sport Plus sale starts, new variant priced at Rs 15.99 lakh|last=DelhiApril 4|first=Varun Singh New|last2=April 4|first2=2019UPDATED|website=India Today|language=en|access-date=2019-11-04|last3=Ist|first3=2019 20:22}} The '''Latitude''' is the midrange model. It added features onto the Sport, such as air conditioning, [[keyless entry]], a security system, and power windows and door locks. The EVIC comes as an optional component with the security and cargo convenience package. This option comes with alarm, tonneau cover, tire pressure monitoring display, garage door opener, and electronic vehicle information center. The model became available in 2011. The '''Limited''' is the top-of-the-line model. It added features such as leather-trimmed seats, had an available sunroof, and [[remote starter]]. A '''70th Anniversary Edition''' was based on the Sport model. It added air conditioning, unique leather-trimmed seats, unique alloy wheels, a sunroof, side-impact airbags, a seven-speaker Boston Acoustics premium sound system with a 368-watt external amplifier, power windows and door locks, keyless entry, and a security alarm. This special edition model was only offered in 2011 to celebrate Jeep's 70th anniversary. All Jeep models for 2011 only offered a 70th Anniversary Edition model (Compass, Patriot, Wrangler, Wrangler Unlimited, Liberty, and the Grand Cherokee). An '''Altitude Edition''' model was made available in 2012. It was based upon the Latitude model, and added black-painted alloy wheels, leather-trimmed seats, a sunroof, and a Boston Acoustics premium sound system with a 368-watt external amplifier. The Altitude package was available on the Jeep Grand Cherokee only at first, but then was available on the Compass, Patriot, Wrangler, and Wrangler Unlimited as well. All models except the Jeep Grand Cherokee dropped this model (the Grand Cherokee model continued to offer this model for the 2013 model year). The Altitude name was chosen in a contest to name a Grand Cherokee concept car. Because of the Altitude's popularity, Jeep decided to offer it on all models except for the Jeep Liberty. The Jeep Patriot and first generation Jeep Compass were phased out during the 2016 model year, replaced by a single new redesigned Compass SUV that FiatChrysler would debut in late 2016.{{cite web|title = It's Official: Jeep Wrangler Pickup Is Coming in 2017|url = http://blog.caranddriver.com/its-official-jeep-wrangler-pickup-is-coming-in-2017/|website = blog.caranddriver.com|access-date = 2016-01-13}}{{cite web|title = Jeep confirms pickup; new SUV to be Patriot or Compass|url = http://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/detroit-auto-show/2016/01/11/jeep-confirms-pickup-new-suv-patriot-compass/78648152/|website = Detroit News|access-date = 2016-01-13}} ===Safety=== The Compass was safety tested by Euro NCAP in 2012 and earned only a two star rating. {{Euro NCAP |year=2012 |overall_stars=2 |description=Jeep Compass |reference_name=compass2012|reference={{cite web |title=Official Jeep Compass 2012 safety rating results |url=https://www.euroncap.com/en/results/jeep/compass/10932 |website=Euro NCAP}}|adult_points=22 |adult_percent=61 |child_points=37 |child_percent=76 |pedestrian_points=8 |pedestrian_percent=23 |safety_points=3 |safety_percent=43 }} {| class="wikitable" |+[[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration|NHTSA]] 2013 Compass:{{cite web|url= http://www.safercar.gov/Vehicle+Shoppers/5-Star+Safety+Ratings/2011-Newer+Vehicles/Vehicle-Detail?vehicleId=7230 |title=2013 Jeep Compass SUV 4WD |publisher=Safercar.gov |date= |accessdate=23 June 2014}} |- |Overall: |{{rating|3|5}} |- |Frontal Driver: |{{rating|3|5}} |- |Frontal Passenger: |{{rating|3|5}} |- |Side Driver: |{{rating|5|5}} |- |Side Passenger: |{{rating|2|5}} |- |Side Rear Passenger: |{{rating|4|5}} |- |Rollover AWD: |{{rating|4|5}} / 16.4% |} =={{Anchor|MP/552}}Second generation (MP/552; 2016–present)== {{Infobox automobile | name = Second generation | image = 2018 Jeep Compass Latitude 2.4L front 4.20.19.jpg | production = 2016–present{{cite web|url=http://www.jeeppress-europe.com/press/article/all-new-jeep-compass-makes-worldwide-debut-in-brazil|title=All new Jeep Compass makes worldwide debut in Brazil |publisher=[[Jeep|Jeep Press Europe]]|date=27 September 2016 |accessdate=30 July 2018}} | model_years = 2017–present | assembly = MP/552: [[Toluca, Mexico]] ([[Toluca Car Assembly|TCA]])

9-speed ''[[ZF Friedrichshafen|ZF]]'' ''[[ZF 9HP transmission|948TE]]'' automatic | wheelbase = {{convert|2640|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|4420|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|1820|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|1650|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | predecessor = [[Jeep Patriot]] }} [[File:2018 Jeep Compass (MP MY18) Sport wagon (2018-05-05) 02.jpg|thumbnail|left|Jeep Compass Sport (Australia)]] [[File:Jeep Compass PHEV Genf 2019 1Y7A5986.jpg|thumbnail|left|Jeep Compass PHEV]] The second-generation of Jeep Compass debuted on September 27, 2016 in [[Brazil]]{{cite web|url=http://www.fcapress.com.br/en/jeep/verRelease/1896.do|title=Jeep Compass: a new direction for the SUV segment |publisher=[[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles|FCA Press]]|date=26 September 2016 |accessdate=30 July 2018}} and at the [[Los Angeles International Auto Show#2016|Los Angeles International Auto Show]] in November 2016, replacing the [[Jeep Patriot]] and first generation Compass. {{cite web|url=https://www.netcarshow.com/jeep/2017-compass/ |title=Jeep Compass (2017) - pictures, information & specs |publisher=Netcarshow.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-25}} Production for North American-market Compass models was moved to [[Toluca, Mexico]], while [[Jeep Cherokee (KL)]] production will move from [[Toledo, Ohio]] to [[Belvidere, Illinois]], where the first-generation Compass and [[Jeep Patriot]] were both assembled. Using a stretched version of the same platform as the [[Jeep Renegade (BU)|Renegade]],{{cite web | title = 2017 Jeep Compass | publisher = Autoblog | author = | date = | url = http://www.autoblog.com/buy/2017-Jeep-Compass/}} the Compass is available in four distinct trim levels: the base '''Sport''', the mid-level '''Latitude''', the luxurious '''Limited''', and the off road-capable '''Trailhawk'''. All trim levels are available with either [[front-wheel drive]] or [[four-wheel drive]], with the exception of the Trailhawk, which is only available in a 4WD configuration.{{Cite web|url=https://www.jeep-india.com/compass-trailhawk.html|title=Explore the New Jeep® Compass TrailHawk - Jeep India|website=www.jeep-india.com|access-date=2019-11-11}} In the United States, the Compass comes equipped with a 2.4L [[World Gasoline Engine#Tigershark|Tigershark]] four-cylinder engine or a 1.4L '''MultiAir''' four-cylinder engine. More than 65 percent of the upper body structure and frame is made of [[High-strength low-alloy steel|high-strength steel]].[https://www.trucks.com/2016/11/17/2016-la-auto-show-2017-jeep-compass/ 2016 LA Auto Show: 2017 Jeep Compass Promises Improved Ride and Performance]. ''trucks.com''. Styling of the second-generation Compass is inspired by two of its larger siblings, the [[Jeep Cherokee (KL)]] and [[Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2)]]. Styling elements taken from the Grand Cherokee include headlamps integrated into the front grille and a narrow front grille with a black finish, while the Cherokee lends some of its rear end styling elements, basic interior design, and 2.4L '''Tigershark''' Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) gasoline engine and [[ZF Friedrichshafen|ZF]]-sourced nine-speed 948TE automatic transmission to the overall design of the Compass. Available features include FCA's UConnect 4C 8.4 and 8.4N touch-screen infotainment systems, a [[Beats Electronics|Beats]] Premium Audio System with a 506-watt digital amplifier, eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, Jeep's Command-View panoramic sunroof, [[LED]] front headlamps, Forward Collision Warning, a ParkView rear-view backup camera system, front and rear parking sensors, Blind Spot Information System (BLIS), and Jeep's [[Selec-Terrain]] full-time four-wheel-drive system (standard on the Trailhawk model). === India-spec model === The Jeep Compass was unveiled in India on 12 April 2017 and assembled in the [[Fiat India|FCA India]] Pune plant since 1 July 2017[http://media.fcanorthamerica.com/newsrelease.do?id=18314&mid=&searchresult First indian Jeep Compass in production]. Apart from manufacturing to the Indian market, Jeep also exports the Indian-made Compass to many right-hand drive markets such as the United Kingdom, Australia, Brunei, Japan, Indonesia and Thailand. The India-spec model is available with two engine options - a 1.4-litre, four-cylinder, turbocharged MultiAir petrol and a 2.0-litre, four-cylinder, turbocharged MultiJet II diesel engine.{{Cite news|url=http://www.autositeindia.com/news/jeep-compass-india-specifications-features-colours/|title=Jeep Compass India specifications, features, expected price and launch date details|date=2017-04-12|work=Autosite India|access-date=2017-04-16|language=en-US}}{{cite web|author=by സ്വന്തം ലേഖകൻ |url=http://www.manoramaonline.com/fasttrack/auto-news/2017/06/01/made-in-india-jeep-compass-rolls-out.html |title=Jeep Compass India |publisher=Manoramaonline.com |date= |accessdate=2017-07-07}} In 2017 Jeep sold about 10,000 Compasses in India from the day of release until the middle of December. === Production === The Compass is assembled at plants in Italy, Mexico, Brazil, China and India.[https://www.freep.com/story/money/cars/chrysler/2016/11/17/fca-jeep-compass-plants/94039654/ FCA to build Jeep Compass in four plants globally]. ''Detroit Free Press''. North American and European models are manufactured in Melfi, Italy and [[Toluca]], Mexico; moved from [[Belvidere, Illinois]]. In Brazil, the second-generation Jeep Compass start production the 26 September 2016 at FCA new [[Goiana]], [[Pernambuco]] Assembly Plant. Production of the first-generation Compass and Patriot ended early 2017, with production of the second generation Compass beginning in spring of 2017 for North American models. Assembled at [[Fiat]]'s facility in [[Ranjangaon]], [[Maharashtra]], it is Jeep's first model assembled in India.{{cite web|title=Jeep Compass India debut on April 12|url=http://www.autocarindia.com/auto-news/2017-jeep-compass-for-india-revealed-404491.aspx|website=Autocar India|accessdate=9 April 2017}}{{cite web|title='Made-in-India' Jeep Compass to debut on April 12, video teaser released|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/autos/made-in-india-jeep-compass-to-debut-on-april-12-video-teaser-released/story-ge3AW4LyqUyXhNQmPkLzjK.html|website=Hindustan Times|accessdate=9 April 2017|language=en|date=8 April 2017}} ===Trim Levels=== In the U.S., the second-generation Jeep Compass is available in several different trim levels. While each of these trim levels offers its own level of standard and optional equipment, all Compasses come equipped with features such as the U Connect [[Bluetooth]] system for hands-free calling and wireless stereo audio streaming via [[A2DP]], auxiliary and USB inputs, a touchscreen audio system, keyless entry, a tilt-and-telescoping, multifunction steering wheel with integrated radio and cruise controls, a six-speaker audio system, Antilock Braking System ([[Anti-lock braking system|ABS]]), power windows and door locks, a split-folding rear bench seat, and a rear view backup camera system. The '''Sport''' serves as the base Compass trim level. Standard features include a five-inch U Connect 3 5.0BT touchscreen radio, a 1.4L '''MultiAir''' Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) gasoline engine with a six-speed manual transmission, sixteen-inch tires with black-painted steel wheels, a tire inflation and repair kit (in lieu of the spare tire and spare wheel), premium cloth seating surfaces, and dual manually-adjustable front bucket seats. Optional features include the 2.4L '''Tigershark''' Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) gasoline engine, an automatic transmission, sixteen-inch alloy wheels, deep-tinted glass, the "Keyless Enter-'n'-Go" system with push-button starter, dual heated front bucket seats, and a remote vehicle starter system. The '''Latitude''' is the mid-level Compass trim level. It adds many more convenience features to the base '''Sport''' trim, including [[SiriusXM]] [[Satellite Radio]], a spare tire and spare wheel, sixteen-inch alloy wheels, deep-tinted glass, the "Keyless Enter-'n'-Go" system with push-button stater, a security system, and premium cloth seating surfaces w/ vinyl accent trim. Optional features include the 2.4L '''Tigershark''' Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) Gasoline engine, an automatic transmission, seventeen-inch or eighteen-inch alloy wheels, a power-adjustable front driver's bucket seat, seven-inch and 8.4-inch U Connect 4 touchscreen infotainment systems with [[Apple CarPlay]] and [[Android Auto]], a nine-speaker [[Beats Electronics|Beats]] premium amplified audio system with subwoofer, a remote vehicle starter system, GPS navigation, driver assistance technologies, and a power rear tailgate. The '''Limited''' is the luxury-oriented Compass trim level. It adds luxury amenities to the mid-level '''Latitude''' trim, including a 2.4L '''Tigershark''' Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) gasoline engine, an automatic transmission, a heated leather-wrapped steering wheel, dual heated front bucket seats, a remote vehicle starter system, a reconfigurable TFT [[LCD]] instrument cluster display, eighteen-inch alloy wheels, luxury leather-trimmed seating surfaces, power-adjustable front bucket seats, an 8.4-inch U Connect 4 touchscreen infotainment system with [[Apple CarPlay]] and [[Android Auto]], a nine-speaker [[Beats Electronics|Beats]] premium amplified audio system with subwoofer, GPS navigation, a dual-pane panoramic sunroof, a power rear tailgate, heated and ventilated front bucket seats, driver assistance technologies, nineteen-inch alloy wheels, and heated rear seats. The '''Trailhawk''' trim is the off-road capable Compass trim level. Unlike all other Compass trim levels, the '''Trailhawk''' is only available with four-wheel-drive (4WD). It adds features to the mid-level '''Latitude''' trim, such as off-road suspension, standard four-wheel-drive (4WD), unique "Ruby Red" interior accent stitching, an 8.4-inch U Connect 4 touchscreen infotainment system with [[Apple CarPlay]] and [[Android Auto]], unique seat trim, a power-adjustable front driver's bucket seat, unique seventeen-inch alloy wheels, the 2.4L '''Tigershark''' Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) gasoline engine, an automatic transmission, dual heated front bucket seats, a heated leather-wrapped steering wheel, a reconfigurable TFT [[LCD]] instrument cluster display, [[Jeep]] "Off-Road Pages" application for the U Connect system, [[Falken]] Wildpeak A/T all-terrain tires, a full-size, and a matching spare tire and alloy spare wheel. Optional features include luxury leather-trimmed seating surfaces, GPS navigation, a nine-speaker [[Beats Electronics|Beats]] premium amplified audio system, a power rear tailgate, a dual-pane panoramic moonroof, heated and ventilated front bucket seats, driver assistance technologies, and heated rear seats. In addition to the standard trim levels, '''Altitude''' and '''High Altitude''' Special Editions are available for the '''Latitude''' and '''Limited''' trim levels respectively, and add "blacked-out" exterior accents, black alloy wheels, and more to their respective trim levels. Optional features are identical to that of the '''Latitude''' and '''Limited''' trim levels. A '''Sun and Wheel Group''' Special Edition model is available for the base '''Sport''' trim level, which adds upgraded alloy wheels, deep-tinted glass, and a dual-pane panoramic moonroof. It is only available in Front Wheel Drive (FWD) configuration with the 2.4L '''Tigershark''' Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) gasoline engine and an automatic transmission. The '''Upland''' Special Edition model is also available for the base '''Sport''' trim level, and adds black alloy wheels, blue accent trim for the exterior badging, Trailhawk-inspired exterior styling elements, and blue stitching on the interior. It is only available with four-wheel-drive (4WD), the 2.4L '''Tigershark''' Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) gasoline engine, and an automatic transmission. ===Safety=== {{Euro NCAP |align=left |year=2017 |overall_stars=5 |description=Jeep Compass |reference_name=Jeep Compass Euro NCAP |reference={{cite web |url=https://cdn.euroncap.com/media/30130/euroncap-2017-jeep-compass-datasheet.pdf |title=Jeep Compass| accessdate=6 August 2017 |website=euroncap.com}} |adult_points=34.5 |adult_percent=90 |child_points=40.7 |child_percent=83 |pedestrian_points=27.3 |pedestrian_percent=64 |safety_points=7.1 |safety_percent=59 }} [[Insurance Institute for Highway Safety|IIHS]]:{{cite web|url=http://www.iihs.org/iihs/ratings/vehicle/v/jeep/compass-4-door-suv/2017 |title=Vehicle details |publisher=Iihs.org |date= |accessdate=17 October 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |- |Small overlap front |style="background: green"|Good |- |Moderate overlap front |style="background: green"|Good |- |Side |style="background: green"|Good |- |Roof strength (2016–present models) |style="background: green"|Good |- |Head restraints & seats |style="background: green"|Good |} {{clear}} ==Sales== {|class="wikitable" |- !
