{{Infobox automobile | name = Jeep CJ | image = Jeep-CJ.jpg | caption = Jeep CJ-5 | manufacturer = {{unbulleted list| [[Willys-Overland]] (1944-1953) | [[Willys Motors]] (1953-1963) | [[Kaiser-Jeep]] (1963-1970) | [[American Motors Corporation]] ([[Jeep]]) (1971-1986) }} | body_style = {{unbulleted list|2-door [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] | 2-door [[convertible (car)|convertible]] | 2-door [[pickup truck]] }} | production = 1944-1986
More than 1.5 million | class = Compact [[sport utility vehicle]] | layout = [[Front-engine design|Front engine]], [[rear-wheel drive]] / [[four-wheel drive]] | assembly = {{unbulleted list| [[Toledo Complex]] [[Toledo, Ohio]], [[United States]] | [[Maywood, California]], [[United States]] | [[Brampton Assembly (AMC)]] [[Brampton, Ontario]] [[Canada]] | [[Pars Khodro]], [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] ([[Arab American Vehicles|AAV]]) }} | successor = {{unbulleted list|[[Jeep Wrangler]] | [[Jeep Comanche]] (For pickup version)}} | predecessor = [[Willys MB]] (For World War 2) [[Jeep Commando]] (For pickup version) }} The '''Jeep CJ''' models are both a series and a range of small, open-bodied [[off-road vehicle]]s and compact [[pickup truck]]s, built and sold by several successive incarnations of the [[Jeep]] [[automobile manufacturer|automobile marque]] from 1945 to 1986. The 1945 Willys Jeep was the world's first mass-produced civilian [[four-wheel drive]] car. In 1944, [[Willys|Willys-Overland]], one of the two main manufacturers of the [[Willys MB|World War II military Jeep]], built the first prototypes for a commercial version – the CJ, short for "civilian Jeep".{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=zTsAbTJB5RIC&pg=PA49&dq=cj+jeep+stood+for+Civilian |pages=49–51 |title=Jeep Collector's Library |first=Jim |last=Allen |publisher=MBI Publishing |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-7603-1979-6 |accessdate=22 May 2014 |authorlink=Jim Allen (4x4 writer) |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140708051243/http://books.google.com/books?id=zTsAbTJB5RIC&pg=PA49&dq=cj+jeep+stood+for+Civilian |archive-date=8 July 2014 |url-status = live}} From then on, all CJ Jeeps consistently had a separate body and frame, rigid [[solid axle|live axles]] with leaf springs both front and rear, a tapering nose design with flared fenders, and a fold-flat windshield, and could be driven without doors. Also, with few exceptions, they had part-time [[Jeep four-wheel-drive systems|four-wheel drive systems]], with the choice of high and low gearing, and open bodies with removable hard or soft tops. After remaining in production through a range of model numbers, and several corporate parents, the Jeep CJ line was officially ended in 1986. More than 1.5 million CJ Jeeps were built, having continued the same basic body style for 45 years since the Jeep first appeared.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/11/28/business/amc-to-end-jeep-cj-models.html |title=A.M.C. to End Jeep CJ Models |newspaper=The New York Times |date=28 November 1985 |accessdate=13 February 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180314104411/https://www.nytimes.com/1985/11/28/business/amc-to-end-jeep-cj-models.html |archive-date=14 March 2018 |url-status = live}} Widely regarded as "America's workhorse", the CJs have been described as "probably the most successful utility vehicle ever made."{{cite book|last=Ackerson |first=Robert |title=Jeep CJ 1945-1986 |year=2005 |publisher=Veloce Publishing |isbn=9781904788966}} American Motors VP Joseph Cappy said the end of "CJ production will signal an end of a very important era in Jeep history."{{cite web |url= https://www.hemmings.com/blog/2011/02/18/class-of-86-jeep-cj-7-and-cj-8/ |title=Class of '86 – Jeep CJ-7 and CJ-8 |work=Hemmings Daily |first=Daniel |last=Strohl |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180113203036/https://www.hemmings.com/blog/2011/02/18/class-of-86-jeep-cj-7-and-cj-8/ |archive-date=13 January 2018 |url-status = live}} The Jeep CJ-7 was replaced in 1986 by the similar-looking [[Jeep Wrangler]]. The Jeep CJ-8 and CJ-10s were succeeded by the [[Jeep Comanche]] pickup. The similar model, the [[Jeep DJ|DJ]] "Dispatcher" was introduced in 1956 as a two-wheel drive version with open, fabric, or a closed steel body in both left- and right-hand drives for hotel, resort, police, and later [[United States Postal Service]] markets.{{cite book |last=Flory, Jr. |first=J. "Kelly" |title=American Cars, 1960-1972: Every Model, Year by Year |publisher=McFarland |year=2004 |pages=412, 700 |isbn=978-0-7864-1273-0}}{{cite book|last=Statham |first=Steve |title=Jeep Color History |publisher=MotorBooks International |isbn=9781610590556 |page=57 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=dR3wmKlfnrMC&pg=PA57&dq=Universal+rolled+out+of+Jeep+factories,+the+DJ-3A+Dispatcher.+The+DJ+series |accessdate=13 March 2018}} ==CJ-1== {{Infobox automobile |name = Willys-Overland CJ-1 |production = 1944 |related = [[Willys MB]] }} By 1944, the Allies were confident the war would be won, and wartime production looked to be winding down.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} This allowed Willys to consider designing a Jeep for the postwar civilian market. Documentation is scarce, but in early 1944, Willys seemed to have found time to start drawing up plans, and one or two prototypes dubbed CJ(-1), for "Civilian Jeep", were running by May of that year. The first CJ(s) had apparently been created by quick modification of the regular military MB, adding a tailgate, lower gearing, a [[Drawbar (haulage)|drawbar]], and a civilian-style canvas top. The first CJ served as a quick proof-of-concept test, and when a further design evolution materialized, probably became the CJ-1 by default.{{cite web |url=http://www.fourwheeler.com/features/1507-the-oldest-restored-civilian-jeep/ |title=The Oldest Restored Civilian Jeep |last=Allen |first=Jim |date=27 July 2015 |website=FourWheeler.com |publisher=Extreme Ventures |authorlink=Jim Allen (4x4 writer) |access-date=13 February 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180222165444/http://www.fourwheeler.com/features/1507-the-oldest-restored-civilian-jeep/ |archive-date=22 February 2018 |url-status = live}} They were manufactured until the CJ-2s appeared, and they were the first Jeeps built from the ground up for civilian use. No CJ-1s built have survived, and how many were made is unknown.{{cite web |url= http://www.thecj2apage.com/story.html |title=The CJ2A Story |publisher=Thecj2apage.com |accessdate=13 February 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20171005221831/https://www.thecj2apage.com/story.html |archive-date=5 October 2017 |url-status = live}} {{clear}} ==CJ-2== {{Infobox automobile |name = Willys-Overland CJ-2 |production = {{unbulleted list|1944-1945|40 or 45 produced}} |engine = {{convert|134|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Willys Go Devil engine|L134]] [[Inline 4|I4]] |transmission = 3-speed ''[[Borg-Warner T-90]]'' manual |wheelbase = {{convert|80|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite book|last=Gunnell |first=John A. |title=Standard Catalog of American Light-Duty Trucks |year=1993 |publisher=Krause Publications |isbn=0-87341-238-9}} |related = [[Willys MB]] }} Although at least 40 were built, the '''Willys-Overland CJ-2''' was not really available at retail.{{citation needed|date=June 2019}} The CJ-2s, also known as "AgriJeeps"{{By whom|date=June 2019}}, were the second-generation prototypes for the first production civilian Jeep, and were used solely for testing purposes. Although their design was directly based on the military [[Willys MB]], using the same [[Willys Go Devil engine]] — they were not only stripped of all military features, particularly the blackout lighting, but also the CJ-2s had many significant differences in body features and construction versus the military Jeep. They had tailgates, power take-offs, engine governors ($28.65), column-shift T90 [[manual transmission]]s, 5.38 gears, 2.43:1 low-range transfer cases, and driver's-side tool indentations. Rear wheelwells were redesigned so that seats could be enlarged, improved, and moved rearward, and new, more weathertight top designs were tried. A canvas half-top with roll-down doors was one of several top designs tried before production. The CJ-2 Go-Devil L-head engine was largely the same as the wartime Jeep, but used a different carburetor and ignition system. {{citation needed span|text=The CJ-2s were built in two main batches, but even within the two groups, each was a little different, as they evolved and were modified for various types of work. For instance a number of experimental combinations of powertrain components were tested. Earlier models were dubbed “pilot models” because they still had so many differences from the production Jeeps. They were painted olive-drab, and had brass “JEEP” badges on the windshield base, the hood sides, and the rear. Some CJ-2s also had an "AgriJeep" plaque fixed to the dash.|date=June 2019}} Later models were stamped "JEEP" and were painted in a few civilian colors that translated into the familiar "WILLYS" stamping and the colors that appeared on the first production CJ-2A Jeeps built from 1945. The spare tire was mounted forward of the passenger-side rear wheel on the earlier models and aft of the rear wheel on later ones. The CJ-2s were likely distributed to "agricultural stations" for evaluation purposes. Of the 40–45 CJ-2s built, serial numbers CJ2-03, CJ2-04, CJ2-06 (X30), CJ2-09 (X33), CJ2-11, CJ2-12, CJ2-14, CJ2-26, CJ2-32 (X56), CJ2-37 (X61), CJ2-38, and CJ2-39 have survived, although some in very rough condition.{{citation needed|date=June 2019}} CJ-2-06 and CJ2-09 have been restored. {{clear}} ==CJ-2A== {{Infobox automobile |name = Willys-Overland CJ-2A |image = 1946 Willys CJ2A all original at 2019 AACA Hershey meet 1of5.jpg |production = {{unbulleted list|1945-1949|214,760 produced}} |transmission = 3-speed [[Borg-Warner T-90]] [[Manual transmission|manual]]{{cite book|last=Gunnell|first=John A. |title=Standard Catalog of American Light Duty Trucks, 1896-1986|year=1993 |publisher=Krause Publications |isbn=978-0-87341-238-4}} |engine = {{convert|134|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Willys Go Devil engine|L134]] [[Inline 4|I4]] |wheelbase = {{convert|80|in|m|2|abbr=on}} {{cite web |url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1949_Jeep/1949_Jeep_Universal_Operation_Data/1949%20Jeep%20Universal-20.html |title=1949 Jeep Universal Operation Data |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |accessdate=2011-11-20 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120306064405/http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1949_Jeep/1949_Jeep_Universal_Operation_Data/1949%20Jeep%20Universal-20.html |archive-date=2012-03-06 |url-status = live}} |length = {{convert|130+1/8|in|m|2|abbr=on}} [https://www.kaiserwillys.com/about_willys_jeep_cj2a_history_specs About Willys Jeep CJ-2A - Jeep Specs and History | KaiserWillys.com] |width = {{convert|59|in|m|2|abbr=on}} {{cite web|url=https://www.thecj2apage.com/specs.html|title=The CJ2A Page - Specifications|first=|last=Johnny|date=|website=www.thecj2apage.com|access-date=2017-12-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171226020731/https://www.thecj2apage.com/specs.html|archive-date=2017-12-26|url-status = live}} |height = {{convert|69.4|in|m|2|abbr=on}} (top up) |weight = {{convert|2,137|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} }} [[File:'46 Jeep CJ (Auto classique Laval '10).jpg|thumb|left|1946 Jeep CJ]] [[File:1946 - Turner Motors - 31 Jan MC - Allentown PA.jpg|thumb|left|1946 advertisement marketed the "''Universal'' Jeep", not mentioning the CJ-2A type-code yet]] [[File:Willys CJ-2A 1946 (14168649288).jpg|thumb|280px|Pasture Green with Autumn Yellow wheels was one of the first two original color choices]] [[File:Jeeps voor landbouw en industrie, Bestanddeelnr 901-9334.jpg|thumb|left|Jeep demonstration for farming and industry – Netherlands, 1946]] The lessons learned with the CJ-2 led to the development of the first full-production CJ, the 1945-1949 '''Willys-Overland CJ-2A''', or '''Universal Jeep'''. A trademark for "AGRIJEEP" was granted in December 1944, but was not used. The CJ-2A looked very much like a civilianized MB with a tailgate and side-mounted spare wheel. A distinct difference between the MB and the CJ-2A lay in the grilles of the two vehicles. Where the MB had recessed headlights and nine-slot grilles, the CJ-2A had larger, slightly bulging headlights, flush-mounted in a seven-slot grille. While still powered by the reliable L-134 Go-Devil engine, the CJ-2A replaced the MB's T-84 transmission with a beefier T-90 three-speed. Production of the CJ-2A started on 17 July 1945, sharing production time with the MB – roughly 9000 more MBs were produced through September 1945.{{cite web|url=https://www.thecj2apage.com/history.html|title=The CJ2A Page -- History of the CJ2A|author=|date=|website=www.thecj2apage.com|access-date=2018-05-06|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190524173858/https://www.thecj2apage.com/history.html|archive-date=2019-05-24|url-status = live}} Many of the early CJ-2As were produced using remaining stock of the military jeep components such as engine blocks, and in a few cases, modified frames. Up to serial no. 13453, the MB-style full floating rear axle was fitted. Once they were used up, the CJ got a stronger Dana / Spicer model 41. Sometimes the use of MB parts was due to strikes at suppliers, such as Autolite. Since Willys produced few parts in-house and relied heavily on suppliers, it was vulnerable to strikes. Unfortunately for Willys, strikes were common after the war, and this likely contributed to low production totals in 1945 and early 1946. Since the CJ-2A was primarily intended for farming, ranching, and industrial applications, stock CJ-2As only came with a driver seat and driver side mirror, and a wide variety of options was available, such as: front passenger seat, rear seat, center rear-view mirror, canvas top, front power take-off (PTO), rear PTO, belt pulley drive, capstan winch, governor, rear hydraulic lift, snow plow, welder, generator, mower, disc, front bumper weight, heavy-duty springs, dual vacuum windshield wipers (stock CJ-2As were equipped with a manual wiper on the passenger side and a vacuum wiper on the driver side), dual taillights (stock CJ-2As had a taillight on the driver side and a reflector on the passenger side), hot-climate radiator, driveshaft guards, heater, side steps, and radiator brush guard. The CJ-2As were produced in lively color combinations that in some ways symbolized the hope and promise of postwar America. From 1945 to mid-1946, CJ-2As were only available in two color combinations: Pasture Green with Autumn Yellow wheels and Harvest Tan with Sunset Red wheels. Additional color combinations added in mid-1946 were: Princeton Black with Harvard Red or Sunset Red wheels, Michigan Yellow with Pasture Green, Sunset Red or Americar Black wheels, Normandy Blue with Autumn Yellow or Sunset Red wheels, and Harvard Red with Autumn Yellow or Americar Black wheels. The Pasture Green and Harvest Tan combinations were dropped later in 1946. The Harvard Red combinations were dropped in 1947 and replaced with Picket Gray with Harvard Red wheels, and Luzon Red with Universal Beige wheels. In 1948, these color combinations were also added: Emerald Green with Universal Beige wheels, Potomac Gray with Harvard Red or American Black wheels. For 1949, the Picket Gray, Michigan Yellow, and Normandy Blue combinations were dropped. Olive drab was also available for export models. On early CJ-2As, the front seats were covered in olive-drab vinyl. Around mid-1947, Slate Gray vinyl became available for certain color combinations. Later, Barcelona Red was added to the mix. A total of 214,760 CJ-2As were produced. Because of the use of military production parts on the earliest CJ-2As, and the many changes made during its early production, restorers and collectors refer to CJ-2As up to around serial no. 34,530 as "Very Early Civilian" and from mid-1946 to about mid-1947 as "Early Civilian". Only minor changes were made after the mid-1947 models. {{clear}} ==CJ-3A== {{Infobox automobile |name = Willys-Overland CJ-3A |image = Willys mb 1943 06011701.jpg |production = 1949-1953 |engine = {{convert|134|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Willys Go Devil engine|L134]] [[Inline 4|I4]] |transmission = 3-speed Borg-Warner ''[[Borg-Warner T-90|T-90]]'' manual |wheelbase = {{convert|80|in|m|2|abbr=on}} |length = {{convert|129+3/4|in|m|2|abbr=on}} {{cite web|url= https://www.kaiserwillys.com/about_willys_jeep_cj3a_history_specs |title=About Willys Vehicles - CJ-3A history specs |website=KaiserWillys.com |accessdate=2019-10-30}} |width = {{convert|57+1/8|in|m|2|abbr=on}} (body) {{cite web|url= http://www.cj3a.info/index.html|title=The CJ3A Information Page|first=Bob|last=Westerman|date=|website=www.cj3a.info|access-date=2017-12-25|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20171225203206/http://www.cj3a.info/index.html|archive-date=2017-12-25|url-status = live}} /
{{convert|63.1|in|m|2|abbr=on}} with spare tyre |height = {{convert|66.4|in|m|2|abbr=on}} windshield up |related = [[Willys M38]] }} The '''Willys-Overland CJ-3A''' was introduced in 1949, and was in production until 1953, when replaced by the CJ-3B. It was powered by Willys' {{convert|60|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} L-134 Go-Devil four-cylinder engine, with a T-90 transmission and [[Dana Holding Corporation|Dana]] 18 transfer case, a [[Dana 30#Dana25|Dana 25]] front axle and Dana 41 or 44 rear axle. It featured a one-piece windshield with a vent, and wipers at the bottom. The CJ-3A had beefed-up suspension (10 leaf) to accommodate the various agricultural implements that were being built for the vehicle.{{cite web |url=http://www.film.queensu.ca/CJ3B/Siblings/CJ3AOrigins.html |last=Cary |first=Reed |title=The CJ-3A Universal Jeep |date=4 March 2001 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |url-status = dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120626210611/http://www.film.queensu.ca/cj3b/Siblings/CJ3AOrigins.html |archivedate=26 June 2012 |df= }} Another difference was a shorter rear wheelwell (the wheelwell from the top front edge to the rear of the body is {{convert|32|in|mm|abbr=on}} on the 3A compared to {{convert|34|in|mm|abbr=on}} on the 2A) and moving the driver's seat rearward.{{cite web|url=http://www.cj3a.info/cj3a/cj3a.htm|title=The CJ-3A|first=Bob|last=Westerman|date=|website=www.cj3a.info|access-date=29 September 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006213747/http://www.cj3a.info/cj3a/cj3a.htm|archive-date=6 October 2008|url-status = live}} As of 1951, a Farm Jeep and a Jeep Tractor version were offered; the latter was very bare-bones, for field use only, and featured a [[power takeoff]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cj3a.info/cj3a/farmjeep/fj.html|title=CJ-3A Farm Jeep and Jeep Tractor|first=Bob|last=Westerman|date=|website=www.cj3a.info|access-date=2017-12-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171226130255/http://www.cj3a.info/cj3a/farmjeep/fj.html|archive-date=2017-12-26|url-status = live}} In total, 131,843 CJ-3As were produced before the series ended in 1953. About 550 of the CJ3-As were assembled by [[Mitsubishi]] as the J1/J2 in late 1952 and early 1953, exclusively for the Japanese police and forestry agency.{{cite book|last=Ozeki |first=Kazuo |title = 日本のトラック・バス 1918~1972 |trans-title=Japanese Trucks and Buses 1918-1972 |publisher=Miki Press |year=2007 |page=131 |location=Tokyo |language= Japanese |isbn=978-4-89522-494-9}} The CJ-3A-derived military jeep was the [[Willys M38|Willys MC (or M38)]], and it began complementing the Ford and Willys [[Willys MB|World War II jeeps]] starting in 1949. [[File:1951 Willys Overland CJ-3a (12670063085).jpg|thumb|left|1951 CJ-3A military version]] {{clear}} ==CJ-4== {{Infobox automobile | name = Willys-Overland CJ-4 | production = {{unbulleted list|1951|One produced}} | engine = {{convert|134|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Willys Hurricane engine|Hurricane]] I4 | wheelbase = {{convert|81|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} The '''Willys-Overland CJ-4''' or "X-151" was only built as an experimental concept in 1950 or 1951.{{cite web|url=https://cj3b.info/CJ4.html|title=The Lost CJ-4 on CJ3B.info|author=|date=|website=cj3b.info|access-date=2017-12-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011132938/http://cj3b.info/CJ4.html|archive-date=2017-10-11|url-status = live}} It used the new [[Willys Hurricane engine]] and had an {{convert|81|in|mm|0|abbr=on|adj=on}} [[wheelbase]]. The CJ-4 body tub was an intermediate design between the straightforward raised hood from the CJ-3B and the all new curved body style of the CJ-5. The design was rejected and the vehicle was eventually sold to a factory employee.{{Cite web |url= https://assets.hemmings.com/uimage/1364246-0-1200.jpg |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-12-28 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20171229112427/https://assets.hemmings.com/uimage/1364246-0-1200.jpg |archive-date=2017-12-29 |url-status = live}} Evidence has surfaced, that derived prototypes called CJ-4M and CJ-4MA (XM170) have also been seriously considered, as precursors to the 1951 M38A1 and M170 military Jeeps. Although the CJ-4M prototype may not have been actually built,{{cite web|url=https://cj3b.info/CJ4M.html|title=The CJ-4M Jeep Prototype on CJ3B.info|author=|date=|website=cj3b.info|access-date=2017-12-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011133113/http://cj3b.info/CJ4M.html|archive-date=2017-10-11|url-status = live}} the stretched wheelbase ambulance prototype with registration "CJ-4MA-01" turned up in 2005.{{cite web|url=https://cj3b.info/CJ4MA01.html|title=CJ-4MA Jeep Prototype on CJ3B.info|author=|date=|website=cj3b.info|access-date=2017-12-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011161927/http://cj3b.info/CJ4MA01.html|archive-date=2017-10-11|url-status = live}} {{clear}} ==CJ-3B== {{Infobox automobile |name = Willys CJ-3B |image = Willyjeep01.jpg |related = Willys M606 |production = 1953-1968 |engine = {{convert|134|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Hurricane I4 |wheelbase = {{convert|80|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1962_Jeep/1962_Jeep_CJ-3B_Brochure/1962%20Jeep%20CJ-3B-03.html |title=Jeep: 1962 Jeep CJ-3B Brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |accessdate=2011-11-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306064326/http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1962_Jeep/1962_Jeep_CJ-3B_Brochure/1962%20Jeep%20CJ-3B-03.html |archive-date=2012-03-06 |url-status = live}} |length = {{convert|129.875|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} The '''Willys CJ-3B''' replaced the [[#CJ-3A|CJ-3A]] in 1953, the same year Willys-Overland was bought by [[Kaiser Motors]]. The Kaiser parent company removed "Overland" from the Willys Motors subcompany name. The CJ-3B introduced a higher grille and hood to clear the new Willys Hurricane engine. A four-speed manual transmission became optional in 1963, at an extra cost of $194. The turning radius was {{convert|17|ft|6|in|m|1|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1962_Jeep/1962_Jeep_CJ-3B_Brochure/1962%20Jeep%20CJ-3B-03.html |title=1962 Jeep CJ-3B brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |accessdate=2012-05-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306064326/http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1962_Jeep/1962_Jeep_CJ-3B_Brochure/1962%20Jeep%20CJ-3B-03.html |archive-date=2012-03-06 |url-status = live}} Until 1968, about 196,000 CJ-3Bs were produced, of which 155,494 were assembled in the U.S.{{cite web|last=Redmond |first=Derek |title=Jeeps for Export on The CJ3B Page |url=http://www.film.queensu.ca/cj3b/History.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205195030/http://www.film.queensu.ca/cj3b/Factory/FactoryExport.html |archive-date=2010-12-05 |url-status = dead| work=Film.queensu.ca |date=2004-11-11 |accessdate=2010-09-29}}{{cite web|url=https://www.kaiserwillys.com/about_willys_jeep_cj3b_history_specs|title=About Willys Vehicles - CJ-3B Universal|author=|date=|website=www.kaiserwillys.com|access-date=2017-12-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228000138/https://www.kaiserwillys.com/about_willys_jeep_cj3b_history_specs|archive-date=2017-12-28|url-status = live}} The CJ-3B was turned into the M606 military jeep (mostly used for export, through 1968) by equipping it with commercially available heavy-duty options, such as larger tires and springs, and by adding black-out lighting, [[olive drab]] paint, and a trailer hitch. Shipments of the M606 militarized version of the Jeep CJ-3B, exported for military aid under the [[Mutual Defense Assistance Act#Mutual Assistance Program|Mutual Defense Assistance Program]], accounted for a substantial percentage of the limited CJ-3B production in the 1960s. === International licenses and derivatives === The CJ-3B design was also licensed to a number of international manufacturers, which produced a civilian and military variants long after 1968, including [[Mitsubishi Motors|Mitsubishi]] of [[Japan]] and [[Mahindra & Mahindra Limited|Mahindra]] of [[India]]. Mitsubishi's version was built from 1953 until 1998, while Mahindra continued to produce vehicles based on the Willys CJ-3B until October 1, 2010. The CJ-3B was also built by Türk Willys Overland. It was the first vehicle plant to be opened in Turkey, in 1954.{{citation |title=1963 Türk Willys Overland: Universal Jeep CJ-3B |type=Museum placard |location=Hasköy, Istanbul, Turkey |publisher=Rahmi M. Koç Museum |quote=In 1954 the first vehicle plant in Turkey, Türk Willys Overland Ltd., was founded by Mr. Ferruh Verdi.}} Mahindra's "Mahindra CJ" produced in two versions: four-seater CJ 340 and six-seater CJ 540. Both were equipped with [[Peugeot]]-sourced {{convert|64|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} engines.{{cite web |title=Mahindra CJ history |url=http://betterparts.org/mahindra/mahindra-cj.html |website=betterparts.org |accessdate=8 December 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118043342/http://betterparts.org/mahindra/mahindra-cj.html |archive-date=18 November 2015 |url-status = live}} File:1963 Türk Willys CJ-3B.jpg|A 1963 Türk Willys Overland CJ-3B on display at the Rahmi M. Koç Museum of Transportation, [[Istanbul]] File:Mahindra CL 550 MDI @ Changanasseri.jpg| Mahindra's CL 550 MDI model File:Cj 6 restaurado en Extremadura.jpg|[[Vehículos Industriales y Agrícolas, S.A|VIASA in Spain]] built their model 'MB-CJ6' – a stretched CJ-3B with an MB 'Go-Devil' engine.[https://web.archive.org/web/20190514120016/https://bec7318a-a-62cb3a1a-s-sites.googlegroups.com/site/mbcj3bwillysviasa/Home/mb-cj3b_viasa/viasa1zg5.jpg?attachauth=ANoY7cp84GkpKyZsImQbeOvCHs9wrY3AeL_nx6uXVe5Pi7hM-V_1NzL749NvxEVu3ivXh_kIx1TLEJtzBromThPjfFn4m_WnN4soMykzsackAn-ZBVzsOa-IHNSn4QbHZqBGOm0HpDUtVnuhm8mYnqVODZbvu7qb4Lnvgtz9n9YWw3Fpo2V4HAa7XOWhqHHDGlM4h_7GYmrkAuuRJUKndZOXQSABFzRZGoPt60Bd6huNuhPhMVDI_E4vxBmGd8QbsJco_JB441Hx&attredirects=0 Willys-VIASA Universal Jeep advert with specifications] {{clear}} {{anchor|Mitsubishi}} ===Mitsubishi Jeep=== {{Infobox automobile |name = Mitsubishi Jeep J-series |image = Mitsubishi 1955 Jeep.JPG |manufacturer = [[Mitsubishi Motors]] |production = 1953-1998 |assembly = [[Mitsubishi Motors#Locations|Pajero Manufacturing Co., Ltd]], [[Sakahogi, Gifu]], Japan |successor = [[Mitsubishi Pajero]] |body_style = {{unbulleted list|2-door [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]]|2-door [[Convertible (car)|convertible]]|4-door [[station wagon]]}} |layout = [[Front-engine design|Front engine]], [[four-wheel drive]] |engine = {{unbulleted list |2.0 L ''[[Mitsubishi Astron engine#4G52|4G52]]'' I4|2.2 L ''JH4'' I4|2.4 L ''[[Mitsubishi Astron engine#4G53|4G53]]'' I4 |2.2 L ''[[Mitsubishi KE engine#KE31|KE31]]'' [[Diesel engine|diesel]] I4|2.7 L ''[[List of Mitsubishi Fuso engines#4DR5|4DR5]]'' diesel I4}} |length = {{convert|3390|-|4330|mm|in|abbr=on}} |wheelbase = {{unbulleted list |{{convert|2030|mm|in|abbr=on}}|{{convert|2255|mm|in|abbr=on}}|{{convert|2640|mm|in|abbr=on}}}} }} The Jeep was introduced to the Japanese market as the '''Jeep J3''' in July 1953 after Willys agreed to allow Mitsubishi to market the car, competing with the [[Nissan Patrol#First generation (4W60; 1951–1960)|Nissan Patrol]] and the [[Toyota Land Cruiser#J20, J30 (1955–1960)|Toyota Land Cruiser]].{{cite web |last1=Edsall |first1=Larry |title=Field Guide: Through the generations with Toyota's Land Cruiser |url=https://journal.classiccars.com/2018/09/22/field-guide-through-the-generations-with-toyotas-land-cruiser/ |website=The Classic Cars.com Journal |accessdate=7 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107010409/https://journal.classiccars.com/2018/09/22/field-guide-through-the-generations-with-toyotas-land-cruiser/ |archive-date=7 November 2018 |url-status = live}} The name was not in reference to "CJ3", but rather denoted the fact that 53 "J1"s (CJ-3A with 6-volt electrics) were built for the Japanese [[Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (Japan)|regional forest office]] and around 500 "J2"s (CJ-3A with 12-volt electrics) were built for the [[Japan Ground Self-Defense Force|National Safety Forces]]. Mitsubishi continued knock-down production of vehicles derived from the CJ-3B design until August 1998, when tighter emissions and safety standards finally made the Jeep obsolete. In total, about 200,000 units were built in this 45-year period.{{cite web |url=http://www.mitsubishi-motors.com/corporate/ir/share/pdf/e/fact_2008.pdf |title=Facts & Figures 2008 |publisher=Mitsubishi Motors |page=40 |date=October 2008 |location=Tokyo, Japan |url-status = dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320113933/http://www.mitsubishi-motors.com/corporate/ir/share/pdf/e/fact_2008.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-20 |df= }} Short, medium, and long wheelbases were available, as well as a variety of bodystyles, and gasoline and diesel engines.{{cite web |last=Redmond |first=Derek |url=http://www.film.queensu.ca/Cj3b/World/Japan2.html |title=Jeeps in Japan |publisher=Film.queensu.ca |date=2010-05-01 |accessdate=2011-05-05 |url-status = dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604024946/http://www.film.queensu.ca/Cj3b/World/Japan2.html |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }} In Japan, it was sold at a specific retail chain called [[Mitsubishi Motors#Japan Sales Channels|Galant Shop]]. The Japanese GSDF refers to them as [[Mitsubishi Type 73 Light Truck|Type 73 Light Truck]]. [[File:Mitsubishi Jeep J-37 003.JPG|thumb|left|Mitsubishi Jeep Delivery Wagon J37]] The original J3 was a basic, doorless, and roofless version, with steering on the left, rather than the right, despite Japan having left-side traffic. The first right-hand drive versions did not appear until nearly eight years later (J3R/J11R). The original J3 and its derivatives were equipped with the {{convert|2199|cc|L|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} [[IOE engine|F-head]] "Hurricane" (called JH4 by Mitsubishi, for '''J'''apanese '''H'''urricane '''4'''-cylinder) inline four-cylinder, originally producing {{convert|70|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} at 4,000 rpm.Ozeki, p. 140 In 1955 a slightly longer wheelbase '''J10''' which could seat six was added, and in 1956 the '''J11''' appeared, a two-door "delivery wagon" with a full metal body. This was considerably longer, at {{convert|433|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} versus {{convert|339|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} for the J3. Local production of the JH4 engine commenced in 1955. A locally developed diesel version ([[Mitsubishi KE engine|KE31]]) was introduced for the JC3 in 1958, originally with {{convert|56|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 3,500 rpm but with {{convert|61|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} at 3,600 rpm a few years later. Later versions used 4DR5 and 4DR6 (J23 turbo) 2.7 liter overhead-valve diesel engines. The final military version J24A produced 135PS from an improved 4DR5 engine with front-mounted air-to-air intercooler. By 1962, the output of the gasoline JH4 engine had crept up to {{convert|76|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}}. By the time of the introduction of the longer '''J20''' in 1960, a six-seater like the J10, but with a differently configurated (more permanent) front windshield, as well as available metal doors, Mitsubishi had also added small diagonal skirts to the leading edge of the Jeep's front fenders. This remained the last change to the sheetmetal up front until the end of Mitsubishi Jeep production in 1998. Later models include 2-L, short-wheelbase, soft-top '''J58''' ('''J54''' with a diesel engine), and the '''J38''' gasoline wagon on the longest wheelbase.{{cite book |ref=JAMA25 |title= 自動車ガイドブック |trans-title=Japanese Motor Vehicles Guide Book |language= Japanese |volume=25 |date=1978-10-10 |publisher =Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association |pages=206–207 |id=0053-780025-3400 }} The last iteration of the Japanese Jeeps was the J53 with diesel turbo engine. {{clear}} ==CJ-5== {{Infobox automobile |name = Willys CJ-5/Jeep CJ-5 |image = Jeep CJ-5 V6 red open body.jpg |production = 1954-1983
603,303 produced {{cite book |last=Morr |first=Tom |last2=Brubaker |first2=Ken |date=2007 |title=Jeep Off-Road |url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=QKrYGfVMUdMC&pg=PA88&lpg=PA88&dq=603,303+CJ-5&source=bl&ots=XQfe3hLV_3&sig=LsKwEhyUMSQEIwhv4iWTyFMU8Ok&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWyaWoo6HYAhXFYVAKHclkB8gQ6AEIUjAJ#v=onepage&q=603%2C303%20CJ-5&f=false |location=Wisconsin |publisher=MotorBooks International |page=88 |isbn=9781610590563 |author-link= |access-date=2017-12-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171224213757/https://books.google.nl/books?id=QKrYGfVMUdMC&pg=PA88&lpg=PA88&dq=603,303+CJ-5&source=bl&ots=XQfe3hLV_3&sig=LsKwEhyUMSQEIwhv4iWTyFMU8Ok&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWyaWoo6HYAhXFYVAKHclkB8gQ6AEIUjAJ#v=onepage&q=603%2C303%20CJ-5&f=false |archive-date=2017-12-24 |url-status = live}} |model_years = 1955-1983 |aka = Ford Jeep (Brazil){{cite web|title="Jipes" in Brasil |url=http://www.film.queensu.ca/cj3b/World/Brasil.html |publisher=The CJ3B Page |last=Redmond |first=Derek |accessdate=2012-02-19 |url-status = dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100716184147/http://www.film.queensu.ca/CJ3b/World/Brasil.html |archivedate=2010-07-16 |df= }}
Jeep Shahbaz ([[Iran]], [[Pars Khodro]]){{cite web|url= http://web.parskhodro.ir/pdf/Parskhodro%20history.pdf |title=Pars Khodro in history |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120312213724/http://web.parskhodro.ir/pdf/Parskhodro%20history.pdf |archivedate=12 March 2012 |accessdate=27 April 2013}}
Shinjin Jeep (South Korea)[http://news.donga.com/3/all/20140614/64257952/1 국내 최장수 자동차 브랜드 ‘코란도’의 7전8기] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304114855/http://news.donga.com/3/all/20140614/64257952/1 |date=2016-03-04 }}, Dong-a Ilbo, 06-14-2014 |engine = {{unbulleted list|{{convert|134|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Willys Hurricane I4 |{{convert|192|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Perkins 4.192 I4 diesel | {{convert|225|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Buick V6 engine#Dauntless|Dauntless]] V6 | {{convert|151|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[GM Iron Duke engine#Hurricane|Iron Duke]] I4 | {{convert|232|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC Straight-6 engine|AMC I6]] | {{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I6 |{{convert|304|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC V8 engine#304|AMC V8]]}} |transmission = {{unbulleted list|three-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]]|four-speed manual}} |wheelbase = {{unbulleted list|{{convert|81|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (1954-1971)|{{convert|83.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite book|last=DeLong|first=Brad|title=4-wheel Freedom|publisher=Paladin Press|isbn=0-87364-891-9}} (1972-1983)}} |length = {{convert|138.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|68.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|67.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |weight = {{convert|2665|lb|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=http://www.carfolio.com/specifications/models/car/?car=58322 |title=1979 Jeep CJ-5 car technical specifications from Carfolio.com - 0 door 4.2-L (4235 cc) I6 99.4 PS, 2X3 speed manual |publisher=Carfolio.com |accessdate=2010-12-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314102420/http://www.carfolio.com/specifications/models/car/?car=58322 |archive-date=2012-03-14 |url-status = live}} |related = {{unbulleted list | [[Jeep DJ|Jeep DJ-5]]|[[Willys M38A1]]}} }} The '''Willys CJ-5''' (after 1964 '''Jeep CJ-5''') was influenced by new corporate owner, Kaiser, and the [[Korean War]] [[Willys M38A1|M38A1]] Jeep. It was intended to replace the CJ-3B, but that model continued in production. The CJ-5 repeated this pattern, continuing in production for three decades while three newer models appeared. "The CJ-5 has the distinct honor of being a vehicle that was hard to kill off... equaling the longest production run of note." {{cite journal |url=http://www.jpmagazine.com/featuredvehicles/154_0707_history_of_jeep_cj5_jeep_autopsy/ |last=Tellem |first=Tori |title=History of the CJ-5 - Jeep Autopsy: CJ-5 One Of The "Unstoppables" |journal=JP Magazine |date=June 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621071512/http://www.jpmagazine.com/featuredvehicles/154_0707_history_of_jeep_cj5_jeep_autopsy/ |archive-date=21 June 2013 |url-status = live}} [[File:'67 Kaiser Jeep (Auto classique VAQ St-Lambert '12).jpg|thumb|left|Willys M38A1]] From 1961 to 1965, optional for the CJ-5 and CJ-6 was the British-made [[Perkins Engines|Perkins]] {{convert|192|cuin|L|2|abbr=on}} Diesel I4 with {{convert|62|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 3,000 rpm and {{convert|143|lb/ft|0|abbr=on}} at 1350 rpm.{{cite web |url=http://www.baeta.org/opie/engine.htm#P |title=Engine Specs - Jeep Engines |publisher=Baeta.org |accessdate=2011-11-20 |url-status = dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116163924/http://www.baeta.org/opie/engine.htm#P |archivedate=2011-11-16 |df= }} In 1965, Kaiser bought license to produce the [[Buick]] {{convert|225|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V6 [[Buick V6 engine#Dauntless|Dauntless]] engine, to offer the new {{convert|155|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} option on the CJ-5 and CJ-6, countering complaints that the 75 hp [[Inline-four engine|four-cylinder]] Willys Hurricane engine was underpowered. Power steering was an $81 option. The V6 engine proved so popular, by 1968, some 75% of CJ-5s were sold with it. [[File:Jeep-A-Trench on a CJ-5 rr.jpg|thumb|left|CJ-5 with the "Jeep-A-Trench" accessory]] Kaiser Jeep was sold to [[American Motors|American Motors Corporation]] (AMC) in 1970, and the Buick engine was retired after the 1971 model year. (GM's [[Buick]] division repurchased the engine tooling in the early 1970s which served as the powerplant in several GM vehicles.) The "Trac-Lok" [[limited-slip differential]] replaced the "Powr-Lok" in 1971, and PTOs were no longer available after that year.{{cite web|url=http://www.jeep-cj.com/forums/f105/transfer-cases-12108/#post97071|title=Transfer Cases - Jeep-CJ Forums|author=|date=|website=www.jeep-cj.com|access-date=2017-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230225819/http://www.jeep-cj.com/forums/f105/transfer-cases-12108/#post97071|archive-date=2017-12-30|url-status = live}} AMC began marketing the Jeep less as a universal utility vehicle, and more as a sporty one, notably increasing its performance and features. '''1972 Revamp'''
The 1972 model year brought significant changes to the CJ-5. American Motors began fitting their own engines, which also required changes to both body and chassis. The base Willys 4-cylinder was replaced by AMC's Torque Command straight-6 engines, giving the entry-level CJ-5 the power of the previously optional Buick V6. Standard became the {{convert|232|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}}, and optional the {{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}}, which was standard in California. Both engines used a one-barrel Carter YF carburetor. Also in 1972, [[AMC V8 engine#304|AMC's {{convert|304|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8]] engine became available, which upgraded the [[power-to-weight ratio]] to a level comparable to a V8 muscle-car. Other drive-train changes included a new front axle - a full-floating, open-knuckle [[Dana 30]], which was both 25 lbs lighter and reduced the turning circle by 6 ft. To accommodate the new engines, the wheelbase was stretched by {{convert|3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}, and the fenders and hood were stretched by {{convert|5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}, pushing the firewall two inches closer to the rear.{{cite book |last=Cranswick |first=Marc |date=2011 |title=The Cars of American Motors: An Illustrated History |url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=r9j7MWLE_jMC&pg=PA241&lpg=PA241&dq=1972+cj-5+nose&source=bl&ots=tUrD5PeDip&sig=LbSTN4Sggq3bTVzuzxFl3cgocqw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwichfjsg7LYAhWGmLQKHXwfBPg4ChDoAQhfMAk#v=onepage&q=1972%20cj-5%20nose&f=false |location= |publisher=McFarland |page=241 |isbn=9780786485703 |author-link= |access-date=2017-12-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230231136/https://books.google.nl/books?id=r9j7MWLE_jMC&pg=PA241&lpg=PA241&dq=1972+cj-5+nose&source=bl&ots=tUrD5PeDip&sig=LbSTN4Sggq3bTVzuzxFl3cgocqw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwichfjsg7LYAhWGmLQKHXwfBPg4ChDoAQhfMAk#v=onepage&q=1972%20cj-5%20nose&f=false |archive-date=2017-12-30 |url-status = live}}{{cite web|url=https://www.kaiserwillys.com/about_willys_jeep_cj5_history_specs|title=About Willys Vehicles - CJ-5, 6|author=|date=|website=www.kaiserwillys.com|access-date=2017-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230230454/https://www.kaiserwillys.com/about_willys_jeep_cj5_history_specs|archive-date=2017-12-30|url-status = live}} A new box-frame was fitted, featuring six cross-members for more rigidity.{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-car-history.com/cj-jeep-history.htm|title=CJ Jeep History|first=Mark|last=Trotta|date=|website=www.classic-car-history.com|access-date=2017-12-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230114906/http://www.classic-car-history.com/cj-jeep-history.htm|archive-date=2017-12-30|url-status = live}} Also, a larger fuel tank was mounted, moved from under the driver's seat to under the rear, between the frame rails.{{cite web|url=http://www.jeepfan.com/tech/spotters-guide-to-the-72-75-amc-cj-5/|title=Identifying a Jeep, An In-depth Spotters Guide to the 72-75 AMC Jeep CJ-5 - jeepfan.com|author=|date=|website=www.jeepfan.com|access-date=2017-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230172559/http://www.jeepfan.com/tech/spotters-guide-to-the-72-75-amc-cj-5/|archive-date=2017-12-30|url-status = live}} A dealer-installed radio became available in 1973, air conditioning became available via dealership in 1975. Electronic, breakerless distributors replaced breaker-point Delco distributors for the full engine line-up, and a catalytic converter was added to models equipped with the 304 V8.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zTsAbTJB5RIC&pg=PA49&dq=cj+jeep+stood+for+Civilian |pages=91–92 |title=Jeep Collector's Library |first=Jim |last=Allen |publisher=MBI Publishing |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-7603-1979-6 |accessdate=22 May 2014 |authorlink=Jim Allen (4x4 writer) |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140708051243/http://books.google.com/books?id=zTsAbTJB5RIC&pg=PA49&dq=cj+jeep+stood+for+Civilian |archive-date=8 July 2014 |url-status = live}} In 1975, for the 1976 model year, the tub and frame were modified from earlier versions. The frame went from a partially open channel/boxed frame with riveted crossmembers, to majoritively boxed with welded crossmembers, and from parallel rails to widening fore to aft to benefit stability.{{Cite web |url=https://www.jeep-cj.com/forums/f102/cj5-1972-1975-a-12408/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-12-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230172121/https://www.jeep-cj.com/forums/f102/cj5-1972-1975-a-12408/ |archive-date=2017-12-30 |url-status = live}} and the body tub became more rounded. The windshield frame and windshield angle were also changed, meaning that tops from 1955 to 1975 will not fit a 1976-1983 CJ-5 and vice versa. The rear axle was also changed in 1976 from a [[Dana 44]] to an AMC-manufactured [[AMC 20|model 20]] that had a larger-diameter ring gear, but used a two-piece axleshaft/hub assembly instead of the one-piece design used in the Dana. For 1977, the frame was modified again to a completely boxed unit. Power disc brakes and the "Golden Eagle" package (which included a tachometer and clock) were new options, as well as air conditioning. In 1979, the standard engine became the {{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} I6 that now featured a Carter BBD two-barrel [[carburetor]]. From 1980 to 1983, the CJ-5 came standard with a "Hurricane"-branded version of the [[General Motors|GM]] [[GM Iron Duke engine#Hurricane|Iron Duke]] I4 with an SR4 close-ratio, four-speed manual transmission. The {{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC straight-6 engine remained available as an option, but the transmission was changed from the Tremec T-150 three-speed to a Tremec T-176 close-ratio four-speed. The Dana 30 front axle was retained, but the locking hubs were changed to a five-bolt retaining pattern versus the older six-bolt. The demise of the AMC CJ5 model has been attributed to a December 1980 ''60 Minutes'' segment where the [[Insurance Institute for Highway Safety]] (IIHS) staged a demonstration to illustrate that the CJ5 was apt to roll over "in routine road circumstances at relatively low speeds." Years later, it was revealed the testers only managed to achieve eight rollovers out of 435 runs through a corner. The IIHS requested the testers implement "vehicle loading" (hanging weights in the vehicle's corners inside the body, where they were not apparent to the camera) to generate worst-case conditions for stability.{{cite web|url=http://walterolson.com/articles/crashtests.html|title="It Didn't Start With Dateline NBC" (National Review 6/21/93)|first=Walter|last=Olson|website=walterolson.com|accessdate=5 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170512134539/http://walterolson.com/articles/crashtests.html|archive-date=12 May 2017|url-status = live}} ===Special CJ-5 versions=== *1961 '''Tuxedo Park''' *1962 '''Tuxedo Park Mark II''' *1963 '''Tuxedo Park Mark III''' *1965 '''Tuxedo Park Mark IV''' :The early Tuxedo Park models were trim lines designed to make the CJ "more comfortable and appealing to the general public."{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zTsAbTJB5RIC&pg=PA82&dq=Jeep+Tuxedo+Park+Mark |page=82 |title=Jeep Collector's Library |first=Jim |last=Allen |publisher=Motorbooks |year=2004 |isbn=9780760319796 |accessdate=9 December 2015 |authorlink=Jim Allen (4x4 writer) |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603184045/https://books.google.com/books?id=zTsAbTJB5RIC&pg=PA82&dq=Jeep+Tuxedo+Park+Mark |archive-date=3 June 2016 |url-status = live}} However, the Tuxedo Park Mark IV was claimed as a separate model from the other CJ series (marked in 1965 as the "Universal"), with more differences than past models. The Tuxedo Park Mark IV was an attempt to crack the mass market; it was, according to Jeep, “a new idea in sports cars ... the sportiest, most FUNctional car on the automotive scene." It added to the standard CJ chrome-plated bumpers, hood latches, gas cap, mirror, and tail lamp trim. Two wheelbases, {{convert|81|in|mm|abbr=on}} and {{convert|101|in|mm|abbr=on}}, were available, with a variety of convertible top and seat colors, and front bucket seats upholstered in "pleated British calf-grain vinyl". Sales of this model, introduced in 1965, were low.{{cite web |url=http://www.allpar.com/trucks/jeep/1965.html |title=Jeep for 1965: CJ, Wagoneer, Gladiator, Universal, Fleetvan, and DJ |work=allpar.com |accessdate=9 December 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151205140021/http://www.allpar.com/trucks/jeep/1965.html |archive-date=5 December 2015 |url-status = live}} *1969-1970 '''Camper''' :From 1969 Kaiser-Jeep offered a camper for the CJ-5 as a factory option, but also available separately, as it would fit any CJ-5 made since 1955. The camper mounted in the "bed" of the CJ-5, extended well beyond the back of the car, and had another axle of its own, that carried most of the weight. It also extended above the front seats of a CJ-5, which is where the main sleeper was located.{{cite web|url=http://www.cj5camper.com/|title=Rare Jeep Camper - 1969 CJ5 Jeep Camper History, Photos and Information|author=|date=|website=www.cj5camper.com|access-date=2013-12-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228021503/http://www.cj5camper.com/|archive-date=2013-12-28|url-status = live}}{{cite web|url=http://www.doityourselfrv.com/1969-cj5-jeep-camper/|title=The 1969 CJ5 Jeep Camper Could Be The Rarest RV Ever|author=|date=|website=www.doityourselfrv.com|access-date=2017-12-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229231848/http://www.doityourselfrv.com/1969-cj5-jeep-camper/|archive-date=2017-12-29|url-status = live}}{{cite web |url=http://www.street2mud.com/albums/album02/JeepCJ5Camper_5.jpg |title=New 'Jeep' camper (brochure) |page=5 |publisher= |accessdate=27 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227142931/http://www.street2mud.com/albums/album02/JeepCJ5Camper_5.jpg |archive-date=27 February 2012 |url-status = live}}{{cite web |url=http://www.street2mud.com/albums/album02/JeepCJ5Camper_6.jpg |title=New 'Jeep' camper (brochure) |page=6 |publisher= |accessdate=27 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227142952/http://www.street2mud.com/albums/album02/JeepCJ5Camper_6.jpg |archive-date=27 February 2012 |url-status = live}}{{cite web |url=http://www.street2mud.com/albums/album02/JeepCJ5Camper_7.jpg |title=New 'Jeep' camper (brochure) |page=7 |publisher= |accessdate=27 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227142956/http://www.street2mud.com/albums/album02/JeepCJ5Camper_7.jpg |archive-date=27 February 2012 |url-status = live}}{{cite web |url=http://www.street2mud.com/albums/album02/JeepCJ5Camper_8.jpg |title=New 'Jeep' camper (brochure) |page=8 |publisher= |accessdate=27 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227143000/http://www.street2mud.com/albums/album02/JeepCJ5Camper_8.jpg |archive-date=27 February 2012 |url-status = live}} When AMC bought Kaiser-Jeep in 1970, they ended the Jeep camper option. With only 336 produced, the Jeep Camper is one of the rarest commercial RV models ever. *1969 '''462''' :The 1969 Universal offered a "462" performance package. It was a limited-production model that featured the V6 engine, front bucket seats and a rear bench, roll bar, heavy-duty frame and springs, a locking differential, oil-pan skid plate, rear swing-out tire carrier, full wheel covers, ammeter, and oil pressure gauges; padded visors were optional.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dR3wmKlfnrMC&pg=PA95&dq=Jeep+462 |page=95 |title=Jeep Color History |first=Steve |last=Statham |publisher=Motorbooks |year=1999 |isbn=9780760306369 |accessdate=9 December 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160502102110/https://books.google.com/books?id=dR3wmKlfnrMC&pg=PA95&dq=Jeep+462 |archive-date=2 May 2016 |url-status = live}} [[File:1974 Jeep CJ-5 Renegade V8 in yellow - all original - at 2015 AACA Eastern Regional Fall Meet 1of7.jpg|thumb|Mostly original 1974 Jeep CJ-5 Renegade]] *1970 '''Renegade I''' :The 1970 "Renegade I" models continued the features of the "462" package, along with special hood trim stripes and limited colors. Renegade I production for 1970 is estimated between 250 and 500 units equipped with all of the previous performance upgrades along with a simple black stripe on the sides of the hood, new 8-inch wide white road wheels with G70x15 tires, and offered in only two bright colors: Wild Plum and Mint Green.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EwWpAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA95&dq=1970+Jeep+Renegade+I+Wild+Plum+Mint+Green |page=95 |title=Jeep: The History of America's Greatest Vehicle |first=Patrick R. |last=Foster |publisher=Motorbooks |year=2014 |isbn=9780760345856 |accessdate=9 December 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603181536/https://books.google.com/books?id=EwWpAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA95&dq=1970+Jeep+Renegade+I+Wild+Plum+Mint+Green |archive-date=3 June 2016 |url-status = live}} Note that there may have been other colors produced including a pale yellow produced in October of 1969. *1971 '''Renegade II''' :The 1971 "Renegade II" continued the previous year's features with bright alloy road wheels (replacing the painted steel units), the addition of a black center hood stripe, and new color selections: about 200 were painted Baja Yellow, 200 Mint Green, 50 Riverside Orange, and 150 finished in Big Bad Orange, the same paint as available on the "Big Bad" [[AMC AMX]] and [[AMC Javelin|Javelin]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpdUEVGU2toC&pg=PA143&dq=1971+Jeep+Renegade+II |page=143 |title=The Story of Jeep |first=Patrick |last=Foster |publisher=Krause Publications |year=2004 |isbn=9780873497350 |accessdate=9 December 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521025058/https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpdUEVGU2toC&pg=PA143&dq=1971+Jeep+Renegade+II |archive-date=21 May 2016 |url-status = live}} AMC design studios proposed a striping scheme for a Renegade III model for the 1972 model year, but because of their popularity, the Renegade became a regular production appearance package option.Foster, Jeep: The History of America's Greatest Vehicle, p, 102. *1972-1983 '''Renegade''' :The 1972 "Renegade" was available from 1972 to 1983 with AMC's {{convert|304|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 engine, alloy wheels, and a Trac-Lok limited-slip differential. [[File:1979 Jeep CJ Silver Anniversary edition at Hershey 2015 AACA show 3of7.jpg|thumb|right|1979 Jeep CJ Silver Anniversary edition, lengthened nose as compared to pre-1972 models]] *1973 '''Super Jeep''' :Only produced in 1973, the Super Jeep was an appearance package created because of a shortage of aluminum wheels needed for the CJ-5 Renegade versions. Only a few hundred were built.{{cite web|url=http://www.jeepcollection.com/portfolio/1973-cj5-5-super-jeep/|title=1973 CJ5 Super Jeep - Jeep Collection|author=|date=|website=www.jeepcollection.com|access-date=2017-12-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229232216/http://www.jeepcollection.com/portfolio/1973-cj5-5-super-jeep/|archive-date=2017-12-29|url-status = live}} *1977-1983 '''Golden Eagle''' :From 1977 to 1983, the Golden Eagle package came with a soft-top or hard-top option, power disc brakes, power steering, tachometer, 304 CID V8, air conditioning, side steps, and Golden Eagle decals. *1979 '''Silver Anniversary'''{{cite web|url=http://www.79silver.com|title=The Silver Registry|website=www.79silver.com|accessdate=28 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729001917/http://www.79silver.com/|archive-date=29 July 2017|url-status = live}} :The 1979 Silver Anniversary edition was a limited-edition version (1000 units) of the Renegade model marketed to celebrate 25 years of the CJ-5. Features included a special "Quick Silver" metallic paint, black to silver accent body striping and special Renegade decals on the hood sides, black soft top, special spare tire cover, black vinyl bucket seats, and a dashboard plaque noting the CJ's production from 1954 to 1979.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EwWpAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA115&dq=1979+Jeep+Silver+Anniversary+CJ-5 |page=115 |title=Jeep: The History of America's Greatest Vehicle |first=Patrick R. |last=Foster |publisher=Motorbooks |year=2014 |isbn=9780760345856 |accessdate=9 December 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504020947/https://books.google.com/books?id=EwWpAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA115&dq=1979+Jeep+Silver+Anniversary+CJ-5 |archive-date=4 May 2016 |url-status = live}} *1980 '''Golden Hawk''' — a 1980-only sticker package for CJ-5, CJ-7 and Cherokee. *1980-1983 '''Laredo''' === Australia === In Australia, a unique variant of the CJ5/CJ6 was produced in limited numbers. In 1965, when the CJ was given the all-new Buick V6, Jeep saw the need for something similar in Australia. So, they began to fit Falcon 6-cylinder engines to them at their Rocklea factory in Queensland. The Jeep was fitted with an engine, pedal box, and clutch/brake system corresponding to the equivalent Falcon at the time; a 1965 CJ5 would be fitted with 1965 Falcon engine/clutch components. Combat 6 jeeps were also fitted with Australian Borg Warner differentials, and Borg Warner-brand gearboxes. Very little documentation about these Jeeps remains, and often the only way to conclusively identify them is by owner history.{{cite web|url=http://www.film.queensu.ca/cj3b/world/australia.html |title=Jeeps in Australia |publisher=The CJ3B Page |date=21 February 2012 |accessdate=24 August 2012 |url-status = dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100716221723/http://www.film.queensu.ca/cj3b/World/Australia.html |archivedate=16 July 2010 |df= }} ===Brazil=== [[File:1963 Willys Jeep Universal.jpg|thumb|1963 Brazilian-built CJ-5]] While most foreign assemblers focused on the CJ-3B, Brazil received the CJ-5, instead. After having closed their market to imported cars in 1954, assembly of the "Willys Jeep Universal" (as it was known in Brazil) from CKD kits began in 1957. By 1958, production relied on locally sourced components, with the vehicles equipped with a {{convert|90|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 2.6 liter I6 engine (also used by Willys do Brasil for passenger cars). The Universals came with a three-speed manual transmission. The Brazilian-built vehicles are easily recognized by their squared-off rear wheel openings. In 1961, a long-wheelbase version, similar to the [[#CJ6|CJ-6]], was added to the line. On 9 October 1967, [[Ford do Brasil]] bought the Brazilian Willys subsidiary and took over the production of the CJ-5, the [[Willys Jeep Station Wagon]]-based "[[Ford Rural|Rural]]", and its pick-up truck version. Ford kept the line with no modifications except for some Ford badges on the sides and on the tailgate. In 1976, Ford equipped the CJ-5 and the Rural with the locally built version of the 2.3-L OHC four-cylinder engine used in the Ford Pinto (also used in the Brazilian [[Ford Maverick (Americas)|Maverick]]) and a four-speed manual transmission. This engine produced {{convert|91|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} ([[Horsepower#Society of Automotive Engineers|SAE]]) at 5000 rpm.{{cite book|title=World Cars 1981 |publisher=The Automobile Club of Italy/Herald Books |editor-last=Lösch |editor-first=Annamaria |page=259 |year=1981 |isbn=9780910714136 }} In 1980, the engine was modified to run on [[ethanol]] ([[Neat ethanol fuel|E100]]); this option lasted until 1983, when Ford ended the production of the CJ-5 in Brazil. {{clear}} ==CJ-6== {{Infobox automobile |image = Willys Jeep Universal 101 4p.jpg |name = Willys CJ-6/Jeep CJ-6 |production = 1955-1975 |wheelbase = {{unbulleted list|{{convert|101|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (1955-1971)|{{convert|103.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (1972-1981)}} |engine = {{unbulleted list|{{convert|134|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Willys Hurricane I4|{{convert|225|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Buick V6 engine#Dauntless|Dauntless]] [[V6 engine|V6]]|{{convert|151|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} GM Iron Duke I4|{{convert|232|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I6|{{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I6|{{convert|304|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC V8 engine#304|AMC V8]]|{{convert|192|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Perkins 4.192 I4 diesel}} |related = Wilys M170 }} The '''CJ-6''' was a stretched version of the CJ-5 with a {{convert|20|in|mm|0|abbr=on|adj=on}} longer-wheelbase (101 in, 1955-1971 / 103.5 in, 1972–1981). The extended chassis allowed a variety of configurations, including adding a second row of seats. Introduced in 1953 as the M170 military version, the civilian CJ-6 made its debut in 1955 as a 1956 model. Never very popular in the United States, most CJ-6 models were sold to [[Sweden]] and South America. It was also assembled in South Africa, by [[Volkswagen]]'s local subsidiary.{{cite journal | ref = SAM1076 | journal = SA Motor | title = News Models | page = 71 | editor-last = Howard | editor-first = Tony | publisher = Scott Publications | location = Cape Town, South Africa | date = October 1976 }} The [[U.S. Forest Service]] put a number of CJ-6 Jeeps into use. American sales ended after 1975, with the introduction of the CJ-7. Just 50,172 had been made when the series went out of production completely in 1981. Just as in the CJ-5, the V6 and V8 engine choices appeared in 1965 and 1972. The M170 military version shared many of the features of the [[Willys M38A1|M38A1]] (Military CJ-5), but had the passenger-door opening extended back to the rear wheel well. Most were used as front-line field ambulances, able to carry four litters. A few were also used as radio units. The Brazilian Willys factory developed a version of the CJ-5 very similar to the CJ-6, offered with either two or four doors. Called the "Willys Jeep 101", it shared the chassis of the local Rural, a redesigned [[Willys Jeep Station Wagon]]. Like the Brazilian-made CJ5s, the 101 has square rear-wheel openings. This version was introduced in 1961, but was not retained after Ford's takeover in the fall of 1967. {{multiple image | align=left | width = 250 | image1=Jeep M170 Ambulance sl.jpg | caption1=The CJ-6 was derived from the 1953 military M170, typically an ambulance. | image2 = 1975 Jeep CJ extended pumper fl.jpg | caption2=Jeep CJ-6 fire engine in North Carolina, 2009.}} {{clear}} ==CJ-5A and CJ-6A== {{Infobox automobile |name = CJ-5A & CJ-6A |production = 1964-1968 }} From 1964 to 1968, Kaiser elevated the Tuxedo Park from just a trim package to a separate model for the CJ-5A and CJ-6A. A Tuxedo Park Mark IV is signified by a different prefix from a normal CJ-5 with a VIN prefix of 8322 and a CJ6a is 8422, while a normal CJ-5 VIN prefix is 8305 from 1964 to 1971. {{clear}} ==CJ-7== {{Redirect|CJ-7|the 2008 film|CJ7}} {{Infobox automobile |name = Jeep CJ-7 |aka = [[SsangYong Korando#First generation .281983.E2.80.931996.29|SsangYong Korando]] |image = CJ-7.jpg |model_years = 1976-1986 |engine = {{unbulleted list|{{convert|150|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC Straight-4 engine|AMC I4]]|{{convert|151|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Iron Duke I4|{{convert|232|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I6|{{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I6|{{convert|304|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC V8 engine#304|AMC V8]]|{{convert|145|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Isuzu [[List of Isuzu engines#Isuzu C engine|C240]] I4 diesel}} |transmission = {{unbulleted list|3-speed [[automatic transmission|automatic]]|3-speed manual|4-speed manual|5-speed manual}} |wheelbase = {{convert|93.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length = {{convert|148|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width = {{convert|68.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|67.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |weight = {{convert|2707|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=http://www.carfolio.com/specifications/models/car/?car=58366 |title=1979 Jeep CJ-7 car technical specifications |publisher=Carfolio.com |accessdate=21 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102062433/http://www.carfolio.com/specifications/models/car/?car=58366 |archive-date=2 November 2013 |url-status = live}} |successor = [[Jeep Wrangler (YJ)|Jeep Wrangler YJ]] }} The '''Jeep CJ-7''' featured a wheelbase 10 inches longer than that of the [[#CJ-5|CJ-5]], with its curved side entry cutouts partially squared up to accommodate hinged doors. The other main difference between CJ-5 and CJ-7 was to the chassis, which consisted of two parallel longitudinal main c-section rails. To help improve vehicle handling and stability, the rear section of the chassis stepped out to allow the springs and shock absorbers to be mounted closer to the outside of the body. It was introduced for the 1976 model year, with 379,299 built during 11 years of production. Transmission options included the standard part-time two-speed transfer case, automatic, and an optional new automatic [[all-wheel drive]] system called [[Jeep four-wheel-drive systems#Quadra-Trac|Quadra-Trac]]. Other features included an optional molded hardtop, and steel doors. The CJ-7 was also available in Renegade and Laredo models. Distinguished by their different body decals, the Laredo model featured highback leather bucket seats, a tilting steering wheel, and a chrome package that included the bumpers, front grill cover, and side mirrors. An optional Trak-Lok rear differential was available, too. Axle ratio was typically 2.73, with 3.13 as an option (standard in high-altitude regions). The reports of the CJ-7 were different in each type of engine: the {{convert|145|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Diesel engine|diesel]] was mated to the 4.10 ratio axle (in both Renegade and Laredo), while the 258 cubic-inch straight six and 150 cubic-inch four-cylinder used 3.73 and AMC V8 304-powered models (produced 1976-1981, which became part of the Golden Eagle version) used the 3.55 ratio axles. A diesel-powered version was made in the Ohio factory for export only. The engines were provided by General Motors, the owners of Isuzu Motor Cars. Production of this diesel version was between 1980 and 1982. This model had the Isuzu C240 engine, T176 transmission, and Dana 300 transfer case, although reports of some being produced with the Dana 20 exist. Typically, they had 4.1-ratio, narrow-track axles. From 1976 to 1980, the CJ-7 came equipped with a Dana 20 transfer case, Dana 30 front axle (27- or 31-spline), and a 29-spline AMC 20 rear axle, while later years, Laredo packages added tachometer, chrome bumpers, tow hooks, and interior upgrades including leather seats and clock. In 1980, the Laredo was first fitted with an AMC 20 rear axle until mid-1986, when it was equipped with a Dana 44, and all 1980 and newer CJ-7s came with the Dana 300 transfer case. The Canadian Army took delivery of 195 militarized versions of the CJ-7 in 1985. These were put into service as a stop-gap measure between the retirement of the M38A1 and the introduction of the [[Volkswagen Iltis|Bombardier Iltis]]. They were codified by the Canadian Forces with the Equipment Configuration Code number 121526. The CJ-7 continues to be used in the sport of mud racing, with either the stock body or a fiberglass replica. CJ-7 has been successfully and widely used as a favorite for rock crawling, through simple and complex modification. These last Jeeps produced were also highlighted with a factory dash plaque that read, "Last of a Great Breed - This collectors-edition CJ ends an era that began with the legendary Jeep of World War II". During its 11 years, the CJ-7 had various common trim packages: *1976-1986 '''Renegade''' (2.4D L6-2.5-4.2-5.0 AMC 304 V8) *1976-1980 '''Golden Eagle''' (5.0 AMC 304 V8) *1980 '''Golden Hawk''' (5.0 AMC 304 V8) *1980-1986 '''Laredo''' (2.4D-4.2 I6) [[File:Jambo -0152.jpg|thumb|left|1982 Jamboree Edition #0152 — Topaz Gold Metallic]] [[File:1982 Olympic White Jambo 693.jpg|thumb|1982 Jamboree Edition #0693 — Olympic White]] Jeep also produced two special edition CJ-7 packages: *1982-1983 '''Limited''' (2,500 units were built as a limited-production luxury model; 4.2-L I6 with T5 or automatic transmissions) *1982 '''Jamboree Commemorative Edition''' (630 numbered units built for the 30th anniversary of the Rubicon Trail;{{cite web|url=http://www.82jambo.com|title=The Jambo Registry|website=www.82jambo.com|accessdate=5 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170612223841/http://www.82jambo.com/|archive-date=12 June 2017|url-status = live}} 4.2L).  with only 630 units produced (560 Topaz Gold Metallic and 70 Olympic White), the CJ-7 Jamboree is the rarest CJ-7 ever built and one of the rarest Jeeps of all time. The Jamboree is in the same production rarity class as the 1971 CJ-5 Renegade-II. It is the most heavily optioned CJ ever built; it was the Rubicon of its day. All units were uniquely numbered via a dash plaque; it is the only AMC Jeep to have been numbered. '''Engines''' *{{convert|150|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I4 *{{convert|151|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} GM Iron Duke I4 *{{convert|232|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I6 *{{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I6 {{convert|99.4|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}}, {{convert|261|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} *{{convert|304|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC V8 {{convert|127|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}}, {{convert|296|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} *{{convert|145|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Isuzu Diesel C240 '''Transmissions''' *Warner T-18 (four-speed with a Dana 20 1976-1979) (aftermarket adapters exist for a dana 300, but it was not a factory option) (also known as a three-speed with granny gear) *Borg-Warner T-4 (four-speed with a Dana 300) *[[Borg-Warner T-5]] (five-speed with a Dana 300) *Tremec T-150 (three-speed manual transmission with a Dana 20 1976-1979) *Tremec T-176 (four-speed manual with a Dana 300) *Borg-Warner SR-4 (four-speed with a Dana 300) *[[Turbo-Hydramatic#Super Turbine 400 / THM400 / THM375 / 3L80 / 3L80HD|GM TH-400]] (three-speed automatic with BW QuadraTrac #1339) *[[TorqueFlite#A999|TF-999]] (three-speed automatic transmission - 4.2-L with a Dana 300) *[[TorqueFlite#A904|TF-904]] (three-speed automatic transmission - 2.5-L with a Dana 300) '''Transfer cases''' *[[AMC and Jeep transmissions#Dana 20|Dana 20]] (1976–79) *[[AMC and Jeep transmissions#Dana 300|Dana 300]] (1980–86) *[[Quadra-Trac|Borg-Warner #1339]] (1976–1979) '''Axles''' *[[Dana 30]] Front narrow track (1976–1981) *Dana 30 Front wide track (1982–1986) *2-Piece AMC 20 Narrow track rear (1976–1981) *2-Piece AMC 20 Narrow track offset differential rear (1976–1979) only for QuadraTrac #1339-equipped vehicles *2-Piece AMC 20 Wide track rear (1982–1986) *[[Dana 44]] Wide track rear (mid-year 1986) ==Scrambler (CJ-8)== [[File:Jeep SCrambler white SC-a.jpg|thumb|upright=1.25|right|Jeep Scrambler (CJ-8)]] The Jeep Scrambler ''' CJ-8 ''' was a long-wheelbase version of the [[Jeep CJ-7|CJ-7]], introduced in 1981 and manufactured through 1986. It featured a {{convert|103.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on|adj=on}} wheelbase{{cite web|url=https://www.morris4x4center.com/jeep-knowledge-center/cat/knowledge-base/post/jeep-vehicle-wheelbase-chart.htm|title=Jeep Vehicle Wheelbase Chart|author=|date=|website=morris4x4center.com|access-date=2017-12-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171215000528/https://www.morris4x4center.com/jeep-knowledge-center/cat/knowledge-base/post/jeep-vehicle-wheelbase-chart.htm|archive-date=2017-12-15|url-status = live}} and a removable half cab, creating a small pick-up style box instead of using a separate pickup bed. CJ-8s used the traditional transfer case with manual front [[locking hubs]] to engage the four-wheel drive. Most had either a four- or five-speed manual transmission, but a three-speed automatic transmission was an option. The term "Scrambler" comes from an appearance package with which many CJ-8s were equipped, which included tape graphics and special wheels. Former [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] owned a Scrambler "CJ-8" and used it on his California ranch.{{cite web |url=http://raysjeeps.net/president-reagan/ |title=President Reagan |work=Ray's Jeeps |year=2005 |accessdate=6 March 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160220093717/http://raysjeeps.net/president-reagan/ |archive-date=20 February 2016 |url-status = live}} A full-length steel hardtop CJ-8 was made for the Alaskan Postal Service, using right-hand drive and automatic transmissions. Instead of the rear tailgate, the steel hardtop used a hinged barn-door opening to the back. Only 230 were produced and sold in the U.S. It was also widely sold in Venezuela and Australia as the CJ8 Overlander, with small differences, including full-length rear windows on the Overlander.Jeep Overlander CJ-8 Specifications and Dimensions. Jeep Australia press release, 1984. Steel hardtops used on these postal Scramblers and Overlanders were known as "World Cab" tops.CJ10 technical manual ===Production=== {|class="wikitable" |- !Year !Production{{cite web |url=http://www.jeepfan.com/tech/prod-numbers.htm |title=Jeep Production Dates, Models, & Numbers |publisher=Jeepfan.com |year=2011 |accessdate=27 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130317034852/http://www.jeepfan.com/tech/prod-numbers.htm |archive-date=17 March 2013 |url-status = live}} |- |1981 |8,355 |- |1982 |7,759 |- |1983 |5,405 |- |1984 |4,130 |- |1985 |2,015 |- |1986 |128 |} ''There is some debate as to whether 1986 models were left over units from the previous model year.'' {{clear}} ==CJ-10== {{Infobox automobile |name = Jeep CJ-10 |aka = Jeep One-Tonner
Jeep J10 |image = Jeep CJ10.JPG |assembly = {{unbulleted list|United States: [[South Bend, Indiana]]|Mexico: [[Toluca, Mexico State]] ([[Vehículos Automotores Mexicanos]])}} |production = 1981-1985 |body_style = 2-door [[pickup truck]] |wheelbase = {{convert|119.8|in|mm|-1|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ifsja.org/forums/vb/showthread.php?t=71765|title=Australian Delivered CJ10 4x4 - International Full Size Jeep Association|author=|date=|website=www.ifsja.org|access-date=2017-12-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222052519/http://www.ifsja.org/forums/vb/showthread.php?t=71765|archive-date=2017-12-22|url-status = live}} |length = {{convert|191|in|mm|-1|abbr=on}} cab & chassis
{{convert|196|in|mm|-1|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gumtree.com.au/s-ad/mount-gravatt/cars-vans-utes/1983-cj10-jeep/1162966804|title=1983 CJ10 Jeep - Cars, Vans & Utes - Gumtree Australia Brisbane South East - Mount Gravatt - 1162966804|author=|date=|website=Gumtree|access-date=2017-12-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220085621/https://www.gumtree.com.au/s-ad/mount-gravatt/cars-vans-utes/1983-cj10-jeep/1162966804|archive-date=2017-12-20|url-status = live}} with the utility box and rear bumper |width = {{convert|68|in|mm|-1|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|72|in|mm|-1|abbr=on}} |weight = {{convert|4300|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |transmission = {{unbulleted list|three-speed [[TorqueFlite]] [[TorqueFlite#A727|A727]] automatic|4-speed ''[[Tremec]] T177'' manual}} |engine = {{unbulleted list|{{convert|151|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I4|{{convert|198|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} Nissan ''[[Nissan SD engine#SD33|SD33]]'' I6 diesel|{{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC I6}} }} The Jeep CJ-10 was a CJ-bodied [[pickup truck]] based on a heavily modified [[Jeep J-Series|Jeep J10]] pickup truck. Produced from 1981 to 1985, it was sold and designed for export markets, [[Australia]] in particular. They featured rectangular headlights mounted in the fenders and a ten-slot grille, where all other CJ Jeeps had a seven-slot grille. The CJ-10 could have either a hard or soft top. The truck could be equipped to handle either a {{convert|5900|lb|kg|abbr=on}} or {{convert|6700|lb|kg|abbr=on}} [[Gross vehicle weight rating|GVW]]. Three engines were offered; a {{convert|198|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} six-cylinder [[Nissan]]-built diesel engine, a {{convert|151|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} four-cylinder AMC-built engine, or a {{convert|258|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} six-cylinder AMC-built engine. The driveline was largely from the larger J series pickups, consisting of either a four-speed [[Tremec]] T177 manual transmission or a three-speed [[TorqueFlite]] A727 automatic transmission, a [[AMC and Jeep transmissions#New Process/New Venture|New Process 208]] transfer case, a semi-floating [[Dana 44]] front differential, and either a semi-floating Dana 44 or [[Dana 60]] rear differential, depending on GVW rating. Importation of the CJ-10 into Australia ended in 1985 with the drop of the [[Australian dollar#Value of the Australian dollar|Australian dollar's value]], causing the vehicle to be significantly more costly than its competitors.{{cite journal |last=Allen |first=Jim |title=The Elusive Jeep CJ-10 |url=http://www.fourwheeler.com/featuredvehicles/129_1210_the_elusive_jeep_cj_10/ |journal=Four Wheeler |date=October 2012 |accessdate=5 April 2013 |authorlink=Jim Allen (4x4 writer) |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203135826/http://www.fourwheeler.com/featuredvehicles/129_1210_the_elusive_jeep_cj_10/ |archive-date=3 February 2013 |url-status = live}} {{clear}} ==CJ-10A== {{Infobox automobile |name = Jeep CJ-10A |production = 1984-1986 |body_style = 2-door flightline aircraft tug |engine = {{convert|3.3|L|cuin|1|abbr=on}} Nissan ''[[Nissan SD engine#SD33|SD33]]'' [[Straight-six engine|I6]] [[Diesel engine|diesel]]}} The '''Jeep CJ-10A''' was a CJ-10-based flightline aircraft tug. Produced in Mexico from 1984 to 1986, it was used by the [[United States Air Force]] as an [[aircraft]]-pulling vehicle. It was a 4x2 bobtail design. About 2,300 were produced. {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Jeep CJ}} *[https://israeljeeps.co.il/%d7%92%d7%99%d7%a4-%d7%90%d7%a1%d7%a4%d7%a0%d7%95%d7%aa/%d7%a7%d7%98%d7%9c%d7%95%d7%92-%d7%92%d7%99%d7%a4/ Jeep] 1970 - 1986 sales & accessories brochures *{{imcdb vehicle|make=Jeep|model=CJ|Jeep CJ}} {{Jeep early timeline}} {{Jeep Car Timeline}} [[Category:Jeep platforms|CJ]] [[Category:Jeep vehicles|CJ]] [[Category:Kaiser Motors]] [[Category:Willys vehicles]] [[Category:AMC vehicles]] [[Category:American Motors]] [[Category:Mini sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Pickup trucks]] [[Category:Sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1944]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Cars powered by longitudinal 4-cylinder engines]]
