revision.text:
{{Infobox automobile | image = Jeep Forward Control.jpg | boxcolor = darkblue | name = Jeep Forward Control | manufacturer = [[Jeep]] | production = 1956–1965 | assembly = | class = [[Truck]] | body_style = | engine = {{unbulleted list|{{convert|134|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[Willys Hurricane engine#F134|Hurricane F4-134]]'' I4 (FC-150, FC-160)|{{unbulleted list|{{convert|226|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[Willys Hurricane engine#Super Hurricane|Super Hurricane]]'' I6 (FC-170, FC-170 DRW, FC-180)|{{unbulleted list|{{convert|272|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} ''[[Ford Y-block engine|Y-block]]'' V8 (FC-180, FC-190)}}}}}} | transmission= {{unbulleted list|3-speed ''[[Borg-Warner]] T-90'' [[Manual transmission|manual]]|4-speed ''Borg-Warner T-98'' manual (from 1958)|3-speed ''[[Cruise-O-Matic]]'' automatic (FC-180, FC-190)}} | layout=[[Front-engine design|Front engine]], [[four-wheel drive]] | predecessor = | successor = [[Jeep Gladiator (SJ)]] | wheelbase = {{unbulleted list|{{convert|81|in|0|abbr=on}} FC-150{{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1956_Jeep/1956_Jeep_FC_Brochure/1956%20Jeep%20FC%20150-02.html |title=1956 Jeep FC brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1959_Jeep/1959_Jeep_FC-150_Folder/1959%20Jeep%20FC-150-02.html |title=1959 Jeep FC-150 folder |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}|{{convert|93|in|0|abbr=on}} FC-160|{{convert|103|in|0|abbr=on}} FC-170, FC-170 DRW|{{convert|123.5|in|0|abbr=on}} FC-180|{{convert|150|in|0|abbr=on}} FC-190}} | length = {{Convert|147.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (FC-150){{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Jeep/1956_Jeep/1956_Jeep_FC_Brochure/1956%20Jeep%20FC%20150-05.html |title=1956 Jeep FC brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}}
{{convert|181.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (FC-170, FC-170 DRW) | height = | designer = [[Brooks Stevens]] }} The '''Jeep Forward Control''' is a [[truck]] that was produced by [[Kaiser Jeep|Willys Motors]], later named Kaiser Jeep, from 1956 to 1965. It was also assembled in other international markets. The layout featured a [[cab over]] (forward control) design. The Forward Control models were primarily marketed as work vehicles for corporate, municipal, military, as well as civilian use. Regular pickup box beds were standard, but customers were offered a large number of "Jeep approved" specialized bodies from outside suppliers. These ranged from simple flatbeds to complete [[tow truck]]s, [[dump truck]]s, and [[fire truck]]s. The vehicles were also manufactured under license in India and Spain. == Design == Willys produced utility vehicles that remained almost unchanged since 1947. As the marketplace grew more competitive in the 1950s, management developed a new range of modern cab and body trucks. Independent designer that was contracted by Willys since the 1940s, [[Brooks Stevens]], used styling cues from full-size cab-over-engine trucks for this new futuristic-looking space-efficient vehicle with the center grille panel made to imitate the classic seven-slot Jeep design.{{cite book|last=Foster |first=Patrick |title=The Story of Jeep|year=2004 |publisher=Krause Publications |isbn=9780873497350 |page=101 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpdUEVGU2toC&pg=PA101&dq=Brooks+Stevens+Jeep+forward+control |accessdate=2 March 2018}} The unconventional forward control layout and "helicopter look" of the cab was too unusual for mainstream buyers during that era, but they were successful in specialty markets that included airport service vehicles, tow trucks, and railroad crew trucks that could ride the rails.{{cite book|last=Foster |first=Patrick R. |title=Jeep: The History of America's Greatest Vehicle |year=2014 |publisher=Motorbooks |isbn=9780760345856 |page=68 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EwWpAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA68&lpg=PA68&dq=Jeep+Forward+Control+helicopter+look+too+unusual+for+mainstream |accessdate=2 March 2018}} Numerous versions of the Forward Control Jeeps were manufactured for general and specialized applications with 1957 being the top production with almost 10,000 vehicles built that year.{{cite book|last=Adamson |first=Glenn |author2=Milwaukee Art Museum |title=Industrial strength design: how Brooks Stevens shaped your world |year=2003 |publisher=Milwaukee Art Museum |isbn=9780262012072 |page=115 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7M5TAAAAMAAJ&q=Jeep.+A+wide+variety+of+these+cab-over-engine+vehicles+were+produced+1957+almost+ten+thousand |accessdate=2 March 2018}} Engineering was based on existing [[Jeep CJ|CJ-5]]. Power came from the [[Willys Hurricane engine|Hurricane]] F-head and L-head 4-cylinder engines. The updates in 1958 on both the FC-150 and 170 versions had attained a goal established by Willys engineers to design a versatile commercial vehicle in which the ratio of the vehicle's [[curb weight]] to its [[payload]] was 1 to 1.{{cite journal|title=Jeep Forward Control|journal=The SAE Journal |date=1958 |volume=66 |page=93 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=80FKAQAAIAAJ&q=Jeep+FC+150+and+170,+have+attained+a+goal+established+a+number+of+years+ago+by+Willys+engineers:+a+versatile+commercial+vehicle+in+which+the+ratio+of+curb+weight+of+the+vehicle+to+pay+load+is+1+to+1.+This+is+believed+to+be+the+lowest+ratio+in+the+U.+S.+truck+industry+today+for+a+standard+light-duty+commercial+vehicle |publisher=Society of Automotive Engineers |accessdate=2 March 2018}} According to the [[SAE International|Society of Automotive Engineers]] (SAE), this was regarded as the lowest ratio offered by domestic manufacturers at that time within the standard light-duty commercial vehicle segment. The FC layout offered advantages including a short turning radius and large cargo bed size given the compact overall length. Proposals included a "Forward Control Commuter" design that may have been among the earliest [[minivan]]-type vehicles. Three operational [[concept car]]s were built by [[:de:Stuttgarter Karosseriewerk Reutter|Reutter]] in [[Stuttgart]], West Germany. [[Brooks Stevens]] was also involved in the transformation of this truck platform into a passenger vehicle.[http://www.thefcconnection.com/the_commuter.htm The Commuter], retrieved on August 10, 2012. == FC-150 == [[File:Willys FC150 Truck 1963.jpg|thumb|FC-150 in Sweden]] Introduced in 1956, FC-150 models were based on the CJ-5 with its {{convert|81|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} wheelbase, but featuring a {{convert|78|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} long cargo box. This was a record-breaking six-foot length (with the tailgate up) load bed on a vehicle whose total {{convert|147.5|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} length was two inches shorter than the diminutive two-seat [[Nash Metropolitan]].{{cite journal|title=New Forward Control design |journal=The Saturday Evening Post |date=November 1956 |volume=229 |page=39 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3foeAQAAMAAJ&q=FC+150+Forward+Control+design+puts+a+record-breaking+74%22+pickup+box+on+an+81%22+wheelbase |accessdate=2 March 2018}}{{cite web|author=Auto editors of ''Consumer Guide'' |title=1957-1965 Jeep |url= https://auto.howstuffworks.com/1957-1965-jeep1.htm |website=HowStuffWorks |date=21 August 2007 |accessdate=2 March 2018}} The rugged design and go-anywhere capability included a claim that the FC could climb grades of up to 60% and reviews by ''[[Mechanix Illustrated]]'' highlighted the vehicle's toughness and surefootedness. In 1958, the FC-150 received a new, wider chassis. Its track was widened from {{convert|48|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} to {{convert|57|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}. A 1958 FC-150 concept featured an {{convert|83.5|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} wheelbase, a widened track (which made production), and the new T-98 4-speed manual transmission. This model had a gross weight of {{convert|5000|lb|kg|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}.[http://www.thefcconnection.com/willys_engineering_design_concepts.htm 1958 Product Engineering Design Concepts] == FC-170 == [[File:JeepFC-170.jpg|thumb|right|1957 [[Jeep]] model FC-170 with pickup cargo bed]] [[File:MHV Jeep Fire Engine 01.jpg|thumb|right|German fire engine van body Forward Control]] [[File:1961 Willys Jeep FC170 4WD ambulance rescue truck (14703513579).jpg|thumb|1961 FC-170 Australian rescue truck]] Introduced in 1957, FC-170 models had a {{convert|103|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} wheelbase with a {{convert|108|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} bed. This was achieved by the forward-control layout. A 1958 concept version of the FC-170 featured a {{convert|108|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} wheelbase. This was required to accommodate a new {{convert|272|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 engine (based on the [[Ford Y-block engine|Ford Y-block]]) with a new transfer case. A new 3-speed automatic transmission (based on the Ford [[Cruise-O-Matic]]) was only available with the inline-6 due to possible driveshaft angle issues. A T-98 4-speed manual was available with both engines. This model had a gross weight of {{convert|7000|lb|kg|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}. == FC-170 DRW == This is a {{convert|1|ST|t|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} dual-wheeled rear axle (dually) model with a {{convert|120|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} load bed. These models have gross weights of {{convert|8000|lb|kg|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} or {{convert|9000|lb|kg|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}. == FC-180 == The FC-180 was shown in concept form on paper in a 1957 Willys company brochure titled "1958 Projects - Product Engineering". It was essentially a lengthened FC-170 DRW (wheelbase increased from 103 in to 123.5 in). Features included a 150 in flatbed, the {{convert|226|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} "Super Hurricane" inline-6 or the {{convert|272|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 as available engines, and the T-98 4-speed manual or 3-speed automatic as available transmissions. This model had a gross weight of {{convert|10000|lb|kg|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}. == FC-190 == The FC-190 was also shown in concept form in 1957. It featured a {{convert|150|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} wheelbase, a {{convert|202|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} flat bed and tandem dually axles. The T-98 manual transmission was standard with the automatic as an option. No six-cylinder option was offered; standard was the {{convert|272|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8. The FC-190 would use components from the FC-170 and FC-180 to keep costs down. This model had a gross weight of {{convert|16000|lb|kg|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}. == Production == The FC Jeeps were exhibited to Jeep [[Car dealership|dealers]] in a closed-circuit telecast on November 29, 1956, and were on display for the public at the December 1956 National Automobile Show in [[New York City]]. The FC-150 went on sale at dealer showrooms on December 12, 1956. The initial response to the four-wheel drive FC Jeeps was favorable. Their best sales year came in 1957, when 9,738 trucks were sold. After the introduction of the FC-170 in 1957, FC-150 sales dropped to 1,546 units in 1959, before rebounding to 4,925 in 1960. Brooks Stevens made a rendering around 1960 for a possible facelift for the FC-series.{{cite web|last=Strohl |first=Daniel |title=Wide-Trac, en Espanol?|url= https://www.hemmings.com/blog/2011/08/22/wide-trac-en-espanol/ |publisher=Hemmings |date=22 August 2011 |accessdate=2 March 2018}} The FC models did not become the big sellers that Willys had hoped. Total production in nine years was just over 30,000 units. The FC line was discontinued in 1964.[http://www.carlislemediasite.com/content.asp?ArticleID=48 Dieffenbach, Mike. A Brief History of the Forward Control Trucks of the Late 20th Century, May 2002] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014031002/http://carlislemediasite.com/content.asp?ArticleID=48 |date=2007-10-14 }}, retrieved on October 30, 2007. == Military variants == Four dedicated military variants of the FC-170 were manufactured for the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps, under a 1964 contract.{{cite web|title=Willys Forward Control Military Trucks |url= http://olive-drab.com/idphoto/id_photos_willys_fc.php |website=Olive Drab |accessdate=2 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=History & General Information |url= http://www.thefcconnection.com/history_&_general_information.htm |website=The FC Connection |accessdate=2 March 2018}} Production is estimated to have been between 400 and 700 units, mostly the M677 four-door pickups. A 1963 analysis done by Jeep, concluded that the militarized FC-170s compared favorably to the aging [[Dodge M37]], at least for ''behind'' the front-line service.[http://thefcconnection.com/Military%20History%20&%20Info/Military%20History%20&%20Info/Comparison%20Study...%20%20FC170%20Cerlist%20Pickup%20vs.%20M37.pdf Comparison Study... FC170 Cerlist Pickup vs. M37.pdf], Kaiser Jeep Corporation, 1 May 1963 The XM-676 prototype had a 50% larger cargo cube, could carry 12 troops in the back instead of eight in the M-37, had a 700-pound greater load rating, and yielded more than twice the mileage, but Jeep was likely more focused on landing the contract for the [[Kaiser Jeep M715|M-715 trucks]] that replaced the M-37. The official operator's and service manuals were written and published by Kaiser Jeep – not by the army. The general government description of the vehicles was ''''Jeep' Truck, Diesel engine, 7000-pound GVW, 4x4''', with the variants named: {{cite book |author= |title='Jeep' Truck, Diesel engine, 7000-pound GVW, 4x4 (SM-1020) |url=http://thefcconnection.com/Military%20History%20&%20Info/Military%20History%20&%20Info/Jeep%20M677%20Service%20manual%20.pdf |location=[[Toledo, Ohio]] |publisher=[[Kaiser Jeep]] Corporation |page=1 |date=May 1964 |work=Service Manual}} * '''M676 Truck, Cargo Pickup''' — a modified version of the commercial FC-170 pickup * '''M677 Truck, Cargo Pickup w/4 Dr. Cab''' — a four-door crew-cab pickup with a canopy over the bed * '''M678 Truck, Carry All''' — a van-body FC-170 with windows, and three cabin doors, and * '''M679 Truck, Ambulance''' — a van-body FC-170 with two cabin doors and no further sidewindows, fitted as an ambulance There were notable mechanical differences with the civilian market vehicles. First of all, the [[Marines|Marine Corps]] variants of the FC-170s were powered by a different engine – a Cerlist {{convert|85|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} three-cylinder {{convert|170|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} two-stroke diesel. The engine was mated with a three-speed T-90A transmission and a model 18 transfer case. Other changes included a reinforced frame, 24-volt electrical system, as well as limited-slip Spicer 44 front and Spicer 53 rear axles.{{cite web|last=Allen |first=Jim |title=Forward Control 101: The M-Series |url= http://www.fourwheeler.com/features/1611-forward-control-101-the-m-series/ |website=Four Wheeler |date=28 November 2016 |accessdate=2 March 2018 |authorlink=Jim Allen (4x4 writer)}} == Foreign market models== Numerous versions of FC models (most not available in the domestic market) were manufactured in many other nations under collaboration agreements with successive owners of Jeep: [[Willys|Willys-Overland]], [[Kaiser Jeep]], and [[American Motors Corporation]] (AMC). === India === [[File:Mahindra FJ-470 (or 460) mini bus in Madurai.jpg|thumb|Mahindra FJ-470 or 460 with a mini bus body]] [[Mahindra & Mahindra Limited]] in Bombay ([[Mumbai]]), India began its vehicle business in 1947 by assembling [[complete knock down]] (CKD) Jeeps.[http://www.mahindra.com/Heritage/History.htmll Official Mahindra history], retrieved on October 30, 2007. It started FC-150 production in [[India]] in 1965 and later expanded the model range for the [[domestic market]] to include the FC-170, as well as its own intermediate sized FC-160. The FC-160 (and later FJ-160) uses a {{convert|93|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} wheelbase. The pick-up box was by Mahindra and other bodies were available. The "[[Cowling|cowl]] and [[chassis]] only" FC-160 model was popular during the 1970 s for conversion into [[Minibus|mini-buses]], [[ambulance]]s, and other vehicles. Most have the basic front face of the FC. Manufacture of the Mahindra FC-160 pickup truck ended in the summer of 1999. The FC-260 Diesel light truck was introduced in 1975. Currently, Mahindra's four-wheel drive FJ-460 (introduced in 1983) and two-wheel drive FJ-470 van or mini-bus vehicles retain the grille arrangement of the original Forward Control. These vehicles can accommodate from 11 to 15 passengers plus the driver.{{cite web | url = http://jeepfc.www5.50megs.com/fc160/fc-160.htm | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070701084304/http://jeepfc.www5.50megs.com/fc160/fc-160.htm | title = Forward Control 160? | archivedate = 2007-07-01 | work = The Jeep Forward Control Page | last = Hornberger | first = Daniel }} === Spain === [[File:Spain-JeepSV.jpg|thumb|right|The Jeep "SV" line of Forward Control vans made in Spain. Note the [[panel van|panel]] version of the van and the [[crew cab]] of the [[pickup truck|pickup]].]] {{main article|es:Jeep-Viasa SV-430}} In the 1960s, Kaiser-Willys licensed [[Vehículos Industriales y Agrícolas, S.A|Vehículos Industriales y Agrícolas]] (VIASA) of Zaragoza in Aragon to build Jeeps in [[Spain]].{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4TIikXGZdcEC&pg=PA127&dq=The+third+company,+VIASA+made+jeeps+under+licence+from+American+Motors |title=The Multinational Motor Industry |first=George |last=Maxcy |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=2013 |isbn= 9780415657662 |accessdate=24 June 2014}} Beginning in 1970, the "SV" line of commercial trucks were built using the Commando 4x4 Jeep chassis, just like the FC models in the United States.{{cite web|url= http://cj3b.info/World/Spain.html |title=Los Jeeps: Made in Spain |first=Derek |last=Redmond |publisher=The CJ3B Page |date=12 February 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2014}} However, the [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberian]] models were unlike any Jeeps produced anywhere else and featured indigenously developed body designs.{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpdUEVGU2toC&pg=PA15&dq=In+Spain,+Vehiculos+Industriales+Y+Agricolas+(V.I.A.S.A.)+built+unique |page=15 |title=The Story of Jeep |first=Patrick R. |last=Foster |publisher=Krause Publications |year=2004 |isbn=9780873497350 |edition=Second |accessdate=24 June 2014}} The SV line included the Campeador (one-ton pickup), Duplex (double cab pickup), Furgon (one-ton van), and the Toledo (9-seat luxury passenger van). Two engines were available: the [[Willys Hurricane engine|Super Hurricane]] in-line six petrol and a [[List of Perkins engines|Perkins]] 4-cylinder [[Diesel engine|diesel]]. During the late 1970s, VIASA was absorbed by [[Ebro trucks]], a division of Motor Ibérica. Production of the full SV line continued until 1985, which also included versions for the Spanish army.{{cite web|last=Cossard |first=Hubert |title=Viasa et Ebro Jeep SV 1970-1985 |url= http://www.cherokee-fr.com/~jeepfamily/Europe/Espagne/SV/EbroSV.htm| website=www.cherokee-fr.com |date=30 September 2010 |language=fr |accessdate=2 March 2018}} Nissan took complete control of Ebro in 1987 and the company was named Nissan Motor Ibérica. == Wide-track concept == Kaiser contracted [[Crown Coach Corporation]], a bus manufacturer, to build a "Wide-Trac" forward control [[concept car]] that combines elements of the original Jeep FC trucks, the VIASA SV pickup, and Brooks Stevens' 1960 proposed facelift.{{cite web|last=Strohl |first=Daniel |title=Kaiser’s Crown (-built Jeep) |url= https://www.hemmings.com/blog/index.php/2011/06/28/kaisers-crown-built-jeep/ |publisher=Hemmings |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=2 March 2018}} == Notes == {{Reflist}} == References == * {{cite web | author = Auto Editors of ''Consumer Guide'' | title = 1956 Kaiser-Jeep FC-150 | publisher = howstuffworks.com | url = http://auto.howstuffworks.com/1953-1956-jeep4.htm | date = 2007-12-27 | accessdate = 2010-05-01 }} * {{cite journal|last=Foster |first=Patrick R. |title=1957-65 Jeep Forward Control Trucks: Too Far Forward? |journal=Collectible Automobile |volume=24 |number=1 |pages=42–63 |date=June 2007}} == External links == {{commons category|Jeep Forward Control}} * [http://www.thefcconnection.com The FC Connection], retrieved on September 14, 2010. {{Jeep early timeline}} [[Category:Jeep vehicles|Forward Control]] [[Category:Pickup trucks]] [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Cab over vehicles]] [[Category:Vehicles introduced in 1956]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:Kaiser Motors]] [[Category:Willys vehicles]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Trucks of the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|UAZ Patriot}} {{Infobox automobile |image = Jeep Patriot.jpg |name = Jeep Patriot |aka =[[Jeep Compass]] |manufacturer = [[DaimlerChrysler]] (2007)
[[Chrysler LLC]] (2007–2009)
[[Chrysler Group LLC]] (2009–2014)
[[FCA US LLC]] (2014–2017) |production =2006–2016 |model_years = 2007–2017 |layout = [[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|Transverse front-engine, front-wheel drive]] / [[Front-engine, all-wheel-drive layout|all-wheel drive]] |class =[[Compact SUV]] |body_style = 4-door [[compact SUV]] |platform = [[Mitsubishi GS platform|Chrysler PM/MK platform]] |assembly = United States: [[Belvidere, Illinois]], ([[Belvidere Assembly]]) |related = {{unbulleted list| [[Mitsubishi Lancer]] | [[Jeep Compass]] | [[Dodge Caliber]] | [[Mitsubishi Outlander]] | [[Dodge Avenger]] | [[Chrysler Sebring]] }} |engine = {{unbulleted list| 2.0 L ''[[World Gasoline Engine#2.0|World]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]] (gasoline) | 2.0 L ''[[List of Volkswagen Group diesel engines#2.0 R4 TDI PD 47-103kW|VW]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]] ([[turbocharger|t/c]] diesel) | 2.2 L ''[[Mercedes-Benz OM651 engine|OM651]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]] ([[turbocharger|t/c]] diesel) | 2.4 L ''[[World Gasoline Engine#2.4|World]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]] (gasoline) }} |transmission = {{unbulleted list| 5-speed ''[[Magna International|Magna]] T355'' [[manual transmission|manual]] | 6-speed ''[[Aisin]] BG6'' manual (Diesel only) | 6-speed ''[[Hyundai Motor Company|Hyundai]] 6F24'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] | [[Continuously variable transmission|CVT]] ''[[Jatco]] JF011E'' automatic }} |wheelbase = {{convert|2635|mm|in|1|abbr=on|disp=flip}} |ftrack = {{convert|59.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |rtrack = {{convert|59.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{unbulleted list| 2007–09: {{convert|64.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | 2010–present: {{convert|65.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} |width = {{convert|69.1|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length = {{convert|173.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |successor = [[Jeep Renegade (BU)]]
[[Jeep Compass|Jeep Compass (MP)]]
[[Jeep Cherokee (KL)]] (Russia) }} The '''Jeep Patriot''' (MK74) is a front-engine five-door [[compact SUV|compact]] [[crossover SUV]] manufactured and marketed by [[Jeep]], having debuted with the [[Jeep Compass]] in April 2006 at the [[New York Auto Show#2007|New York Auto Show]] for the 2007 model year.{{cite journal|editor-last=Fritz |editor-first=Dariene |title=Jeep 4x4 Capability – Patriot |journal=Automotive Engineering International |date=2007|volume=115 |issue=5 |pages=34–36 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=V1xKAQAAIAAJ&q=2007+Jeep+Patriot |publisher=SAE International |accessdate=31 March 2018}} Both cars, as well as [[Dodge Caliber]] shared the [[Mitsubishi GS platform|GS platform]], differentiated by their styling and marketing, with the Patriot exclusively offering a four-wheel drive system, marketed as Freedom Drive II. The Patriot was manufactured at [[Chrysler]]'s [[Belvidere, Illinois]] assembly plant alongside the Compass.{{cite press release |url=http://www.worldcarfans.com/10612215415/all-new-2007-jeep-patriot-production-launched |title=All-new 2007 Jeep Patriot Production Launched |date=21 December 2006 |publisher=worldcarfans.com |accessdate=24 January 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201151249/http://www.worldcarfans.com/10612215415/all-new-2007-jeep-patriot-production-launched |archivedate=1 February 2014 }} Although the model was still selling well even as it was essentially unchanged as it entered its 11th model year, production ended with the 2017 model year.{{cite web|last=Wendler |first=Andrew |title=Jeep Patriot Reviews |url= https://www.caranddriver.com/jeep/patriot |publisher=Car and Driver |accessdate=31 March 2018}} ==Design== [[File:Jeep Patriot black rr.jpg|thumb|right|Pre-facelift Jeep Patriot Limited (Europe)]] [[File:Jeep Patriot interior.jpg|thumb|right|Interior]] In the U.S. the Patriot uses either the 2.0 L or 2.4 L ''[[Chrysler World engine|World]]'' gasoline [[Straight-4|I4]] engine. Both front-wheel drive and [[four-wheel drive]] are available. The Patriot features two four-wheel drive systems both of which are electronically controlled. The basic four-wheel drive system is called [[Freedom Drive I]]. This system is a full-time front-wheel-drive based 4WD/AWD system that is front-wheel-drive when it has traction, but can automatically put up to 50% power to the rear wheels, the ECC (Electronically controlled clutch located on the rear differential)can be locked in 50–50 below a certain speed. This "locking" isn't a true lock and just requests the ECC be locked more than in the regular AWD mode. The ECC clutch is pulsed during turns to avoid the system from binding the drivetrain. The other system, called [[Freedom Drive II]], is based on Freedom Drive I, but by using the vehicle's [[continuously variable transmission|CVT]] transmission it is capable of a 19:1 gear reduction simulating a low range usually found in vehicles with dedicated transfer cases. This 19:1 "crawl" ratio is achieved with a much lower (numerically higher) rear differential gear compared to non Freedom Drive II vehicles. The 2.4 L ''[[Global Engine Manufacturing Alliance|GEMA]]'' [[straight-4|I4]] is an option for the 4X2 model Patriot. For Europe and Australia, a 2.0 L (1968 cc; 120 cid; 140ps) [[Volkswagen]]-manufactured [[diesel engine]] is fitted along with a 6-speed manual gearbox. All EU cars are fitted as standard with four wheel drive and a version of the Freedom Drive System that tuned differently from the U.S. versions, but with similar capability to FDII with brake traction control and three switchable electronic stability control and traction control settings for on or off-road use. The Patriot won 2007 Green 4x4 Award and the 2008 4x4 of the Year in the UK. The Patriot uses a [[continuously variable transmission]] equipped with a [[Jeep four wheel drive systems#Freedom Drive|four wheel drive system]], marketed as Freedom Drive II, capable of holding the lowest ratio the CVT can reach, in lieu of a traditional two-speed transfer case. The Patriot carries Jeep's "Trail Rated" badging. {| class=wikitable |- !Model!!Engine!!Power!!Torque!!Transmission |- |Sport||rowspan=2|2.4 L ''[[Chrysler World engine#2.4|World]]'' [[Straight-4|I4]]||rowspan=2| {{convert|172|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} ||rowspan=2| {{convert|165|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} ||5-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]] |- |Limited||[[Continuously variable transmission|CVT]] |} ==Models== The Patriot is offered in three basic models with several additional options available: '''Sport:'''
-Manual Roll-Up Windows and Manual Door Locks
-Vinyl-Wrapped Steering Wheel and Dual-Note Horn
-Cruise Control (Not all years)
-Anti-Theft Ignition
-Vinyl (Later Cloth) Seating Surfaces
-Manual Front Bucket Seats
-Folding Rear Bench Seat
-Heater and Fan Blower
-2.0L I4 Engine (4X2) or 2.4L I4 Engine (4X4)
-5-Speed Manual Transmission
-Tinted Windows
-16" All-Season Tires
-16" Styled Steel Wheels
-AM/FM Stereo w/ Single-Disc CD Player (Later CD-MP3 Player) and Four Speakers '''Latitude:'''
-Power Windows w/ One-Touch Driver's Auto Down Feature and Power Door Locks
-SIRIUS-XM Satellite Radio (optional accessory)
-Leather-Wrapped Steering Wheel
-Keyless Entry w/ Panic Feature and Security System
-Cloth Seating Surfaces
-Air Conditioning w/ Manual Control
-17" All-Season Tires
-17" Alloy Wheels -Rear Dome Light Flashlighthttp://www.justforjeeps.com/dolifl.html '''Limited:'''
-Cloth (Later Leather) Seating Surfaces
-Power Front Driver's Seat
-Power Sunroof
-U Connect Hands-Free Bluetooth Telephone System ==Electric version== At the 2009 [[North American International Auto Show]] in [[Detroit]], the Jeep Patriot was added to Chrysler's [[Envi (automobile)|ENVI]] lineup. As with the previously announced Jeep Wrangler EV, the Jeep Patriot EV is an [[Range-extended vehicle|extended-range electric vehicle]] (EREV, also called a [[plug-in hybrid vehicle]]), capable of traveling {{convert|40|mi|km|0|abbr=on}} solely on battery power and up to {{convert|400|mi|km|0|abbr=on}} on a single tank of gas.{{cite web|url= http://jalopnik.com/5128342/jeep-patriot-ev-a-conceptual-electric-missile-from-chrysler |title=Jeep Patriot EV: A Conceptual Electric Missile From Chrysler |first=Matt |last=Hardigree |publisher=Jalopnik |date=10 January 2009 |accessdate=24 January 2014}} However, Chrysler's new partner [[Fiat SpA]] disbanded the ENVI division in November 2009, and removed the three ENVI models from its 5-year plan for Chrysler.{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-BusinessofGreen/idUSTRE5A605N20091107 |title=Chrysler dismantles electric car plans under Fiat |first=Kevin |last=Kroliki |date=6 November 2009 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=24 January 2014}} There have been no announced plans to continue with the electric version. ==2011 facelift== [[File:2013 Jeep Patriot Sport (14260842071).jpg|thumb|left|2011 facelift]] [[File:Jeep Patriot 2.2 CRD Limited (Facelift) – Heckansicht, 26. Juni 2011, Düsseldorf.jpg|thumb|right|2011 facelift]] The Patriot received minor interior and exterior upgrades for 2011. The front fog lamps were shrunken and relocated, and the "Patriot" lettering on the rear bumper was removed and replaced with a more traditional rear bumper. Three trims were offered in the US: Sport, Latitude, and Limited (which replaced the earlier Latitude X). In Canada, North Edition replaced the Latitude trim with slightly different equipment. In the EU, four trims were offered: Sport, Sport Plus, Limited, and an Overland version. In the EU market, the 2.0 L Volkswagen PD Diesel Engine was replaced by a 2.2 L Mercedes-Benz Twin-Cam Common Rail Diesel engine delivering {{convert|163|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. For 2011, a 70th Anniversary Edition model was offered to commemorate the Jeep history. It was based on the Sport model with special olive or beige interior colors, unique alloy wheels, a nine-speaker [[Boston Acoustics]] premium sound system with [[subwoofer]] and fold-down lift gate speakers, [[Sirius XM Radio]], a leather-wrapped [[steering wheel]], [[leather]] [[seats]], heated front seats, and other features. This model was available from May to October 2011. For 2012 only, an Altitude Edition model, based on the Sport model, was offered. It featured a black leather upholstery, special black-finished alloy wheels, a nine-speaker sound system, Sirius XM Radio, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, heated front seats, and black-painted exterior accents. This model started production in May 2012, and was only available for a few months. For the 2013 model year, a Freedom Edition model, based on the Sport model, was offered to commemorate Jeep's commitment to the [[U.S. Army]] and [[military]], as well to commemorate all of the [[soldiers]] who have served. It has a special [[star]] hood [[decal]], power leather seats, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, Sirius XM Radio, and dark-finished alloy wheels. This model features Commando Green Metallic exterior paint that is not available on other 2013 Jeep Patriots. The Jeep Patriot underwent many changes in trims or models for the 2014 model year; however, 2014 was the first model year that Freedom Drive 1 Patriots came with a Hyundai 6-speed automatic transmission instead of the CVT. ==Discontinuation== 2017 was the last year for the Patriot, but production was discontinued in December 2016 (with the remainder of the fleet marketed as "2017" and sold until stock depletion).{{Cite web|title = It’s Official: Jeep Wrangler Pickup Is Coming in 2017|url = http://blog.caranddriver.com/its-official-jeep-wrangler-pickup-is-coming-in-2017/|website = blog.caranddriver.com|access-date = 2016-01-13}}{{Cite web|title = Jeep confirms pickup; new SUV to be Patriot or Compass|url = http://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/detroit-auto-show/2016/01/11/jeep-confirms-pickup-new-suv-patriot-compass/78648152/|website = Detroit News|access-date = 2016-01-13}} Both Patriot and first-generation Jeep Compass were replaced by second-generation Compass. ==Safety== ===Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS)=== {| class="wikitable" |+[[Insurance Institute for Highway Safety|IIHS]] scores{{cite web |url=http://www.iihs.org/ratings/ratingsbyseries.aspx?id=635 |title=IIHS-HLDI: Jeep Patriot |publisher=Iihs.org |accessdate=2013-03-22 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318003940/http://www.iihs.org/ratings/ratingsbyseries.aspx?id=635 |archivedate=2013-03-18 }} |- |Moderate overlap frontal offset||Good |- |Small overlap frontal offset||Poor{{cite web|url=http://www.iihs.org/ratings/rating.aspx?id=1814&seriesid=635 |title=2012 Jeep Patriot Small SUV – Top Safety Pick |publisher=Insurance Institute for Highway Safety |date= |accessdate=24 January 2014}} |- |Side impact||Good* |- |Roof strength||Good |} *2007–2013 models with additional optional side airbags. revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2010}} {{Infobox automobile |image = Jeep-dj5.jpg |name = Jeep DJ |aka = Mail Jeep |manufacturer = [[Willys Motors]] (1955–1962)
[[Kaiser Jeep]] (1963–1970)
[[American Motors]] (1970)
[[AM General]] (1971–1984) |production = 1955–1984 |class = [[Truck]] |body_style = 3-door commercial vehicle |layout = [[Front-engine, rear-wheel drive layout|FR layout]] |platform = [[Jeep CJ]] |engine = Various |transmission = Various manual and automatic |wheelbase = {{convert|80|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} - Most |length = |width = |height = |weight = {{convert|3400|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} |related = [[Jeep CJ]] |successor = [[Grumman LLV]], [[Jeep Wrangler#JK Wrangler Unlimited|Wrangler Unlimited]] }} [[File:1965-Willys Jeep Gala Surrey pink.jpg|thumb|right|1965 Surrey Gala]] [[File:1964 Jeep Surrey Gala at Union Park DSM IA.jpg|thumb|right|1964 Surrey Gala]] The '''Jeep DJ''' (also known as the '''Dispatcher''') was a [[2WD|two-wheel-drive]] variant of the [[4WD|four-wheel drive]] [[Jeep CJ|CJ]] series. Production started in 1955 by [[Willys Motors|Willys]], which was renamed [[Kaiser Jeep]] in 1963. In 1970, [[American Motors]] (AMC) purchased Kaiser’s money-losing Jeep operations and established [[AM General]], a [[wholly owned subsidiary]] that built the DJ through 1983. ==DJ-3A== The DJ-3A was introduced in 1955. It used the body style of the older [[Jeep CJ#CJ-3A|CJ-3A]], along with the [[Willys Go Devil engine|L-134]] engine. Unlike the CJ-3A, it came with either a [[Manual transmission#Column-mounted shifter|column shift]] or floor shift three-speed Borg-Warner T-96 manual transmission. It was offered with many different body options including a soft top, hard top, or even a full van body. One model was a postal delivery vehicle with the driver's position on the right side for mail box delivery[https://books.google.com/books?id=nNwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA154&dq=1954+Popular+Mechanics+January&hl=en&sa=X&ei=af4kT9LXBIiKgwfB_Iy1Dw&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q&f=true "Jeep For Mail Carriers Mounts Steering Wheel on Right Side."] ''Popular Mechanics'', March 1954, p. 154, bottom of page. In early 1959, Willys introduced the '''Jeep Gala''' to the export markets and uses desiring the nimble size and open bodywork, but no need for four wheel-drive.{{cite book |page=[https://archive.org/details/jeepcolorhistory00stev/page/57 57] |url=https://archive.org/details/jeepcolorhistory00stev |url-access=registration |quote=jeep gala. |title=Jeep Color History |first=Steve |last=Statham |publisher=MBI Publishing |year=2002 |isbn=978-0-7603-0636-9 |accessdate=12 November 2011}} This model gained popularity as a "fun car" at [[resort]]s in [[Hawaii]], [[Mexico]], and islands in the [[Caribbean]] area. It was finished in pink, green, or blue and trimmed with matching white striped fabric, as well as with [[Fringe (trim)|fringe]] on its top. In fall of 1959, a similar model called the '''Jeep Surrey''' was introduced in the US market. The primary target market were resort hotels and vacation centers.{{cite book |page=102 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpdUEVGU2toC&pg=PA109&dq=Jeep+Surrey |title=The Story of Jeep |first=Patrick R. |last=Foster |publisher=Krause Publications|year=2004 |isbn= 978-0-87349-735-0 |accessdate=12 November 2011}} It also served as a low-cost rental vehicle for their guests. The Surrey came with a standard striped fabric top, as well as a matching fabric cover for what was advertised as a "[[Continental tire]] mount."{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AnQiAQAAMAAJ&q=jeep+surrey+Continental+tire |title=Pink Jeep (advertisement) |journal=The New Yorker |year=1959 |volume=35 |accessdate=12 November 2011}} ==DJ-5 and DJ-6== The DJ-3A was replaced by the [[right hand drive]] DJ-5 '''Dispatcher 100''' in 1965. It was based on the [[Jeep CJ#CJ-5|CJ-5]] and used the [[Willys Hurricane engine|Hurricane]] and [[Buick V6 engine#Dauntless|Dauntless]] engines. A {{convert|20|in|0|adj=on}} longer [[wheelbase]] '''DJ-6''' model was built from 1965 to 1973 alongside the [[Jeep CJ#CJ-6|CJ-6]]. ==DJ-5A through DJ-5M== The DJ-5A was introduced in 1967, beginning the lettering system indicating changes within the series. The DJ-5A (Kaiser Co.) used a standard CJ front end, with a four-cylinder [[Chevrolet Nova]] {{convert|153|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} engine and two-speed [[Powerglide]] automatic transmission, with a T-handle shifter located on the floor next to the driver's seat. The main body was a single unit, resembling the earlier Jeep when equipped with the metal Extreme Cold Weather Enclosure hard top. The models used by the United States Post Office had right-hand drive (without power steering), and were built in a lighter, less durable design than the standard Jeep. These changes included the use of C-channel frame rails (as opposed to the box rails of the CJ-5) and, while the hood was the same dimensions as (and interchangeable with) the CJ, it did not have the reinforced design of the original. Also, the standard configuration had only a driver's seat and a letter tray installed. This decreased curb weight, combined with different leaf springs than other models, allowed carrying more cargo weight behind the driver. The metal side doors were also designed to slide open and closed, and could be locked open while driving. They were supported by ball bearings, which ran in a channel just under the rain gutter, and a plastic retainer ran in a small channel along the body. A worn, damaged or lost retainer would allow the door to swing outward, fail to engage the rubber stop on the rear bumper, and slide all of the way off of the channel (and the vehicle). A single, hinged rear door gave access from floor to the bottom of the hard top, and was the width of the open area between the wheel wells. There were no cutouts in the body for the rear wheels, which made tire changes more difficult, as even when the frame was jacked well off the ground, the axle did not fall enough for the tire to clear the body. The DJ-5A used standard 15-inch passenger car tires, with no provision for carrying a spare. While the front bumper was of the standard CJ design (though thinner and lighter than the original), the rear bumper was a unique design, a single stamped part which ran the full width of the vehicle. At each end was a rubber stopper for the sliding doors. The 10-gallon fuel tank was under the rear body, just ahead of the bumper. In 1971, a unique five-slot grille without turn signals that was used only on postal Jeeps was introduced. The 1971 model actually has the grille extend past the front of the hood edge. This allowed more room for the [[AMC Straight-6 engine]] and radiator. Like the DJ-5A, while resembling the CJ series, these were built as a completely enclosed, [[rear-wheel drive]] vehicle, with sliding side doors (which could be opened while driving), and a swinging rear door. Most models only had the driver's seat and a mail tray where the second seat would normally be located. One improvement over earlier Jeeps was mounting the rear springs outside of the frame rails, thus providing greater stability for the vehicle with its top-heavy enclosed cargo area, especially at highway speeds. Most models were also equipped with a [[limited slip differential]] and a heavy-duty steering gearbox. Other improvements include a vent in the roof and cut-outs around the rear tires. AM General used a variety of powerplants during production. DJ production was ended in 1984 with the DJ-5M, which used the {{convert|150|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC straight-4 engine]]. ==DJ-5E Electruck== American Motors experimented with [[electric vehicle]]s and starting in 1974 mass-produced the DJ-5E, a rear-wheel drive electric delivery van, also known as the '''Electruck'''.{{cite book|title=Department of the Interior and related agencies appropriations for 1979|year=1978|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Joq2AAAAIAAJ&q=DJ-5E+Electruck&dq=DJ-5E+Electruck|author1=Committee on Appropriations |author2=House of Representatives |author3=Ninety-fifth Congress |author4=second session |accessdate=26 December 2010|page=343}} Similar in appearance and in most of its dimensions, the DJ-5E was powered by a set of two 27-volt lead-acid batteries with a 54-volt {{convert|30|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} compound wound DC motor with electronic regulation made by [[Gould Electronics]].{{cite book| author=Automobile club d'Italia|title = World Cars 1977|publisher=Herald Books|year=1977|isbn= 978-0-910714-09-9 |page=34}} The U.S. Postal Service purchased 352 vehicles for the use in cities with serious air pollution.{{cite book |last=Hyde |first=Charles K. |title=Storied Independent Automakers: Nash, Hudson, and American Motors|publisher=Wayne State University Press |year=2009 |page=222 |isbn=978-0-8143-3446-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PerGbKxOPZYC&pg=PA222&dq=DJ-5E+Electruck|accessdate=26 December 2010 }} The Electruck was capable of cruising at {{convert|33|mph|abbr=on}} with a range of {{convert|29|mi|km|abbr=on}} with 20% of its battery power still remaining in reserve. ==Wrangler Unlimited== The [[Jeep Wrangler#JK Wrangler Unlimited|Wrangler Unlimited]] is currently available in right-hand drive for [[USPS]] delivery in rural areas of [[North America]]. These have replaced Jeep DJs for the USPS role.{{Citation needed|date=October 2019}} ==Model numbers== *DJ-3A (1955–65): {{convert|134|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Willys Go Devil engine|Willys Go Devil]] straight-4 L-head engine, three-speed manual *DJ-5 (1965–67): {{convert|134|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Willys Hurricane engine|Willys Hurricane]] straight-4 F-head engine, three-speed manual *DJ-5A (1968–70): {{convert|153|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} Chevy Nova [[Chevrolet 153 4-cylinder engine|straight-4]], two-speed [[Powerglide]] automatic *DJ-5B (1970–72): {{convert|232|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC Straight-6 engine]], BorgWarner T-35 three-speed automatic *DJ-5C (1973–74): {{convert|232|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC Straight-6 engine, T-35 or M-11 automatic *DJ-5D (1975–76): {{convert|232|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC Straight-6 engine, 727 [[TorqueFlite]] automatic *DJ-5E (1976): ''Electruck'' Electric *DJ-5F (1977–78): {{convert|232|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} or {{convert|258|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC Straight-6 engine, 727 TorqueFlite automatic *DJ-5G (1979): [[AMC Engines#Audi.2FVW 121|AMC (Audi)]] {{convert|121|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} straight-4, 904 TorqueFlite automatic or {{convert|232|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} or {{convert|258|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} AMC Straight-6 engine, 727 TorqueFlite automatic *DJ-5L (1982): [[GM Iron Duke engine]] {{convert|151|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} straight-4, Chrysler 904 transmission *DJ-5M (1983–84): {{convert|150|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC straight-4 engine]], Chrysler 904 transmission ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Jeep DJ}} *[http://www.facebook.com/groups/104313209606221/ Jeep DJ - Postal Jeep Facebook community] *[http://www.postal-jeep.com/ Postal Jeep Homepage] *[http://www.jeeptech.com/engine/ Jeep Engine Specs] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080210183807/http://www.film.queensu.ca/cJ3B/Siblings/Dispatcher.html The Dispatcher Jeeps page] {{Jeep early timeline}} {{Jeep Car Timeline}} [[Category:Jeep vehicles|DJ]] [[Category:Historic electric vehicles]] [[Category:Vehicles introduced in 1955]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:1970s cars]] [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:Kaiser Motors]] [[Category:Willys vehicles]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:United States Postal Service]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]]

{{short description|American car model}} {{For|the unrelated but Jeep-based vehicle produced by Mahindra|Mahindra Commander}} {{see also|Studebaker Commander}} {{Infobox automobile | image = Jeep-Commander.jpg | caption = | name = Jeep Commander | assembly = {{ubl | Austria (XH): [[Graz]] ([[Magna Steyr]])|United States: [[Detroit, Michigan]] ([[Jefferson North Assembly Plant]])}} | manufacturer = {{ubl | [[DaimlerChrysler]] (2006–2007) | [[Chrysler LLC]] (2007–2009) | [[Chrysler Group LLC]] (2009–2010) | [[Magna Steyr]] }} | model_years = 2006–2010 | production = July 18, 2005–2010 | class = [[Mid-size SUV]] | designer = Don Renkert (2002) | aka = | layout = [[Front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout|Longitudinal Front-engine, rear-wheel drive]] / [[four-wheel-drive|four-wheel drive]] | body_style = 4-door [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] | engine = {{ubl | 3.0 L ''[[Mercedes-Benz OM642|OM642]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]] ([[turbocharged]] [[diesel fuel|diesel]])|3.7 L ''[[Chrysler PowerTech engine#3.7 EKG|PowerTech]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]] ([[gasoline]])|4.7 L ''[[Chrysler PowerTech engine#4.7|PowerTech]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]] (gasoline / [[E85]])|5.7 L ''[[Chrysler Hemi engine#5.7|Hemi]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]] (gasoline)}} | transmission = {{ubl | 5-speed ''[[5G-Tronic|W5A580]]'' automatic| 5-speed [[Chrysler RFE transmission#545RFE|545RFE]] automatic}} | length = {{convert|188.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|75.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|71.9|-|75.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|4391|-|4829|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} | wheelbase = {{convert|109.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | related = [[Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK)]] | predecessor = | successor = {{ubl | [[Dodge Durango#Third generation .282011.E2.80.93present.29|Dodge Durango]] | [[Jeep Grand Cherokee]] | [[Jeep Grand Commander]] (China) }} | sp = us }}
The '''Jeep Commander''' XK and XH (export diesel) is a [[mid-size SUV]] that was manufactured from 2005 to 2010 by the [[Jeep]] division of the American manufacturer [[Chrysler]].
==Concept car== Jeep exhibited a [[concept car]] named Commander during the 1999 [[auto show]] circuit. The concept featured an experimental [[direct methanol fuel cell]] that produced electricity to charge a [[nickel–metal hydride battery]] pack. Full-time four-wheel drive was by a severe duty electric motor on each axle.<ref>{{cite web|title=1999 Jeep Commander Concept Car |url= http://testdrivejunkie.com/1999-jeep-commander-concept-car/ |website=testdrivejunkie.com |accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> The suspension could be raised {{convert|4|in|mm|0}} for traversing off-road purposes.<ref>{{cite web|title=1999 Jeep Commander - Concepts |url= http://www.carstyling.ru/en/car/1999_jeep_commander/ |website=www.carstyling.ru |accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> The overall styling influenced the development of the [[Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK)|third-generation Grand Cherokee]] that was at that time six years away.<ref>{{cite book|last=Foster |first=Patrick |title=The Story of Jeep|date=2004|publisher=Krause Publications |isbn=9780873497350 |page=274 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpdUEVGU2toC&pg=PA274&dq=1999+Jeep+Commander+a+proposed+fuel-cell |accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="Nunez"/> The concept car had the same height as production Grand Cherokees, but was about {{convert|8|in|mm|0}} wider. This allowed for an interior featuring an extra wide [[Center console (automobile)|center console]] in the front and three bucket seats in the second row. The Commander concept had no relation to the production SUV.<ref name="Nunez">{{cite web|last=Nunez |first=Alex |title=Family Resemblance: Jeeps old & new |url= https://www.autoblog.com/2006/11/23/family-resemblance-jeep-concepts-and-the-grand-cherokee/ |website=Autoblog |date=23 November 2006 |accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
== Production == The production version of the Jeep Commander (XK and the diesel-powered XH export version) debuted at the 2005 [[New York International Auto Show|New York Auto Show]] as a five- or seven-passenger counterpart to the third generation [[Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK)|Jeep Grand Cherokee]]. It was developed to target consumers who wanted a three-rows-of-seats SUV, but designed to be only two inches longer than the existing Grand Cherokee with its two-rows of seats as well as to be assembled on the same production line.<ref>{{cite web|title=2006-2010 Jeep Commander |url= https://www.allpar.com/model/jeep/commander.html |publisher=Allpar |accessdate=31 March 2018}}</ref>
It shared its [[unibody]] construction, independent [[Short long arms suspension|short/long arm]] front suspension and its [[multilink suspension|5-link]] [[live axle|live]] rear axle with the Grand Cherokee on which it was based. It featured an upright windshield and squared-off sides. Its stepped roof was disguised by the roof rack; a design similar to the [[GMC Envoy|GMC Envoy XL]] and [[Chevrolet TrailBlazer|Chevrolet TrailBlazer EXT]]. This allowed the second and third-row seats to be mounted higher than the first-row seats.
[[File:Jeep Commander 002.JPG|thumb|[[Left- and right-hand traffic|RHD]] Jeep Commander in Japan]] [[File:Commanderpanel.jpg|thumb|RHD Interior]]
===Features=== Standard features included: [[electronic stability control]], [[traction control]], electronic roll mitigation, back up sensors, [[immobiliser]], front dual-stage and side curtain [[airbags]], [[Tire-pressure monitoring system|TPMS]], power heated mirrors, [[remote keyless entry]], [[Headlamp#Automatic headlamps|automatic headlights]], ''UConnect'' infotainment system and a full-size spare wheel. Some optional features included: [[Windshield wipers#Rain-sensing wipers|automatic wipers]], a 276-watt [[Boston Acoustics]] premium sound system, hands-free phone integration, dual zone auto climate control, remote start, a power liftgate, heated first and second row seats, auto dimming mirrors, hill start assist, hill descent control, and adjustable pedals. ''Smartbeam'' headlights were also available as well as [[HID headlamp|HID headlight]]s.
The optional ''Command View'' sunroof package included a power front sunroof and two smaller sunroofs over the second row seats. The Commander also had an optional entertainment package which included a DVD player, {{convert|9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} TV, and [[backup camera]]. In Europe and certain other markets like Chile, South Africa, and South Korea, the Commander offered a [[V6 engine|V6]] [[Diesel engine]].
===Off-Road Capabilities=== The Commander was offered with three different four-wheel drive systems: [[Quadra-Trac I]], [[Quadra-Trac II]], and [[Quadra-Drive II]]. Quadra-Trac I was available on models equipped with the 3.7 L engine; it is a full-time system that requires no driver input. Quadra-Trac II was available on models equipped with a [[V8 engine|V8]] engine; it is a full-time system as well but adds a low range as well as a neutral position for towing. Quadra-Drive II expands on Quadra-Trac II by adding electronic [[limited slip differential]]s to the front and rear axles. When equipped with Quadra-Drive II, [[skid plate]]s for the fuel tank, front suspension, and transfer case were also added.
{| class="wikitable" |- |Ground clearance||{{convert|8.3|in|mm|1|abbr=on}} |- |[[Approach angle]]||34° |- |Departure angle||27° |- |[[Breakover angle]]||20° |}
== Trims == '''Base'''/'''Sport''' - 2006-2010: Includes: 3.7 L V6 engine or 4.7 L V8 engine, AM/FM radio with CD player and six speakers, alloy wheels, cloth seats, Automatic transmission. keyless entry, power windows, door locks, and driver's seat, and five-passenger seating; seven passenger seating available.
'''Limited''' - 2006-2010: Includes: 4.7 L or 5.7 L HEMI V8 engine, AM/FM radio with six-disc integral CD changer and six Boston Acoustics speakers, security system, dual power seats, leather seats, and standard seven-passenger seating.
'''Overland''' - 2007-2009: Includes: 5.7 L HEMI V8 engine, AM/FM radio with GPS navigation and six-disc integral CD changer, Sirius satellite radio, wire mesh grille insert, leather-and-suede seats with embroidered Overland logos, wood trimmed steering wheel, leather wrapped emergency brake handle with leather wrapped door handles as well, and dual-panel ''Command View'' sunroof.
'''65th Anniversary Edition''' - only in 2006: Includes 3.7 L or 4.7 L engine, unique 65th anniversary badges on the front doors and front bucket seats, power driver seat, unique embroidered floor mats, folding third row seats, automatic front headlamps, front fog lamps, premium sound system with six speakers and a 276-watt external amplifier, an AM/FM stereo with six-disc, in-dash CD/MP3 changer, Sirius satellite radio, and Radio Data System (RDS), unique darkened seventeen-inch (17"x7.5") alloy wheels, a full-sized spare tire on a matching wheel.
'''Rocky Mountain''' - (2007-2009): Includes 3.7 L or 4.7 L engine, unique Rocky Mountain badges on the front doors and front bucket seats, power driver seat, folding third row seats, automatic front headlamps, front fog lamps, Boston Acoustics premium sound system with six speakers and a 276-watt external amplifier, an AM/FM stereo with six-disc, in-dash CD/MP3 changer, (navigation available), Sirius satellite radio, and Radio Data System (RDS), unique darkened seventeen-inch (17"x7.5") alloy wheels, a full-sized spare tire on a matching wheel.
== Engines == {| class="wikitable" |- !Years !Engine !Power !Torque !Notes |- |2005–2010||3.7 L ''[[Chrysler PowerTech engine#3.7 EKG|PowerTech]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]]|| {{convert|210|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|235|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} || Base/Sport |- |2005–2007||4.7 L ''[[Chrysler PowerTech engine#4.7|PowerTech]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]]|| {{convert|235|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|290|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} || Base/Sport/Limited |- |2008–2009||4.7 L ''[[Chrysler PowerTech engine#4.7|PowerTech]]'' V8|| {{convert|305|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|334|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} || Base/Sport/Limited |- |2005–2008||5.7 L ''[[Chrysler Hemi engine#5.7|Hemi]]'' V8|| {{convert|330|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|370|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} || Limited/Overland |- |2009–2010||5.7 L ''[[Chrysler Hemi engine#5.7|Hemi]]'' V8|| {{convert|360|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|390|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} || Limited/Overland |- |2006–2010||3.0 L ''[[Mercedes-Benz OM642 engine|OM642]]'' Diesel V6 || {{convert|218|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|376|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} || XH - Outside North America |}
==Discontinuation== The Jeep Commander was discontinued after the 2010 model year. Chrysler announced that the 2011 [[Dodge Durango]] would be its successor; which is produced alongside its platform mate the 2011 [[Jeep Grand Cherokee]] at [[Jefferson North Assembly]] in [[Detroit, Michigan]]. Shortly after production ended, Chrysler CEO [[Sergio Marchionne]] said of the Commander, "That vehicle was unfit for human consumption. We sold some. But I don't know why people bought them."<ref>[https://www.leftlanenews.com/marchionne-jeep-commander-was-unfit-for-human-consumption.html Marchionne: Jeep Commander was "unfit for human consumption"]</ref>
In 2017, [[Jeep]] released a three-row concept vehicle based on the [[Jeep Cherokee (KL)]] platform for the Chinese market, called the '''[[Jeep]] Yuntu''', utilizing a plug-in gasoline/electric hybrid power train. <ref>http://www.motortrend.com/news/jeep-yuntu-concept-for-china-looks-to-the-future/</ref>
A three-row version of the [[Jeep Cherokee (KL)]] with slightly altered styling was released exclusively for the Chinese market named the [[Jeep Grand Commander]]. While similar in size to the original Commander, the Grand Commander will offer four-cylinder power. It will not be sold in any other markets. <ref>https://auto.ndtv.com/news/jeep-launches-grand-commander-at-beijing-motor-show-1844466</ref>
Jeep is currently planning a successor to the Commander for the North American market, which may be named the [[Jeep Wagoneer (SJ)|Jeep Grand Wagoneer]]. Based on the [[Ram 1500]] platform, the all-new vehicle will be built in [[Warren, Michigan]] and will share production with a possible [[Dodge Ramcharger]] successor as well. The all-new vehicle, which was first shown to [[Jeep]] dealerships at a dealership meeting in 2017, is due for release in 2019. <ref>https://5thgenrams.com/inside-ram-1500-dt-based-wagoneer-grand-wagoneer/</ref>
== Total American sales == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Calendar year ! Sales |- | 2006<ref name="CheersandGears.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.cheersandgears.com/topic/55253-total-chrysler-llc-december-2007-sales-up-1-percent-on-the-strength-of-retail/ |title=Total Chrysler LLC December 2007 Sales Up 1 Percent on the Strength of Retail |publisher=CheersandGears.com |date=2008-01-03 |accessdate=2009-01-05}}</ref> | 88,497 |- | 2007<ref name="CheersandGears.com"/> | 63,027 |- | 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cheersandgears.com/topic/27526-december-2008-sales-chrysler-llc/ |title= December 2008 Sales: Chrysler LLC |publisher=CheersandGears.com |date=2009-01-05 |accessdate=2009-01-05}}</ref> | 27,694 |- | 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cheersandgears.com/topic/50556-chrysler-group-llc-december-2009/ |title= Chrysler Group LLC December 2009 Sales |publisher=CheersandGears.com |date=2010-01-05 |accessdate=2010-01-05}}</ref> | 12,655 |- | 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cheersandgears.com/topic/74955-december-2010-sales-chrysler/ |title= Chrysler Group LLC December 2010 Sales |publisher=CheersandGears.com |date=2011-01-04 |accessdate=2011-01-04}}</ref> | 8,115 |- | 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allpar.com/news/index.php/2012/01/chrysler-sales-shoot-up-37-26-for-2011 |title=Chrysler sales shoot up 37% (26% for 2011) |publisher=allpar.com |accessdate=2012-01-04 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120110023127/http://www.allpar.com/news/index.php/2012/01/chrysler-sales-shoot-up-37-26-for-2011 |archivedate=2012-01-10 }}</ref> | 105 |}

: ''See also [[Jeep Cherokee]] for other models using this name'' {{Infobox automobile |image = 1975 Jeep Cherokee in beige, front right.jpg |caption = 1975 Jeep Cherokee |name = Jeep Cherokee (SJ) |manufacturer = [[Jeep]] ([[American Motors]]) |body_style = 2-door [[station wagon|wagon]]
4-door wagon |production = 1974–1983 |assembly = {{Unbulleted list| [[United States]] | [[Argentina]] | [[Australia]] {{cite web |url= http://www.4wd1.com/Editorial-16.htm |title= Jeep in Australia 1978 - 1991 |work= 4wd1.com |accessdate= 11 February 2016 |url-status= dead |archiveurl= https://archive.is/20141115084501/http://www.4wd1.com/Editorial-16.htm |archivedate= 15 November 2014 }} | Mexico }} |class = Full-size [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] |platform = [[Jeep SJ|SJ]] |related = [[Jeep Wagoneer (SJ)]]
[[Jeep Gladiator]] |layout = [[Front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout|Front-engine, rear-wheel drive]] / [[Front-engine, four-wheel-drive layout|four-wheel drive]] |engine = {{Unbulleted list| {{convert|258|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''AMC'' [[AMC Straight-6 engine|I6]] | {{convert|360|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''AMC'' [[AMC V8 engine|V8]] 2-barrel | {{convert|360|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''AMC'' V8 4-barrel | {{convert|401|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} ''AMC'' V8 4-barrel }} |transmission = {{Unbulleted list| 4-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]] | 3-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] }} |width = {{convert|74.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length = {{convert|186.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = {{convert|66.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |weight = {{convert|4514|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} |wheelbase = {{convert|108.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | successor = [[Jeep Cherokee (XJ)]] }} [[File:Jeep Cherokee SJ 2-door tan+white r.jpg|right|thumb|1974 Jeep Cherokee, base model]] [[File:Jeep Cherokee SJ Chief S f.jpg |right|thumb|Wide-track Jeep Cherokee]] [[File:1983 Jeep Cherokee (SJ) two-door at 2015 AMO show 2of5.jpg|thumb|right|1983 Jeep Cherokee 2-door]] The [[Jeep SJ|SJ]] series '''Jeep Cherokee''' is a full-size [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] that was produced from 1974 through 1983 by [[Jeep]]. It was based on the [[Jeep Wagoneer (SJ)|Wagoneer]] that was originally designed by [[Brooks Stevens]] in 1963. == Development == The Cherokee was a redesigned reintroduction of a two-door body style, with a single fixed rear side window with an optional flip-out section. Previously, a two-door version had been available in the Jeep Wagoneer line from 1963 to 1967, although this had the same [[Pillar (car)|pillar]] and window configuration as the four-door Wagoneer. The Cherokee was marketed as the "sporty" two-door variant of Jeep's [[station wagon]]. The term "Sport Utility Vehicle" appears for the first time in the 1974 Cherokee sales brochure.{{cite book |last=Allen |first=Jim |title=Jeep: Collector's Library |publisher=Motorbooks, MBI Publishing | date=2003 |page=168 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4ywrhvzRCsEC&pg=PA168&dq=term+Sport+Utility+appears+for+the+first+time+1974 |isbn= 978-0-7603-1486-9 |authorlink=Jim Allen (4x4 writer)}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20180103154658/https://www.autopaper.com/images/2214/98959-02.jpg '74 Jeep brochure picture – Cherokee page (archived)][https://web.archive.org/web/20161219202409/http://www.lov2xlr8.no/brochures/jeep/74jeep.html '74 Jeep Cherokee brochure – front (archived)] A four-door was not added to the lineup until 1977. The initial, 1974 Cherokees were only available in the standard "narrow track" configuration as base models (Model 16), or top-of-the-line S models (Model 17).{{cite web |title=The Unofficial First-Year Cherokee Registry |url=http://www.ifsja.org/forums/vb/showthread.php?t=150372 |accessdate=16 September 2017}} Later, the [[Car model#Trim levels|trim level]]s of the Cherokee included the S (Sport; 1974—), Chief (1976–1983), Golden Eagle (1978–1979), Golden Hawk, and Laredo (1980–1983).{{Cite web |url=http://www.classiccarstodayonline.com/2015/06/15/a-look-back-at-the-1963-1991-jeep-wagoneer-a-guide-to-year-to-year-changes-2/ |title=A look back at the 1963 – 1991 Jeep Wagoneer: a guide to year-to-year changes |access-date=2018-01-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170708213534/http://www.classiccarstodayonline.com/2015/06/15/a-look-back-at-the-1963-1991-jeep-wagoneer-a-guide-to-year-to-year-changes-2/ |archive-date=2017-07-08 |url-status=dead }} Golden Eagle and Golden Hawk were graphics packages; the Laredo was more of an upholstery package. For the final year only, in 1983 a new “Pioneer” package was standard on the four-door and optional on the two-door. Cherokee Chief and Laredo packages were still available, but only on widewheel two-door models. == Performance == Engine choices consisted of [[AMC Straight-6 engine|AMC I6]] or [[AMC V8 engine|V8]] powerplants. When it was equipped with the net {{convert|215|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} {{convert|401|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[AMC V8 engine]], it would outrun other 4x4s in its class, and, with 3.07:1 highway gearing, could reach speeds in excess of {{convert|100|mph|0|adj=off}} (early models had 120 mph speedometers). A range of AMC engines were offered: the {{convert|110|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} {{convert|258|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} inline six-cylinder, a {{convert|175|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} {{convert|360|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 with two-barrel [[carburetor]], a {{convert|195|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} four-barrel 360, the {{convert|401|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} V8, and even a Zeitgeist/Peugeot turbo diesel, albeit very rare. The durable 401 had a forged crankshaft and forged connecting rods, in addition to the high nickel content block of the other AMC V8s. The 401 was discontinued at the end of 1978. After [[takeover|acquiring]] AMC in 1987, [[Chrysler]] kept the {{convert|360|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 in production until 1991 for the [[Jeep Wagoneer (SJ)|Jeep Grand Wagoneer]]. The SJ Cherokee - along with the Wagoneer and J-Truck - continues to hold the record for the largest engine ever offered in a Jeep, with the 401's displacement surpassing that of even the SRT-8 [[Grand Cherokee]]'s {{convert|392|CID|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chrysler Hemi Engine|Hemi]]. ==Mechanicals== A T-18/T-18a four-speed manual gearbox was standard for all years, while through 1979 the [[General Motors]]' [[Turbo-Hydramatic]] TH400, more commonly fitted to 3/4- and 1-ton trucks rather than SUVs, was optional. For comparison, GM’s own SUV, the [[Chevy Blazer]], used the TH350 automatic. After 1979, the TH400 was replaced by the [[Chrysler]] [[TorqueFlite]] 727. A gear-driven [[AMC and Jeep transmissions#Dana 20|Dana 20 transfer case]] with 2.03:1 low range was standard with the manual gearbox (which had a much lower first gear of 6.3:1), while the TH400 automatics received the permanent four-wheel-drive [[Jeep four-wheel-drive systems|QuadraTrac]] system. The chain-driven, aluminum QuadraTrac was advanced at the time.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} It included a vacuum-operated center differential lock. The [[transfer case]] was offset, allowing it to sit just above the frame to avoid obstacles, and the chain itself is larger than nearly any other.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} A test by ''Petersen's Complete Book of Four-Wheel Drive'' reported that the Cherokee was the only vehicle unable to be [[dynamometer|dynoed]] because the transfer case would not allow the rear wheels to spin, unlike the other full-time four-wheel-drive vehicles being tested.{{cite book|year=1975 |page=98 |title=Petersen's Complete Book of Four-Wheel Drive |publisher=Petersen Publishing |isbn= 9780822700999 }} In the off-road test, the same held true. This transfer case was also employed successfully in Baja races, for example by [[Roger Mears]] in the [[Baja 1000]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} A 2.57:1 low range was optional on QuadraTrac. In 1976, the Cherokee Chief package was introduced. Aside from trim changes, this model received larger fenders and wider axles, allowing larger tires to be fitted to further improve off-road ability. Four-door models were not available with "wide-track" axles. The Golden Eagle package was introduced in 1979. It was the same as the Chief but had denim interior upholstery, gold painted steel wheels and distinctive exterior trim that included a large gold eagle decal on the hood. In 1980 the high end Laredo package was introduced. [[Dana 44]] axles were used both in the front and the rear at least through 1979. Brake hardware was mostly General Motors equipment (sourced from the straight axle 1/2 ton 4x4 light duty truck and SUV line including the six lug rims), with disc brakes up front (optional on earlier models) and drum brakes in the rear. All Cherokees had semi-elliptical leaf springs in the front and rear. == International markets == The Cherokee was marketed in left and right hand drive countries (such as the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and [[Australia]]). Main production of the Cherokee was in [[Toledo, Ohio]]. ===Australia=== The SJ Cherokees were assembled in [[Brisbane]], Australia from 1981. The initial units were fully built imports that needed to be partly disassembled for right-hand-drive. Later Jeep Australia began full assembly of the SUV and J20 trucks from [[knock-down kit]]s. Problems with spare parts, quality control, the limited capacity of the assembly plant (a maximum of 60 Cherokee/J20 vehicles per month), and lack of dealer support (many were multi-franchise stores so Jeeps were not their focus) were disadvantages to maintaining market share. Australian tariff regulations defined "real" 4x4 vehicles as having a separate frame and chassis construction and had a 25% duty and no quota restrictions, while vehicles with an integral chassis were classified as "cars" and subject to both an import quantity restriction and a 57.5% tax. This meant that assembly of the SJ models continued even after the modern, [[Jeep Cherokee (XJ)|unibody XJ compact model]] had been introduced by AMC. All Cherokee assembly was discontinued in Australia by 1985, three years after the SJ had been replaced in the [[United States|U.S.]] by the XJ. ===Argentina=== In [[Argentina]], the Cherokee was manufactured by [[Industrias Kaiser Argentina]], who renamed the SUV the Jeep Gladiator.{{cn|I can find no evidence of anything but pickups and possibly panel vans being manufactured by IKA|date=February 2020}} It was offered with a single type of engine, the locally built [[Jeep Tornado engine|Tornado inline-six]], and was equipped with 3-speed manual transmission. Later Jeeps received an updated and more powerful version of this engine with seven main bearings, called the "Torino." == Awards == In February 1974, the Jeep Cherokee was the first vehicle to earn ''Four Wheeler'' Magazine's "Achievement Award" that later became the annual "Four Wheeler of the Year" recognition.{{cite web |last=Perronne |first=Craig |title=40 Years Of Old Photos 4x4 Trucks & Desert Racing 1960s-1990s - A Stroll Through the Images of the Past |publisher=Four Wheeler Magazine |date=June 2002 |url= http://www.fourwheeler.com/featuredvehicles/129_0206_40_year_old_photos_4x4_trucks_desert_racing/index.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101127062213/http://www.fourwheeler.com/featuredvehicles/129_0206_40_year_old_photos_4x4_trucks_desert_racing/index.html |archivedate=27 November 2010 |accessdate=11 February 2016}} == See also == * [[Jeep Wagoneer (SJ)]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Jeep Cherokee (SJ)}} * [http://www.ifsja.org/ International Full Size Jeep Association] * [http://wagoneers.com/ wagoneers.com] {{Jeep early timeline}} {{Jeep Car Timeline}} [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Jeep vehicles|Cherokee]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1974]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]]
